PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Rt Hon. Sir Billy Snedden) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) views with grave concern the alarming carnage on the nation's roads, particularly over the recent Easter holidays;
(2) calls on the Government to allocate extra funding to the States for special road projects in areas with high accident rates; and
(3) calls on the Prime Minister and the Minister for Transport to encourage all State governments to-
(a) adopt uniform traffic codes;
(b) increase road safety education;
(c) adopt stricter licensing law procedures;
(d) increase highway patrols; and

(e) hold referendums, in applicable States, at the earliest possible time to determine whether the majority of Australian citizens are in favour of random breath testing and harsher penalties for drink drivers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) notes with concern the anti-competitive features of the 2 Airline Agreement ;

(2) deplores the restrictive arrangements being developed by associate and or subsidiary companies of Ansett Airlines, TNT Ltd and News Corporation Ltd to confine on-carriage passengers from feeder air services to the Ansett Airlines jet network; and
(3) calls on the Minister for Transport to initiate action immediately to ensure that passengers from feeder air services have ready access to the jet services operated by Trans Australia Airlines.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a question on notice which I asked on 17 February and which is still not answered seeking the sources of information in respect of El Salvador. Is the Minister aware that Rafael Gonzales, a representative of the Democratic Revolutionary Front of El Salvador, visited Australia between 6 and 17 April and that that gentleman addressed a large number of public meetings in various cities of Australia on the problems of El Salvador and the possible solutions? Did the Minister have a chance to meet Mr Gonzales and, if he did not, did any representative of the Department of Foreign Affairs have a chance to meet that gentleman? If, so, what will be the result of any discussions that took place?

—I am aware of the visit to which the honourable gentleman referred. No , I did not meet Mr Gonzales. To the best of my knowledge, no meeting took place between him and officers of my Department, but I will check.

—I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs to recent Press reports in Australia alleging widespread and increasing use of child slave labour in Thailand. Is the Minister aware of these reports? Have the allegations contained in them been investigated? Is it a fact that such practices violate a number of international conventions and declarations which have been ratified by Australia? As Australia has in recent times expressed concern to the governments of the Philippines and Canada about their respective treatment of dogs and seals, will the Government now bring to the attention of the Government of Thailand the concern of the Australian people regarding the practice of child slave labour in that country?

—The Australian Government is concerned about any allegations of mistreatment of children of the kind alleged by the honourable gentleman. I have seen the reports to which he has referred. I have asked my Department to investigate them. Should such an investigation indicate that there is substance in the reports, certainly action will be taken along the lines suggested by the honourable member.

—Is the Prime Minister concerned about the allegation made by the Premier of Queensland that the Aboriginal land rights movement is part of a communist inspired plot to create a separate black nation within Australia? Has the Prime Minister any evidence which would support such an allegation? If not, will he repudiate this statement on behalf of this Government and this Parliament?
—I have no such evidence.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Capital Territory. I point out that I ask it in the environment of Anzac Day being only a few days away. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the actions of a Canberra resident who has painted a swastika on his garage door?
—What?
—Yes, I know that it is hard to believe. What is the Minister's response to this behaviour? What is the Minister doing about it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of all honourable members of this House, and I believe on behalf of all Australians, I express my abhorrence and disgust at the action of a resident of Canberra who has painted a swastika on the garage of his residence at Holtermann Place, Charnwood.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members-Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that members of the Labor Party think this is funny. I regard this as an exceptionally serious matter. On page 3 of today's Canberra Times a photograph is published showing a swastika which has been painted on a garage door and which is about 6 feet in height. The artist, a Mr Alan McDonald, a student at the Canberra College of Advanced Education, had this to say:

ANSWER.PARA: It is the first of several different paintings I intend to do to brighten the place up a bit--

This vile symbol, the most cursed in the history of mankind, is coming off the garage door and it will be coming off today. I believe this is a deliberate outrage, an affront against decency and a despicable act-coming, as the honourable, gallant and distinguished member for Kennedy said, three days before Anzac Day. I am taking immediate legal advice to ascertain my powers to act in this matter. At this very moment the Assistant Secretary of the Legislation and Policy Co-ordination Division in the Department of the Capital Territory, Mr Hedley, and other officers of my Department are waiting on Mr McDonald at his residence formally to direct and require him to remove that symbol forthwith. In addition, I am in conference with the Minister for Administrative Services who is responsible, of course, for the Australian Federal Police. I assure the House and I assure the Australian public that the action necessary will be taken to have this symbol removed.

In addition, I draw attention to the fact that the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police, Sir Colin Woods, has granted approval for a group from the Canberra College of Advanced Education to take part in the Anzac Day march on Sunday in Canberra. Inquiries are under way and if it is ascertained that Mr Alan McDonald is connected with that group from the CCAE, I indicate-the Minister for Administrative Services will confirm this-that appropriate action will be taken with respect to the permission already granted. I believe everybody in this House would join with me in saying that the public exhibition of this swastika is disgraceful, disgusting and an affront to thousands and thousands of people who shortly will be--

TALK.START.PARA: —He has achieved what he set out to do. He has got billy goats like you talking about it.

—I am sorry that the honourable member for Port Adelaide appears to think that this is not a matter of seriousness. He ought to be ashamed of himself. I should like to make one further comment while I am on my feet in relation to the observance of Anzac Day on Sunday. It is a national day of remembrance. On behalf of the Government I appeal to all those participating to treat it as such. On behalf of the Government I indicate in advance that any persons or groups who seek to disrupt or desecrate this national day of remembrance will find their actions will be stoutly resisted.
—Heil Hitler.
—A point of order, Mr Speaker. I ask that the person who called out the words 'Heil Hitler' from the Australian Labor Party benches identify himself and withdraw that offensive remark.
—I call the Leader of the Opposition.
—We have just heard from the Minister in charge of national bathos.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Hodgman

TALK.START.PARA: —I call on you to withdraw that immediately.

INTERJECT.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members on the Opposition benches will remain silent. There was nothing unparliamentary in what the Leader of the Opposition said, but he should ask his question and not make any comment.
—I now move to pathos. I ask a question of the Minister for Administrative Services.

—A point of order, Mr Speaker. As I went to resume my seat a member of the Australian Labor Party called out the words 'Heil Hitler'. As that was clearly directed at me, I ask that that person withdraw that remark. I take the strongest exception to it. I seek your protection, Mr Speaker, and ask that that remark be withdrawn and that the man who said it be publicly identified.

—I did not hear the remark. If the remark was made, I am sure that it was not directed at the Minister. I do not believe that if a remark such as that were made it would have been directed at the Minister.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Hodgman

TALK.START.PARA: —I appeal to you, Mr Speaker. I heard it clearly. It was heard by other members. There is no doubt that it was directed to me. If the honourable member has the decency to stand up and identify himself, I ask that he withdraw that remark.

INTERJECT.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order. If the words were spoken by a member and the member will identify himself, I shall call for them to be withdrawn. Were the words used by any honourable member?
—I used the words, Mr Speaker.
—Were the words used by the honourable member directed to the Minister?
—No, Mr Speaker. It was a form of salutation in consideration of a nazi-type answer given by the Minister.
—I object to that. You are a liar.
—The honourable member for Shortland will withdraw those remarks that he made in his explanation-that is, his description of the nature of the reply. I ask him to withdraw.
—I could not quite hear what you said, Mr Speaker.
—The honourable member for Shortland, while at the Dispatch Box, used words in his description of the answer which I ask him to withdraw.
—I said, Mr Speaker, that it was a salutation. If it upsets the Minister, I shall withdraw.
—The honourable gentleman will withdraw unqualifiedly.
—I withdraw, Mr Speaker.
—The honourable member has withdrawn. I call upon the Minister to withdraw.
—I should like the Minister--
—The honourable member for Shortland will resume his seat. The Minister will withdraw the statement that he made, directed at the honourable member for Shortland.
—I withdraw, Mr Speaker. I ask, again, for the withdrawal of the words 'Heil Hitler', which I regard as personally offensive and which were directed to me. I appeal to you, Mr Speaker.

—The Minister will resume his seat. I have asked honourable members whether the words were used. One honourable member has said that he used the words. I asked him whether they were directed at the Minister. He said 'no'. Therefore, I cannot ask him to withdraw something that was not directed at the Minister.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Hodgman

TALK.START.PARA: —Again-

INTERJECT.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I make no apology for this. Mr Speaker, I appeal to you. The honourable member for Shortland denied that he directed that remark to me. I submit, with respect, that that is a very hard statement to accept, and I ask you, Mr Speaker, to ask the honourable member to state to whom he was talking. The fact is that the remark that he made was offensive. I seek a withdrawal, Mr Speaker.

—Order! The Minister has made his point. I ask him to resume his seat . The fact is that the House will judge what words were said and the manner in which they were directed, and I shall not pursue the matter further.

—In a somewhat more prosaic form I ask a question of the Minister for Administrative Services. I refer to repeated commitments by the Prime Minister and the Minister for Administrative Services that those who give evidence to the joint police task force about the activities of the Nugan Hand group will be given protection and confidentiality. Is he aware of one such person who, as an investigator for the Army in the late 1960s, uncovered a wide spectrum of illegal activities by Nugan Hand and people connected with Nugan Hand, including currency violation, arms trafficking and tax evasion? Is the Minister aware that this person provided a comprehensive report of these activities to the Government early in 1971? As a result of this report is he aware that this person claims to have responded to an official personal request to give detailed evidence about his investigations to members of the task force in Canberra in February last year? Does he know that that person further claims that within 36 hours of co-operating with the task force, information about his evidence was circulating in various quarters in Melbourne? Is he also aware that at the same time, according to this person, a chain of connected events began that had the effect of destroying his livelihood, causing the loss of his house and threatening the physical wellbeing of his family? In the light of these circumstances, will the Prime Minister and the Minister for Administrative Services guarantee that witnesses who come forward to testify on the activities of the Nugan Hand group will be fully protected from any future victimisation, harassment or physical danger?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can only assume that the person about whom the Leader of the Opposition is talking is the person I have in mind. It is very difficult, without knowing whom we are talking about, to be certain. When the Leader of the Opposition made similar allegations on AM yesterday I took the step of writing to the Leader of the Opposition asking him to inform me as to whom he was talking about and particularly to substantiate the claims he made on AM that the Australian Federal Police, by implication, leaked 'like a sieve'. I took that as a very serious allegation. I certainly intend to follow that up to make sure that any evidence that the Leader of the Opposition has is acted upon.

ANSWER.PARA: Before I respond completely to the Leader of the Opposition I want to make two points about this continuing debate in Parliament. This debate began when the Leader of the Opposition accused the Deputy Prime Minister of being involved in trying to stop an inquiry into the Nugan Hand group. That was found to be totally false and, worse, we all now know that the Leader of the Opposition used the forms of this House quite improperly to bring that accusation against the Deputy Prime Minister. That is the first point. The second stream of allegations that the Leader of the Opposition made was based on documents that were given to him by an ex-officer named Bailey. The House will recall that I asked the Leader of the Opposition to table those documents in the House, as he strung the thing along for all the political value he could get out of it. I advise the House that all the documents that we finally got out of the Leader of the Opposition had been either with the joint task force investigating Nugan Hand or with the Royal Commissioner.

TALK.START.PARA: —Except one.

—Except one, but a copy of that document was with the files that we gave to the Royal Commissioner. The point I am making is that the stream of allegations that the Leader of the Opposition brought into this House wasted our time week after week. If he had told us what was on those files and what documents he had we would have been able to tell the Opposition that the matters were already being investigated and that this Government had provided all the relevant files to the two investigations.

ANSWER.PARA: I come now to the gentleman about whom I think the Leader of the Opposition was talking. I can only assume it is the same person because he still has not had the decency to tell me who it is, despite the fact that I have asked him. If we are talking about the same gentleman, it is true that this ex-army officer did come forward to the Australian Federal Police with information concerning Nugan Hand. The Federal Police took it very seriously and invited members of the New South Wales police force who formed the Joint Task Force on Drug Trafficking which was investigating Nugan Hand, also to interview this gentleman. This was done. Later in the year, towards the end of 1981, after all those investigations were under way, the gentleman wrote to the Prime Minister and accused the Australian Federal Police of leaking or providing information, I presume to his competitors, which meant that his business was in the hands of creditors. The Government immediately acted on that information. It was passed to me and I immediately had conferences with the Australian Federal Police and my Department .

As a result of the accusation that leakage by the Australian Federal Police caused the disruption or closure of his business, this gentleman, on the advice given him by my Department, was invited to take the matter to the Ombudsman. That is where the matter now is-being investigated by the Ombudsman. All honourable members will recall that the Government introduced that procedure and that this Parliament endorsed the concept that if complaints were made against any police officers the Ombudsman would be there to investigate them impartially and report to the Government. The present situation is that the Australian Federal Police has provided an interim report to the Ombudsman. However, the Australian Federal Police Commissioner is not satisfied with that report and more information is to be provided to the Ombudsman. Therefore, we await the Ombudsman's investigation.

TALK.START.PARA: —What protection will you offer? That is the question.

—One second-the Leader of the Opposition has made such a fool of himself on this matter; he ought to stop making more of a fool of himself. The final point is that as late as 19 April, the beginning of this week, my Department checked with the Ombudsman. It has been informed-and I have been subsequently advised-that the Ombudsman has been in touch with the gentleman concerned and that that gentleman is happy with the way in which the investigation is going.

—Is the Minister for Housing and Construction aware of criticism of the Commonwealth Government by the housing Ministers of both New South Wales and Victoria which alleges that houses provided for servicemen are being left unoccupied for lengthy periods? Will the Minister tell the House what action is being taken to ensure that surplus servicemen's houses are released for use by families in need of accommodation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the feelings of the New South Wales and Victorian housing Ministers on this matter in particular. At the outset I say that obviously they are confused. Defence housing is not a part of welfare housing. It is owned by the Department of Defence and is for the housing of Service personnel and their families. Under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement ( Servicemen) there are arrangements whereby the Minister for Housing and Construction can inform the State housing Ministers that certain houses are surplus to defence requirements. Alternatively, the State housing Ministers can request the Federal Minister for Housing and Construction to give to them houses which they believe are surplus to the requirements of the Defence Department. It is true that occasionally houses that are owned by the Defence Department are left vacant, but there are very good reasons for that. Quite obviously, Service transfers and repostings take place. The houses concerned may not be in the required location and may be unsuitable. The Department of Defence keeps the matter under very close scrutiny. When it is quite obvious that the houses are surplus to requirements, the Department of Defence immediately advises me and I, in turn, notify the State housing Ministers that they are available for the provision of welfare housing.
—That is not happening and you know it.

—What I have stated is true. In cases in which it is not clear to the Department of Defence that houses are required by it, the Department advises me and in many cases I come to an arrangement with the particular State housing Minister to transfer the houses to him temporarily. This presents enormous difficulties. It is quite easy to get people into these houses but it is very difficult indeed to get them out when the Department of Defence requires the houses for defence personnel. To sum up, the Defence Department is responsible for providing accommodation for defence personnel. Notwithstanding the efforts that it has made over the years, in many areas there is a shortage for such personnel and their families. We as a government, inspired by the Minister for Defence, are doing what we can to overcome that lag, but the Defence Department is not responsible for building up welfare housing stocks. The Department of Defence and the Ministry of Housing and Construction cannot be blamed by the States of New South Wales and Victoria for their failing to provide welfare housing in their respective States.

ANSWER.PARA: Since 1 July 1981, 303 houses have been returned permanently to the States and 13 have been returned on a temporary basis. The Department of Housing and Construction and the Department of Defence, however, cannot be looked upon--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Minister is not fair dinkum. The Government has just knocked a million dollars off the housing grant for the Services.
—The honourable member for Newcastle will resume his seat. There is no point of order.

—The State Ministers for housing cannot expect the Federal Department of Defence and Department of Housing and Construction to overcome the obvious disinterest of State Ministers in welfare housing. They want to talk a lot about it but they do very little about it.

—I ask another question of the Minister for Administrative Services. He will recall that in answering me a few minutes ago he declared that I had wasted the time of this House week after week in a totally unproductive way by raising matters of concern about the activities of the organisation Nugan Hand. If that is so, I ask him: Why was it then necessary for six weeks of that so- called unproductive exercise to prod the Government into dramatically expanding the terms of reference of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking in a way in which any reasonable person would describe as a humiliating climb-down for the Government and a remarkable victory for the Opposition?
—The honourable gentleman will ask for information and cease his comments.

—If the exercise contributed nothing in facts which were not already well known to the Government, why did the Government not act earlier initially to provide terms of reference for the Stewart Royal Commission sufficiently wide to cover all those matters it will now investigate as a result of an expansion of the terms of reference this week? Can we safely conclude that the Minister's problem is not a dyslectic one and therefore it must be one of competence?

—The Government has always taken the allegations made about Nugan Hand extremely seriously. But more than that, as well as taking the matter seriously, our record has been a record of action in ensuring that the matter was investigated. I will demonstrate again why the Leader of the Opposition is a fool on this matter. He may be able to convince some of the gullible people on the other side of the House that somehow he is in front on the matter--
—The Minister will resume with his answer to the question.
—But the truth of the matter, Mr Speaker, is that the Government-and I will demonstrate it in a moment-was always a couple of steps in front of him on this matter.
—Ha, ha!
—Well, listen for a moment.
—What a morning-Michael Hodgman and now Kevin Newman, both from Tasmania!
—Order! The Minister will resume his seat. The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting during the answer and I ask all honourable members on the Opposition benches to cease interjecting.

—If I may just go back over the record, it will demonstrate what I have just said. The first thing that happened with the Nugan Hand group was that the Prime Minister, in taking the initiative, extended the terms of reference of the Joint Task Force of Commonwealth-New South Wales police forces to investigate the matter. That was the first thing-a deliberate attempt to make sure that the matter was under investigation. Then we came to the matter of debates in this House. It was pointed out to the Leader of the Opposition that that task force, on our initiative, was investigating the matter, and consistently through the debate that we had on the matter I pointed out two things to the Leader of the Opposition. First of all, there was the Stewart Royal Commission investigating matters that at least related to Nugan Hand. I admitted in debate that I was not certain whether, and the advice I have received was not certain whether, the Stewart Royal Commission could investigate the matter, but the advice I was receiving indicated that on balance it probably could. That was said consistently during the debate. We came to a morning when serious allegations were made afresh by the Leader of the Opposition. What I did was this: I said, 'Let us take the new matters which the Leader of the Opposition has introduced', and I sent them to Mr Justice Stewart myself. The whole Parliament endorsed that action. More than that, at the same time I pointed out that when the Commonwealth set down the Royal Commission in association with the States the terms of reference were such that, if necessary, they could be expanded. The Premiers agreed with that. The Prime Minister agreed with that. That is what we said. To summarise, we had set up a joint task force- Long before the Leader of the Opposition was calling for extended terms of reference for the Stewart Royal Commission, I had informed this House that we were willing to extend the terms of reference and that I and the Government were testing the terms of reference on the information that the Leader of the Opposition had given us. That is the position. It demonstrates our willingness at all times to act. For the Leader of the Opposition to claim that he has had some moral victory is absolutely ridiculous on the facts.

—I ask the Minister for Trade and Resources whether it is the intention of his Department to follow up the reported tremendous reception which the Japanese gave to the promoted consumption of kangaroo steaks. I ask this question because of the downturn in the kangaroo culling industry in Maranoa. I see the Japanese reception to our 'roo steaks as a great opportunity to develop a new market and for this valuable product to help offset some of the short beef quota to Japan.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen some Press reports about the promotion of Australian kangaroo game meat in Japan. From those reports there seems to have been some degree of acceptance. However, the level of acceptance on a commercial basis is something which I do not know. I think that at this stage it is very questionable as to just how much penetration or how much real interest in Japan there is for kangaroo meat. I am certain that whatever penetration is made into the Japanese market it will not have any bearing on our traditional exports of beef.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Health explain to the House why unemployment beneficiaries and special beneficiaries are the only groups of social security beneficiaries who are denied access to the free pharmaceuticals scheme?
—I will regard the question as being on notice. I will seek advice from the Minister for Health and let the honourable gentleman have an answer as soon as possible.

—I direct my question, truly without notice, to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is he aware that a constituent of mine, Mrs Ana Voita, formerly of Romania, has today commenced a hunger to death strike in a last resort, desperate bid, to urge the Romanian Government to allow her brother to migrate to Australia? Is the Minister aware that the Australian Government long ago approved the actual application but the Government in Romania continues to act as if neither the approval nor the man even exists? Does the Minister agree that after five months tenacious intervention by me, which has come to nought, it is time for us all to do what we can to bring a touch of humanity to the face of the Government of Romania and to cause it at the very least to consider the application, which has undoubted merits? Finally, does the Minister agree, almost on the eve of Anzac Day, that those who have laid down their lives for our country and freedom have made a huge contribution to our often taken for granted position of being one of the best places in the world in which to live?

—I certainly agree with the last remark of the honourable gentleman. I am aware of his unremitting efforts on behalf of his constituents. Unfortunately , the record of the Romanian Government in relation to requests for family reunions of the kind mentioned by the honourable gentleman can be described only as lamentable. That Government has been extremely obstructive in efforts to re- unite families in the way that the honourable gentleman has described. However, I do not believe that the most likely way to overcome this problem is by using the hunger strike technique that the honourable gentleman says one of his constituents has adopted. I urge him to use his influence on her to give up any attempt at a hunger strike. The Australian Government takes every opportunity with Romania, and other eastern European countries which have been equally obstructive on this issue, to try to have people reunited with their families when Australia has indicated that there are no bars to their admission. If the honourable gentleman wishes to provide me with specific details of this case, I will see what can be done.

—Is the Minister for Administrative Services aware of a letter from Margaret Llewellyn complaining about high housing interest rates which was published in the Melbourne Age access columns on 20 March 1982? Is the Minister aware that Margaret Llewellyn was subsequently sent by mail from the Government Information Unit, and quite unsolicited, an information sheet on the Government' s new housing package? Will the Minister agree that the transmission of this unsolicited information is an invasion of the personal privacy of Margaret Llewellyn? Will the Minister confirm that the Government Information Unit has been instructed to forward such material or propaganda to all Australians who complain about Government policy? Will the Minister advise how much this procedure is costing Australian taxpayers? Should not these funds be used for necessary and essential welfare services?
—I am not aware of the article, nor am I aware of what the Government Information Unit-if indeed it did send anything-may have done in this matter.
—They did; it is here.

—All right; let me finish. What I am aware of is that the Government Information Unit provides facts on policies and actions of this Government. I would have thought that any citizen who received such information would be better informed as a result of it. I will have the matter investigated and provide an answer for the honourable member.

—I direct my question to the Treasurer. Can he confirm that the Government's borrowings overseas are conducted on European markets through negotiations between Treasury representatives and European banks? For these services do the banks receive a front end commission of approximately three- quarters of one per cent? Is it also correct that the Reserve Bank is the exclusive source of advice to the Treasury on such matters? Can the Treasurer confirm that, in regard to loans raised in the United States, the Chase Manhattan Bank is the source of the negotiations? Does the Treasurer agree that it would be in Australia's best interests for the Australian banking system to be more involved in negotiating loans for both the public and private sector on international money markets? Will he examine ways in which the expertise of Australian banks can be both improved and utilised in this most important area?

—I thank the honourable member for Bradfield for a very good question. I will not try to answer all of it today. I simply say to the honourable gentleman that it is the wish of the Government to involve the services of the Australian banks to the maximum extent practicable, and in the interests of borrowing at the finest margins obtainable. It has to be borne in mind that quite often Australia can get the best deal in its borrowings by using the services of a bank or a group of financial institutions closer to the market in question. Traditionally, Australian Governments have been able to borrow at very fine margins and therefore it is in the interests of Australian taxpayers that we take advantage of the best available advice in respect of individual markets. I will investigate whether there are any additional ways in which the services of Australian financial institutions can be involved. In that context, I indicate to the honourable member that a couple of years ago, at my initiative, there was a greater involvement of Australian institutions in borrowings in the Japanese market.

—My question is also directed to the Treasurer. I refer to his reply to me in this House on 20 August last year concerning resource development. I ask: Does the Treasurer recall saying that it was absurd to accuse him or the Department of the Treasury of attempting to suppress State government figures on resource infrastructure? How does he reconcile this answer with a letter from his departmental head, Mr John Stone, to the Secretary to the Department of Industry and Commerce, Mr Neil Currie, four months earlier in April 1981, a copy of which I would like incorporated in Hansard? Is the Treasurer aware that Mr Stone in his letter detailed his concern about the proposed publication of the State government figures and asked Mr Currie to reconsider releasing the figures because of the difficulties this would create for the Commonwealth? Is he also aware that Mr Stone says in his letter that the Treasurer very strongly shares Mr Stone's view on this matter? In the light of this letter, will the Treasurer now say why he misled the House last August in seeking to defend himself--
—Order! The honourable gentleman is not entitled to include that comment in his question.
—Why did the Treasurer last August seek to defend himself against my charge of suppression of resource figures?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the Treasurer, is leave granted to incorporate the letter in Hansard?

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
The Treasury Canberra, ACT 2600 Office of the Secretary 20 April 1981 Mr N. S. Currie, C.B.E.
Secretary
Department of Industry and
Commerce
Edmund Barton Building
Barton, ACT 2600
Dear Neil
PROPOSED SCHEDULE OF INFRASTRUCTURE PROJECTS

I understand that your Department has recently been collecting information from , inter alia, relevant State and Commonwealth authorities regarding their proposed investment in infrastructure over the next several years, and that publication of such a schedule is envisaged within the next couple of weeks as a supplement to the schedule of ''Major Manufacturing and Mining Investment Projects'' relating to the private sector.

My officers have expressed their concern about this project on several occasions, but I understand the attitude of your officers to be that a decision now not to publish would be embarrassing because of undertakings given to the State authorities.

The purpose of this letter is to convey to you personally my concern about the proposed publication of these estimates. There is, first, the question of the meaning and reliability of such estimates and their potential for misuse. I understand, for example, that not all the States have responded as fully as requested. Additionally, there are doubts about the extent to which the information received from individual authorities has the imprimatur of State Governments and, even where that might be the case, what meaning can be attached to it in advance, in some cases years in advance, of relevant State Budgetary and Loan Council processes. I believe that publication of the schedule would give any estimates therein a degree of credibility and prominence they could not possibly warrant (and should not be assisted in attaining).

Of even more concern, however, are the potential difficulties which I see publication creating for the Commonwealth in its dealings with the States in the area of infrastructure financing at the forthcoming meetings of the Loan Council in May and June, and beyond. Although Cabinet has not yet completed its consideration of this matter, it is my expectation that the Commonwealth will be seeking at the forthcoming Loan Council meetings a significant re-scheduling of borrowings under projects already approved. In the longer term the pressures building up in the economy-as evidenced most recently by the December quarter National Accounts, released last week-in part as a result of resource developments, underline the point that keeping the infrastructure program within reasonable bounds will be a continuing requirement. I need hardly say that the publication in the next couple of weeks of a schedule of the sort proposed would be anything but helpful from that standpoint. I gather that investment totalling $20.8 billion has found its way into the ''committed'' and ''final feasibility'' categories. In my view, publication of figures of this sort, whatever caveats might be put on them, would be quickly promulgated as a ''benchmark'' of the infrastructure ''task'' facing the States over the next few years.

Your officers have, I believe, also pointed to a demand by private developers for such estimates as a further reason for publication. Frankly, I find it difficult, in view of the nature of the estimates and the various alternatives available (e.g. the Jackson and Associates survey of construction activity already conducted on a consultancy basis for the Department of Housing and Construction) to attach any weight whatsoever to that argument. Indeed, I would have thought that, notwithstanding the fact that there will always be businessmen eager to have the Government do market research for them at the taxpayers' expense, the added information burden on the States and relevant private developers runs quite counter to what the Government has been trying to achieve in the Review of Commonwealth Functions. This is quite apart from the question of what possible value to private developers there could be in estimates which quite clearly, under the pressure of economic events, are not going to be realized. Better, I should have thought, to have no estimates at all than to have such misleading ones as, under those circumstances, these will certainly prove to be.

I also put it to you, in all frankness, that it seems more than a little ironic that the Department of the Chairman of the Functions Review Committee should be seeking a new role for itself as the collator of information on projected public sector infrastructure expenditures, particularly when relevant information is already available to the Commonwealth through normal Loan Council processes and at a time when the capacity of the Bureau of Statistics to undertake collections in this kind of area is being so tightly circumscribed. There is a strong smell of ''making work'' about it which seems even less attractive in these times than it would in any case.

For those various reasons, therefore, I would ask that you consider carefully whether the proposed publication should proceed. As you will gather from the foregoing my own strong view is that it should not.
I should say that we have mentioned this matter to the Treasurer, who has reacted very strongly to the same effect.
I should also mention that I am forwarding a copy of this letter to the Chairman of the Public Service Board for his information.
Yours sincerely J. O. Stone Secretary to the Treasury

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take the opportunity of looking at the answer that I gave to the honourable gentleman. I have not looked at that answer since I gave it. I will accept that the honourable gentleman correctly recalls to the House what I remarked at the time. It is true that, as a consequence of the correspondence that he refers to between Mr Stone and Mr Currie, there was a difference of opinion between the departments regarding publication of those figures. The question of whether what Mr Stone said in the letter and therefore the views of the Department of the Treasury on the publication of those figures represents an attempt to suppress the release of information is, of course, a question of how one interprets those remarks.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not accept that, every time a department head or a Minister argues that there are reasons why particular information ought not to be made available and that there are disadvantages in that information being made available, that necessarily represents suppression of figures. The response of some members of the Opposition and others in the community to the figures that have been put out repeatedly by this Government regarding resource development has been more to the effect that we have been too anxious to provide the figures. In that context , whatever might be said about revisions of expectations in the resource development area that have occurred in recent months, the fact is that the levels of business fixed investment in Australia are likely this financial year to achieve the target of a 10 per cent to 15 per cent rise in real terms. The level of business investment in Australia now is treble what it was in 1977-78, and if the honourable gentleman will be a little patient there will be a bit more news later today which will give some fairly dramatic evidence of the continuing success of this Government's economic policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Primary Industry aware of an allegation by a State Labor back bencher that New Zealand shark is being imported into Tasmania and then exported to Australian markets with the utilisation of freight equalisation? Secondly, is the Minister aware that table fish is being imported by air freight into Tasmania from New Zealand because there is a shortfall of Tasmanian fish in Tasmania? What is the reason for this scandalous affair? Thirdly, is the Minister aware--
—Order! The honourable gentleman is not entitled to make statements of that kind in asking his question, and he should now proceed to ask for information and cease giving it.
—Is the Minister aware that Tasmanian shark fishermen are unable to sell their shark in Australia as a result of cheap New Zealand-Russian imports?
—Do you have a hammer and sickle on your garage door?
—There is a Russian consortium. Fourthly, are there any quotas on fish, particularly shark, being imported from New Zealand to Australia?
—Is Tasmania part of Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I always thought so; I was taught that at school. As far as I know there has been no change in the situation in the intervening years. Let me deal seriatim with the several questions asked by the honourable member. It would not be possible for fish to come from New Zealand to Tasmania and get the benefit of freight equalisation to get it across the little piece of water between us unless the fish passed through a further manufacturing process. If the honourable member is aware of fish being freighted to Tasmania and gaining the benefit of freight equalisation I ask for further evidence so that action can be taken.

ANSWER.PARA: I am not aware of fish being flown into New Zealand by air. I will have that matter checked. I am aware, though, that there has been a great increase in the value of fish that has come from New Zealand over the past three years. In 1978- 79 $9.2m worth of fish was imported. The amount went up to $14.9m worth of fish the next year and to $19.6m worth in 1980-81. This is a very big increase in the value and volume of fish from New Zealand. Part of this volume of fish is exported by a consortium-as the honourable member mentioned, a Russian-New Zealand consortium- that has been fishing off New Zealand. In the early days that consortium exported a high volume of fish called orange roughy.
Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —That is its name. I am not going to debate the issue-it is called orange roughy. We took up with New Zealand the question of whether this fish was being landed at an appropriate price or was in fact being dumped. Some sort of voluntary restraint was entered into. At the same time a great deal of shark was being caught off New Zealand and was being put in refrigerated store. I understand that in recent days that product has been released from store and has been sent across to the Australian market.

ANSWER.PARA: At the same time there has been a very big increase in the Australian catch-an 87 per cent increase-over the last year. All of this has combined to lead to a decline of some 20 per cent in the price on the Australian market from January to March, and the price is still falling. I will look further at the questions raised by the honourable member and see whether I can give him any further information. I do not believe there is a case for dumping in the price paid for the fish from New Zealand, but I will look at the total impact on the Australian industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, may I add to an answer I gave to the honourable member for Perth?
—The Minister may proceed.

—In the answer I gave to a question on child slave labour in Thailand asked by the honourable member for Perth I indicated that we would investigate reports and, if it appeared necessary, we would make representations. I think it could be inferred from that reply that the Thai Government was unaware of the practices to which the honourable gentleman referred. I have now been informed that the Thai Government is aware of violations of the child labour law in Thailand which prohibits the employment of children under 15 years of age and that the Thai Government itself has undertaken a program to publicise the issue. So that, far from there being a need to make representations to the Thai Government on this question, that Government itself has taken steps to deal with violations of Thai law.

—I would like to raise with you, Mr Speaker, a matter that I have raised on many occasions before-the sitting hours of this House. Now that the Senate has shown a degree of sanity which we perhaps would have found difficult to believe some time ago I wonder whether you, Mr Speaker, will take some initiative to raise this matter with the Government and with the Opposition . Past attempts to resolve the matter have been very unsatisfactory. I will not go into that question, but I think my discussions with members of parliament on both sides of the House indicate that there is a great move for change and a great desire to adopt similar hours to those now adopted by the Senate. I wonder whether you, Mr Speaker, will take that initiative in the next few days so that adequate discussions can be held and perhaps the question of new sitting hours can be resolved before the House resumes for its Budget sittings in August.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-When the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) announced on Monday, 19 April, that he had accepted the resignations of the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) and the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) as Ministers in his Government, in the course of his statement he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Relevant papers will be available to be tabled.

The Leader of the House (Mr Sinclair) tabled a series of documents on Tuesday, 20 April. Yesterday at Question Time the Prime Minister, in answer to the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown), said:

The head of the Department had been asked to provide all files that were relevant to this subject; all files that related to it. That question, as I understand it, was asked more than once. Checks were made in New South Wales because the documents that have been tabled, as I am advised, mostly come from files held in New South Wales rather than head office. Subject to what the Minister may say, it is also my understanding that the files were sent to Canberra so that there could be a double check through head office as to whether there are any additional pieces of paper relevant to the issue. On the advice that has been given to me, all pieces of paper that are relevant to this issue have been tabled in the Parliament.
That is what the Prime Minister said yesterday at Question Time. I was quoting then from the Prime Minister's greens, not having seen the final Hansard.

I so indicated to the Prime Minister, on the basis of written advice given to me by the Secretary of my Department, that all documents associated with the importation of a colour television set by the honourable member for Warringah ( Mr MacKellar) are contained in the booklet tabled in the House on 20 April, entitled 'Documents relating to the importation of a colour television set by the Honourable M. J. R. MacKellar, M.P.', and dated 20 April 1982 and the associated explanatory memorandum. I have now to tell the House that during the dinner break last night the permanent head of my Department gave me a further document which I wish to table, and will shortly. This is a minute paper dated 4 February 1982 and signed by Mr R. E. Kennedy, Director, Internal Affairs Unit. That document, on its face, does not expressly refer to the issue. It does, however, refer to matters described as 'of vital concern to the departmental administration'.

In my view, this document is relevant and my duty to the House is to table it. The reason the document is relevant is that, upon inquiries having been made of Mr Kennedy, it has been brought to my notice that one of the matters referred to was the matter of a television set brought into Australia by the honourable member for Warringah without payment of duty. I have discussed with the Prime Minister my proposed tabling of this document, and he is likewise of the view that the document should be tabled. It has, of course, always been the Government's position that all relevant documents with respect to this matter should be tabled. I realise that the tabling of this document, like the tabling of the other documents, refers to individuals. However, the paramount duty is of course to this House, and I am obliged to table the document. I table that document.

In the circumstances I have issued a further instruction to the permanent head of my Department that further searches should be made to ensure that all relevant documents are made available and, of course, subsequently tabled. The Government is determined that all relevant documents will be tabled. Should any further relevant documents be discovered, they will of course be tabled. I should add that I have invited the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown) to examine the files to see the originals of the documents and that invitation is still open to him. I discussed with the honourable member for Parramatta certain covering letters which enclosed the papers which were subsequently tabled the other day. Although they do not, of course, take the matter anywhere with respect to substantive issues, nevertheless on a very wide interpretation of relevancy covering letters enclosing papers may be construed by some people as being relevant. Although I have already discussed these with the honourable member for Parramatta and I know that he is not concerned about them, nevertheless I wish, as an abundance of caution, likewise to table those accompanying papers.

To take the matter even further, one of those accompanying letters was in a different file, and it-the accompanying letter-had itself a notation on it. I think, again as an abundance of caution-although in my view the matter is not taken any further by such a statement-I should table that document, which I have also shown to the honourable member for Parramatta. There is a notation on the bottom of it, and it is for that reason that it might be construed as an additional document, even though a copy of the principal document is already tabled. I table that document.

As I have already said, the Government's concern, above all, is to table all relevant documents. I have indicated to the honourable member for Parramatta that he is at liberty to look at the originals of the files. There are obviously things such as newspaper cuttings but I wish to give an assurance to you, Mr Speaker, to the honourable member from the Opposition who is responsible for the handling of this matter, and to the House that it is my conviction and belief that I have now tabled, in the exercise of my duty, all papers relevant to this matter.
Motion (by Mr Sinclair)-by leave-agreed to:

That this House, in accordance with the provisions of the Parliamentary Papers Act 1908, authorises the publication of the minute dated 4 February 1982 from the Director, Internal Affairs Unit, together with the associated papers presented earlier this day by the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave -The tabling of this document is another step along the tortuous road that started last October when the then Minister for Health brought a colour television set into Australia. It seems to us to be a travesty of the parliamentary system that it has taken so long for another document to be found. At the start this was a very straightforward problem. Did the Minister bring in a television set? Was it a colour set? Did he make a false declaration? Was duty paid? If not, why not? Did, in fact, the then Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs know that the television set was a colour set? Perhaps it was an honest mistake and perhaps early along the line the whole thing could have been solved very simply. But then it made the Press. Since then we have seen the Government thrashing about, searching for a credible story, a story acceptable to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) with his oft repeated statements about a high sense of ministerial propriety. We saw the odd spectacle of Ministers locked up for 24 hours, trying to concoct an acceptable statement. There were multiple statements and excessive shreddings. It was real cloak and dagger stuff. Yesterday in the House I asked the Prime Minister whether all the documents had been tabled. the Prime Minister is reported as having said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the head of the department had been asked to provide all relevant files. 'That request was made more than once, and I understand the files were all sent to Canberra so that there could be a double check with head office to see if there were any additional pieces of paper that were relevant to the issue'.

That was his answer. Yesterday, in the Senate, Senator Grimes asked a question about a report he knew of that had been prepared by Mr Kennedy, the head of the Internal Affairs Bureau, which concerned an interview that he had had with Mr Bennett, the New South Wales President of the Customs Officers Association. So last night, I believe after some searching into the deep, dark recesses of the Department's files, the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) suggested to me that he had a paper which he wanted to table. Having looked at it, one could not possibly call it a document; I think a piece of paper is a better term. The Opposition objected to the tabling of this document. We did not think it fulfilled any reasonable purpose, so it was withdrawn. Then, later in the night, the Minister came in and said he intended to table it anyhow but unfortunately it was after 11 o'clock and it could not be tabled. That probably says something more about the inefficiency of this Government. Eventually, this morning, we have this document. The document tabled today achieves exactly what the Opposition feared right from the beginning of the MacKellar affair. It is a cheap attempt to discredit two officers working with the Bureau of Customs-Mr Peter Bennett, the New South Wales President of the Customs Officers Association, who is also a preventive officer in the Bureau, and Mr Robert Spanswick, the national secretary of the same organisation.

It has never been accepted that one can ignore revelations or allegations made by individuals simply on the basis of attempting to discredit them personally. That is not accepted in the law. It should not be accepted in the parliamentary sphere. The only test should be: Are the allegations being made by an individual true? Also, the motives for making those allegations are only partly relevant-to the extent that those motives make it unlikely that the individual is telling the truth. The allegations made by Bennett and Spanswick were true. It has now been shown by the resignations of the Ministers that they were. Any attempt now to discredit them is a shonky exercise and totally irrelevant.

Yesterday evidence was produced in the House-it has not been denied-that another officer named Mayhew had been questioned, interrogated and intimidated on three occasions by senior departmental officers trying to shake his belief that the television set which was carried in by Mr MacKellar was in fact a colour television set. He was repeatedly interrogated and attempts made to make him believe that it was a black and white television set because that was the official view of the department. He stuck to the truth. He stuck to what he believed to be the truth. Surely that is an example of the nazi or communist technique of brainwashing people, of re-educating them to believe that something is not what they really do believe. That sort of procedure has brought no credit at all on the department or the Bureau of Customs. The document produced today has no relationship whatever to the MacKellar affair. It refers to an investigation which began on 1 October of last year, nearly a week before Mr MacKellar returned to Australia. However, the document does indicate that internal departmental inquiries were already going on against the two officers from the Customs Officers Association. The document also shows the existence of a number of 'reports'. Specifically, in paragraph 1 of the letter, Mr Kennedy says:
The Acting Secretary requested that I prepare for him a report of the interview with Bennett.
Where is that report? The last paragraph reads:
I propose to discuss with Mr Kelly-
Mr Kelly is the New South Wales Collector of Customs-
certain other matters . . .

Where are the records of those discussions? The first paragraph of the document that we have this morning refers to matters of vital concern to the departmental administration. The document that we have had tabled today is not a report on the investigation, or interrogation, at all. It is a report on the people who are being interviewed. It reveals more about the author than it does about the people being interviewed. The document that has been tabled by the Minister is most significant because it reveals how the internal affairs unit deals with anyone whom it regards as recalcitrant. Two honest officers who are critical of the operation are referred to as follows:
Bennett raised a number of issues principally in respect to departmental administration. . . . We did take the opportunity to 'bleed' him of his thinking and aspersions.
Now what are we to read into that quotation? I repeat:
We did take the opportunity to 'bleed' him of his thinking and aspersions.
Does that language not clearly indicate that an attempt was made to convince him that what he was saying was wrong? Mr Kennedy continues:
It can be accepted that Bennett regards the Minister as being dishonest.

I guess that is for the nation to decide. The fact that Mr Bennett is still the New South Wales President of the Customs Officers Association, that he is still a working officer within the Customs Bureau and that the two Ministers are now on the back benches might lead one to believe that what he was saying was correct. Mr Bennett is then described as being 'most critical of senior administrative officers and their administrative ability'. Surely no one will cavil about that. From what we have found out about this department and the Customs Bureau in the last week or so surely no one will cavil about his view that he had grave fears about their administrative ability. The report goes on:
Together with his confederate Robert Spanswick he is currently before the Stewart Royal Commission.

Let us look at the little phrase, 'his confederate Robert Spanswick'. Surely that is an emotive description of a man who is honestly trying to do his job. Surely the term 'his confederate' is applied to criminals. Is it normally applied to a colleague working alongside him? Should we use the word ' confederate'? Surely that gives us another insight into the sort of document this is. The report states: 'he is currently before the Stewart Royal Commission '. Surely this report from Kennedy was dedicated to discrediting Bennett and Spanswick because they were about to give evidence before the Stewart Royal Commission on the maladministration of the Bureau of Customs.

The point is that this document sheds no light at all on the MacKellar affair. It does indicate, however, a cheap attempt by the Government, an attempt by the Prime Minister-with whom I understand the tabling of this document has been discussed-to discredit two honest officers, two officers who were proven right by the Prime Minister himself when he dismissed the Ministers.

Yesterday I asked the Prime Minister whether any additional documents on the MacKellar affair should be tabled. I think we will eventually get around to calling this the Telegate affair, Mr Speaker. The Prime Minister said that all documents had been tabled already. However, I understand that there is a number of additional documents. Specifically, there is at least one more document prepared by Mr Kennedy regarding the MacKellar affair; that is, the document Senator Grimes asked about in the Senate yesterday. The Opposition would certainly like to see that document. Is this the start of a new process-the document-a-day-trick? How long is it going to take us to have all of the documents that are relevant to this case tabled in this Parliament?

TALK.START.PARA: —You object when we put one in. What's wrong with you?

—The Minister says we object because a document was produced. I have clearly outlined that this document merely refers to the people who were interviewed. It is no record of interview. Mr Kennedy is a policeman. He may not be called that in the Department but he is a policeman. He is a former inspector of the Commonwealth police. Any person in Australia knows that any policeman interrogating a person or investigating a matter keeps notes in a diary. Where are the diary notes of the interview? All this document is is Kennedy's opinion of the people he was interviewing. It has no relevance at all. How long will this take? Must we go through a turgid, lingering process of recrimination and repetition before we elicit the tabling of all the documents? We want the lot- the records of interview, the police notes, the whole range of documents relevant to this investigation.

SPEECH.PARA: Surely the new Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs must have misgivings about the Department which he is now administering. There is surely evidence of a cover-up. Mr MacKellar claims in all honesty that he offered to pay the duty. Did Mr Moore know that the television set was a colour television set? If he did , why was the duty not paid? This Department is a major revenue collecting department of this Government. Apart from the Australian Taxation Office, it probably collects more than any other agency-somewhere in the vicinity of $7, 000m a year. The Opposition has claimed that there is a need for a judicial inquiry into the whole running of the Bureau of Customs. Surely the events of the last few days have underlined the importance of that. Surely they have underlined the responsibility the Opposition has shown in bringing these facts to light.

The events of the last few days have really shown how incredibly incompetent this Government is, how incredibly bereft of morality it is. This is a government which is bent on cover-ups. We have a Prime Minister whose credibility is shot to pieces-the first Prime Minister in history who has merited a headline in a newspaper reading: 'Lies, lies, lies'. Kids in playgrounds now when telling lies talk about 'doing a Fraser'. What sort of a leader have we got? What sort of leadership has this country got? It is evident in the maladministration of a major department. The Prime Minister recently spent a good deal of taxpayers' money trying to justify himself in the electorate of Lowe by putting around a letter saying that it was not true. Nobody believed him.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable gentleman should remain relevant. Leave was granted on one basis. He should not transgress beyond that.

—Let me finish on this point, Mr Speaker. The document that has been tabled in this House today, because we have demanded the presence of more documents, is in no way conclusive. All it is is an attempt to discredit two people who have been proved by recent events to be honest. We object to the tabling of this document. We object to the fact that these two honest people are now being pilloried in public, pilloried in that Department. We demand that all the documents relevant to this case, all the documents that are hidden away in that Department, be tabled immediately so that people can make a judgment about that Department, about this affair. We repeat that this incident merely reinforces our desire to have a judicial inquiry with all the powers of a royal commission which will enable people to come forward, give their evidence honestly and reveal the truth of this affair. The Opposition is far from finished with this telegate affair. The Government can expect to hear a lot more from us. We expect all the documents to be tabled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: EMPLOYMENT AND YOUTH AFFAIRS; CONSUMER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr N.A. BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable gentleman claim to have been misrepresented?

—Yes, in two respects. The first is that the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown) said that there was an intention to discredit certain persons, whom he named, by means of tabling this document. There is no intention to discredit anyone. The document was tabled consistent with my obligations to this House. It is my duty to table documents which are relevant to the issues we are canvassing.

SPEECH.PARA: The second matter is that a suggestion was made by the honourable member for Parramatta which disturbed me somewhat. It was to the effect that the fact that the document was not tabled last night was due to the Government and myself as representing the Government. That is not the case. We were ready, willing and able last night to table the document which is relevant to this matter. An attempt was made by the Opposition-not by the honourable member for Parramatta- to nobble me in the best traditions of the Sydney Australian Labor Party to prevent me from tabling this relevant document.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you mean by that?

—There was an attempt to nobble me by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen). The Opposition takes the view that it wants tabled all documents which are relevant, except those that it does not think are relevant and those that it believes are embarrassing or for some other internal reason does not want to be tabled. The honourable member for Parramatta knows that that is true.
—The Minister is now going beyond the bounds of a personal explanation.

—Several other honourable members know that that is true. We would have been able to table this document last night. The Opposition, having called through the honourable member for Parramatta for all relevant documents to be tabled, then said, after the honourable member for Parramatta agreed with me that it was relevant: 'No, please do not table this document'. I will not be a party to that because I have obligations to this House, as does the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), to table all relevant documents. That is what we will do. We will not be nobbled by the Labor Party and prevented from doing so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I claim to have been obviously misrepresented.
—Does the honourable member wish to make a personal explanation?
—Yes.
—He may proceed.

—The word 'nobble' is a racecourse expression which means an attempt to prevent somebody from doing his best. Last night I happened to be sitting alongside my colleague the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown) when this document was shown to him. I said: 'I think it is outrageous to table a document that will malign two officers and has nothing to do with the MacKellar affair whatsoever'. The document maligns them in the terms that they are deemed to be not normal people but people who are apparently interested in their own self-aggrandisement. The document refers particularly to the evidence which they have given before the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking. What would the royal commissioner think of these people if he read about this assessment which was made of them by a police officer without any supplementary evidence as to what took place? As my colleague, the honourable member for Parramatta, has said, everything that was complained about in respect of the MacKellar affair was true. But giving a virtual paramedical assessment of their capacity, or adulation of each other, or that of anybody else to give evidence before a royal commission whose inquiry is still part-heard does not help the normal conduct of justice. If a statement were tabled here regarding witnesses before a royal commission, you yourself, Mr Speaker, would be very guarded about whether it was proper to comment on the propriety, ability or otherwise of a witness. That is what this document does.

SPEECH.PARA: I said to the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr N.A. Brown): 'I don't care whether you table the statement or not, but it is not right to do it' . He said: 'Well, I will go and ask the Prime Minister'. He then went down the corridor, asked the Prime Minister, came back and said: 'Well, I am going to table it'. I said: 'Well, table it. It is your responsibility'. He was not nobbled. He did not know what to do from the point of view of propriety. That is the most important thing. He had to run down the corridor to ask the Prime Minister what to do and he told him to table the document. I do not excuse him for it. He could not do it because of the lateness of time. That was his problem . But his problem of lateness of time was caused by his having to consult again with the Prime Minister. He could always have tabled the document. I would not have objected.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable gentleman is going beyond the bounds of a personal explanation.

—I never objected in parliamentary terms to the tabling of the document. I objected in terms of normal propriety, to protect people, and particularly witnesses who have given evidence before a royal commission that is still hearing evidence. I still adhere to that.
—You were not too worried about that in another investigation.

—Let us talk about the facts today. In very simple terms there was no attempt to nobble. That is a ridiculous expression. Any nobbling would have to take place in the forms of this House. The Minister is in charge of the business of the House and he knows what he can do. He did not do it because he had to go to obtain further instructions. He has a conscience about the matter and he is trying to erase it with a word that was never used.
—The honourable member is now going beyond the bounds of a personal explanation.

—As my part in this whole deal has been painted by the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr N.A. Brown) let me put the facts as I know them. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) recognises that rapid and uncontrolled export oriented resource development is creating major regional dislocations throughout Australia and in particular-
(a) is contributing to the economic decline of regions traditionally dependent on diverse manufacturing industries, and

(b) has led to a severe imbalance in the development of growing regions whereby public funds are channelled into the provision of physical infrastructure for projects of large corporations while community needs are neglected, and
(2) calls on the Government to-
(a) develop and implement policies for balanced development which take into account the different needs of each of Australia's regions;
(b) support regional authorities and assist them to create employment and enter into partnership arrangements with private enterprise to attract new economic activity to their regions, and
(c) promote planning of public investments and co-ordination of government services on a regional basis through the co-operation of Federal, State and local government.

This motion draws attention to the need for integrated policies for balanced national development which take account of the different needs of each of Australia's regions. It is the kind of motion that one would expect to be supported on both sides of the House. However, in respect of this Government it really is a motion of condemnation on two basic counts. For the first time in Australia's history we have a Federal Government that has no regional development policies. Federal funds for urban and regional development programs have been cut by 90 per cent under this Government. The small allocations in the 1981-82 Budget were made for the winding up of former programs. The growth centre program is now defunct. In April 1981 the Government terminated the Decentralisation Assistance Program and abolished the Decentralisation Advisory Board. At the same time that this Government has been dismantling former regional development programs it has been pursuing policies which are having a dislocating effect on the lives of many people and a disruptive effect on the viability of regional economies. This Government has failed to bring any co- ordination to the process of industrial restructuring that has been occurring over the past six years.

When this motion was placed on the Notice Paper the Government was in the business of talking up the expectation of a resource boom. Now it is attempting to talk down the prospect of economic growth, to dampen the legitimate expectations of the people for expansionary policies, relief from hardship, reduction of unemployment and decent social services in this country. We in the Opposition were always dubious about the Government's inflated expectations of a resource boom. We saw a large and rapid investment in a few sectors and in a few regions taking shape within an economy that was deliberately held stagnant to support those regions. We expressed concern about the structural impact of that investment in the context of the Government's over-tight monetary policy.

It is becoming clear that the expected boom in resource investment and the subsequent surge in resource exports will not occur at the high levels claimed previously by this Government, particularly at election time. A substantial number of projects have been cancelled, deferred or reduced in scale, and many more still remain in doubt. The fall-off in the expected level of investment and the current problems on Australia's trade balance illustrate one of the dangers we referred to at the time-the vulnerability of an economy heavily dependent on primary product exports and fluctuations in international demands. This points to the validity of Labor's proposed alternative development strategy which includes national co-ordination for the maintenance and strengthening of a viable and diversified manufacturing base. However, we should not now be misled into thinking there are no structural problems to be dealt with in relation to expanded resource sector investments. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard three tables showing expectations of actual capital expenditure in the private and public sector.
Leave granted.
