TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House.
—I take a point of order. The honourable member's motion speaks about rapid growth. I take it that the tables tend to show something else. Is that right?

—The Leader of the House (Mr Sinclair) saw the tables and agreed that leave should be given for their incorporation. The tradition of this House is that documents which are not unparliamentary can be incorporated. The honourable member knows that this is the case. The tables show that substantial investments have already been made. A large proportion of the recent increase in imports reflects this investment. Public funds have been locked into providing the physical infrastructure for the expected private investment. This has happened in every State. The honourable member knows the situation in New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of this Government's policies, local and semi-government authorities have had to pay record interest rates. At present the rate is between 15.5 per cent and 15.7 per cent, and it will rise pretty soon to in excess of 16 per cent . Most of the money has been going into this sector and as a result the little people who want to buy a house have been forced out of the money market. That is really what has been happening under this Government. It has happened even though the resources boom has been cut off. We have not had the expansion that has been forecast particularly at election time by this Government. But the public sector has been locked into its commitment to provide infrastructure. As a result housing and other facets of urban living in this country have been placed in a disastrous position.

The point is that there is rapid expansion in a few regions such as the Hunter Valley in New South Wales, the Latrobe Valley in Victoria, Gladstone in Queensland and the north west region of Western Australia. At the same time States such as Tasmania and South Australia and provincial centres such as Ballarat, Geelong and Bendigo in Victoria are experiencing an agonising decline. My colleague the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren), who will also speak in this debate, will talk about the personal problems that are in fact affecting a provincial area such as Ballarat. The expanding regions lack basic social amenities and services. There has not been proper planning to cope with the needs of the additional population for decent housing, health, education and welfare services. There has been no planning to diversify the economies of those regions to ensure employment opportunities for women and for youth. There has been no planning to prevent a drain of skilled tradesmen and professional workers out of established industrial and administrative sectors. There has been no planning to ensure a longer term viability of those regions. At the same time , there has been no planning to regenerate the declining regions.

Australia's economic structure is undergoing far reaching changes as the post- war industrial development strategy of import replacement is being abandoned in favour of export expansion. Concentration of ownership in our agricultural and pastoral industries, increasing import penetration, technological changes and cut backs in public sector activities are combining to reduce employment growth and to erode the viability of some important established regions. Again, my colleague will deal particularly with the region of Ballarat in Victoria. We could also talk about other regions that are affected so badly. In the face of these challenges this Government is not prepared to do anything to prevent the fragmentation and alienation that results.

Let us consider some of the initiatives that could be taken to promote a more balanced national development, to strengthen the economies of the threatened regions and to diversify the economies of expanding regions. First, we need a Federal government that will work co-operatively with State, Territory and local governments. By that I mean that public servants in the national government should go out and co-operate with officers at a State and local government level . There needs to be a basis of trust between those three levels of government and an understanding with the private sector. From personal experience I know that public servants who were with the former Department of Urban and Regional Development went out and built up a basis of trust. This spirit of co-operation has to be developed. There has to be an understanding and faith between people working at the grass roots level if we are to develop these regions.

Secondly, we need a national public inquiry into the problems and possibilities of established provincial cities and country towns. Thirdly, we need to establish a regional development task force to liaise with State and Territory authorities. The task force should investigate the forms of support that could be given to existing regional organisations and, where appropriate, to promote the growth of local and regional development boards. Such boards would need to work in close co-operation with local authorities, business, union and community groups. Regional development programs cannot work if the people in the region are not committed to the proposals and actively involved in shaping the proposals. The boards could undertake a number of initiatives such as research and feasibility studies. They could acquire and develop land for industrial and commercial uses. They could invest in new economic enterprises or operate businesses on their own account. We have to recognise that the problems which are not of local origin cannot be solved by local response alone.

There is a need for an integration of the policy initiatives of the Federal and State governments to build on the initiatives of the local people. In other words, there has to be co-operation, a spirit of working together, trust and understanding between the levels of government. We need a national plan for industrial regeneration which will provide our various regions with a vision for renewal. So a fourth initiative would be to change the charter of the Industries Assistance Commission to identify the kinds of industries we could establish in different locations and the kinds of support those industries would require to be established on a viable footing. If we had now the imagination and vision of the Coombs leadership on post-war reconstruction in Australia we would be in a healthier situation and more able to help people in regional areas.

We need to use our powers over foreign investment to achieve a higher degree of technological transfer, industrial research and development, and training programs suitable for decentralised locations. We need to promote downstream processing and fabrication of our natural resources in new locations. We need to support research and development of viable small and medium scale energy industries, such as solar power generation. We need to support the viable co- operative processing of farm produce. We need to encourage the production of crop fuels and to undertake projects to conserve the natural resources of water, soil and forests. We need to upgrade and expand community amenities and services which have an influence on decisions concerning the location of projects requiring investment, which are themselves employment generating and which improve social and cultural opportunities.

A fifth initiative would be to encourage the decentralisation of Australian and State government services and employment to major rural cities. Of course, the Labor Government set up a committee to examine that. From its investigations it found that at least 18,000 too many Commonwealth public servants were located in the central business district of Melbourne. It was feasible for regional and provincial centres such as Geelong, Ballarat and Bendigo to absorb some of the 18,000 Commonwealth public servants. That was a rational proposition. It still is a rational, sane proposition. It would give stimulus to those areas. My sixth point is that we need to encourage decentralisation to major rural cities where natural growth occurs. The Albury-Wodonga and Bathurst-Orange growth centres began to take shape under the Labor Government to 1972 to 1975. This could be applied to other areas. For instance, the Minister for Science and Technology ( Mr Thomson), who is sitting at the table, represents an area in northern Queensland. There should be a stimulus to areas such as Cairns and Townsville in Queensland; Geelong, Bendigo and Ballarat in Victoria; and Wagga, Dubbo or Coffs Harbour in New South Wales. These areas really need support. They have been neglected by this Government and no moves have been made towards planning the development of other centres. My seventh point is that we need to ensure that adequate social amenities and services are provided in selected areas of natural resource development. Negotiations should be held with the Northern Territory and the States to see that the costs of provision are fairly shared between the developers and the public authorities. As a guideline for those negotiations the view of the Federal Treasury, as expressed in its submission to the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, should be considered. The Treasury had this to say:

Industrial infrastructure in remote areas provided wholly by developers, where industrial infrastructure forms part of a State system, as is the case with much of the prospective investment in the aluminium industry, this should not prevent funding of the full cost by developers, through capital contributions, appropriate user charges or a combination of both.

Developers in remote areas should also contribute to the cost of social infrastructure to reflect the benefits they derive, the higher costs of providing facilities in such areas and the additional risks involved for government in doing so. Where significant expansions of existing social infrastructure are required, for example, at Gladstone and in the Hunter Valley, there are also strong grounds for requiring some capital contributions from developers.

I conclude my remarks on this point: That statement by the Federal Treasury to the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources indicates what it believes should be the developers' contribution. If one were to visit an area such as Gladstone one would see what is the social infrastructure of that city. It is a disgrace to this Parliament, the Queensland Government and local government authorities that people in that area have to live under such terrible conditions . What has occurred? The only Government that tried to do something about the social infrastructure was the Labor Government of 1972 to 1975. It included Gladstone in an area improvement program in order to try to improve the social conditions of people living in that area. The intention of the Government, under its new expansion program, is that most of the industries will be located at Boyne Island, which is south-east of Gladstone. The prevailing winds in that area come from the south-east. All the smog created by industry will flow across to where people live in Gladstone. It is sad that people are living under such appalling conditions.

The Opposition believes that if we are to defend and protect the interests of people the Australian Government, the State governments and local governments, together with business, must co-operate in the development of this nation. I am pleased that I have moved this motion. I hope that the Government takes some notice of the arguments that I have put forward.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion Mr Deputy Speaker. As a member from one of the regional areas, I understand the tremendous concern that the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) has for this matter. It is interesting to note that the motion we are discussing today first appeared on the Notice Paper on 25 November 1980. That was a time when the nation was still giving some credibility to the claims of a number of Ministers opposite that Australia was on the verge of the greatest mineral boom since the middle of the nineteenth century. The whole thrust of economic theory at that stage was supposed to rest on the growth of unprecedented dimensions in mineral exports. According to this Government's propagandists, the structural changes that would be accelerated by the 'boom' would change the employment configuration but would create new and expanding employment opportunities-the millenium was just around the corner. It appears more like Armageddon than the millenium.

SPEECH.PARA: Many honourable members, particularly on this side of the House, are obviously somewhat more perceptive-either that or they are more concerned with honesty. We did not believe the Government's propaganda, which was either a cheap election exercise or the result of very bad advice. On either account, this Government was then and still is ill-equipped to govern this nation. The boom never eventuated and it was never likely to do so. Yet, there are still members of the Government who persist with the economic policies which they perceived to be appropriate at that time. To a large extent, they are absurdities. There is a certain degree of obscenity in them because they do not take into account the effects of those policies upon people who live in this country and who see their livelihoods disappearing. As I said, even at that time many honourable members, particularly on this side of the House, were extremely sceptical of the claims of the Government. We believed that not only would jobs not be created to compensate for those jobs that would be lost but also the livelihoods of many people would be destroyed. This was particularly applicable in those regions of Australia which have long standing diversified manufacturing industries. I represent one such region. The electorate of Ballarat embraces a number of centres that have a long history of reliance upon manufacturing industry, that have now been threatened by the cries of the free traders and the malaise of the Australian economy. The citizens of Ballarat, Maryborough, Kyneton and Daylesford take particular exception to the lack of concern that the Government has shown towards their plight. They are rapidly becoming aware that it is not only lack of concern but also a lack of competence that is causing it.

In each of these areas the local citizens have formed organisations to encourage the development of industry already existing in the towns or cities to provide the facilities through which industrial estates for new industries can be created, in order that new industries can be established in the area. In particular, I refer to Maryborough and Ballarat. Both of these centres are concerned to spend their own funds on imaginative schemes to attract new industry and new business to their areas. In particular, I refer to the efforts of the Ballarat Regional Employment Committee, the Ballarat Development Committee, the Ballarat Industrial Consortium and the Maryborough Development Board. I know these organisations well. I know their genuine concern. They will be aware of that fact. They know that we are carrying their message to this Parliament.

Each of these bodies is representative of a broad cross-section of interests in its centre. They are extremely dedicated to the task of ensuring that in these cities and the region generally the long-established lifestyle of the people living there will be maintained and enhanced. Yet while the Government conducts policies that result in uncertainty and hesitancy in industry, lower morale among all levels, and a continuing deterioration of the employment market, their efforts appear so often to be fruitless. It appals me to think that a region so rich in history, which has contributed so much to Australia, should be threatened by a government which just does not understand its needs.

Apart from a number of contracts with Alcoa of Australia Ltd at Portland, Ballarat has not received the benefits of any growth purported to have occurred in the economy. In fact, the Government's cynical disregard for truth has left businessmen and employees anxious about their future. I am particularly concerned, as the member for Ballarat, because on a regional basis the area that I represent is seriously affected by the state of the economy. In 1976 the percentage of the Ballarat electorate work force engaged in manufacturing industry was 48.4. At the same time, that for Australia was 39.5. We do not have the figures from the latest census, but there is no doubt that the present comparison would be just as dramatic.

In August-September 1981, a reputable study of youth unemployment was undertaken in Ballarat by students of the Ballarat College of Advanced Education , replicating a study undertaken in Melbourne for the Victorian Employment Committee. The population studied was 780 households. The study identified 296 young people in the age group 15 to 24. Eighty-one of these-27.4 per cent-were unemployed. This figure is much higher than the national average. Under a wider definition of unemployment in that age group, which would include those who would like to work full time, or even part time, those who have returned to school because they have failed to find work, those undertaking industrial learning because they are unable to find work, and those who do not have regular paid jobs beyond five hours per week, the figure would come to 37.2 per cent of the 15 to 24-year-olds. As I said, that study was undertaken in August-September 1981. There are no grounds for believing that the situation is any better today.

The region of Ballarat encapsulates many of the problems of regions throughout Australia. To some degree it is a microcosm of those regions. So let us not pretend that we can ignore this reality. Let us not forget that this removes the immediate school leaver element, because we are talking about August-September. A similar study in Melbourne, the one on which this study was based, showed unemployment at 14.3 per cent in February to July 1980. Of course, it would be somewhat higher now. But it points out the fact that in a region such as Ballarat and, I would imagine, in many of the other regions, such as Bendigo and Geelong, the situation would be almost as critical.

An Industries Assistance Commission report, discussion paper No. 3, entitled ' Regional implications of economic change', identified the Central Highlands region as the second most dependent area upon protection for assistance for its manufacturing industry in Australia. The Central Highlands region was second only to Melbourne in the requirement for protection. This is something of which I am particularly conscious, and so are our people in Ballarat. I have not yet encountered any unrealistic businessmen in our region-that is, those who are Luddites or proto-Luddites in disposition, or who do not recognise that gradual change will take place. However, they do recognise that just as someone once said 'There is no such thing as a free lunch', there is also no such thing as free trade.

All major industrialised and trading nations have devices to ensure the maintenance of adequate standards of living for their people. We are being asked by some of our myopic free traders on the Government side to ignore that reality . I will not ignore that reality, and I will not see the people of Ballarat and similar regions having their livelihoods placed in jeopardy. All major industrialised nations attempt to maintain adequate standards of living for their people.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have a better attitude than the honourable member for Bendigo.

—It will not be very long before there is a change in that direction, too. I ask only that the Government recognise this. A study commissioned for the Ballarat Regional Employment Committee, through its Ballarat Expands Today and Tomorrow Committee, undertaken by the Victorian Chamber of Manufactures and published in February 1981, identified the following major disadvantages for manufacturing industry in Ballarat. This is something of which the Government can take notice. They included the high charges for telephone calls, the high charges for freight, and distance factors such as access to service and some suppliers. I was impressed by the comment made by my colleague the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) when he indicated that it would be desirable for some of the Commonwealth Government services to be decentralised. Another disadvantage identified was high fuel costs. These are in the areas of communication and transport.

SPEECH.PARA: We want regions of Australia which are currently suffering seriously in the country's economic malaise to be given priority for industrial development. Australia is one of the few countries of the Organisation for Economic Co- operation and Development which does not have a program for regional economic expansion. Such schemes are strongly supported by governments in Germany, France , the United Kingdom, the United States of America and Canada. Australia has never given more than token support to decentralisation programs. The Australian Labor Party believes in regional economic development for Australia. Such a program would greatly enhance industrial opportunities in provincial centres such as Ballarat and those areas that the honourable member for Reid has mentioned.
