SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKenzie Mr A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to this motion I would like to pick out some of the phrases and words used by the mover, the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren), because I think they highlight the attitude of the Australian Labor Party towards resource development, also its attitude towards the benefits of development. The first part of the motion refers to rapid and uncontrolled export oriented resource development. Notwithstanding that notice of this motion was given on 25 November 1980, I would like in the time available to point out why some of the things expected have not occurred. In particular, I would like to refer to the coal industry and the effect of wage escalations, industrial disputes, strikes and port delays on that developing industry. I will come to that later.

SPEECH.PARA: The motion says that this uncontrolled export oriented resource development is creating major regional dislocations and that it is contributing to the economic decline of regions. All I can say to the honourable member for Reid and to the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren), who seconded the motion, is that it must be some time since they were in the regions where these major resource developments are taking place.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are talking about the decline in Bathurst-Orange, which you represent but don't do much about.

—The honourable member refers to Bathurst-Orange but to my knowledge no major export oriented resource development is taking place in that region. Let us look at some of the new resource development in this country, largely as a result of the policies of this Government and despite the obstructive and delaying tactics of unions and people who are opposed to resource development. For example, what about the Northern Territory? Would the people there agree with the honourable member for Reid? Those people, including Aboriginal land holders, will benefit enormously from the uranium developments happening there. The town of Jabiru is a total new development in the Top End of the Northern Territory. It has had a tremendous spin-off for the city of Darwin as well. My friend the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), who represents the Bowen Basin coal fields, represents one of the most exciting developing areas in Australia. It is experiencing massive increases in population and we see not only existing towns, such as Moranbah and Blackwater, getting bigger but also entirely new infrastructures-in fact, whole new towns and settlements-are being established at Middlemount, German Creek, Dysart and other places that I have visited. That has largely been done at the companies' expense. These towns are providing recreational services, health and hospital services and educational services, including the provision of school facilities. I wonder how this sort of motion would be accepted in the Bowen Basin coal fields of Queensland. Look at the north west of Western Australia, the Pilbara region, the areas associated with the North West Shelf development and the new towns of Karratha, Tom Price and Paraburdoo, as well as the massive developments at Port Hedland.

SPEECH.PARA: The motion says that rapid resource development is contributing to the economic decline of the regions. How well would that be accepted in those areas? Perhaps the honourable member for Reid is referring to those areas where there is already major industry. He refers to manufacturing industry in his motion. I will very happily come back to the more populated areas where resource developments are taking place. I have one in my own electorate; namely, the area between Lithgow, Wallerawang and Portland. My friend representing the Hunter Valley, the honourable member for Paterson (Mr O'Keefe), will support me when I say that there are some mammoth developments going on in the Hunter Valley, all to the long term advantage of the residents of that area. They may have some difficulties in the short term, and certainly I recognise those. Let us look at some of those difficulties. When we have a number of resource development projects proceeding rapidly we certainly get some pressure on infrastructure and we certainly get some pressure on wages. Existing businesses have difficulty retaining skilled tradesmen. They move off to the mines in droves, naturally enough; the wages are higher within the mining industry. That causes some temporary dislocation within the area. There is some competition for clerical staff. Local councils have difficulty providing the infrastructure expected. For example, I know that in my own area the Small Arms Factory in Lithgow has great difficulty holding many of its skilled tradesmen because they can go off and earn two or three times as much in the mines. But that is a short term phenomenon, an adjustment that has to be made. Nobody would say that because of that these developments should not take place.

I refer honourable members to figures which I find staggering. The average spending capacity increase as a result of the coal mining industry in the Hunter Valley is about $7m; that is, the extra contribution in consumer spending capacity that has come to the valley. In 10 years' time that will move to about $180m. Some extra 9,000 people will be employed in the lower Hunter alone. Some 30 new mines will be developed. Each mine in Queensland costs about $500m. Perhaps the mines in the Hunter Valley will cost less than that, nevertheless the mines will provide tremendously increasing opportunities, particularly for young people. The average age of people employed directly in the coal mining industry is only 28.3 years. Where else in regional economies and in regional centres could young people get those sorts of opportunities?

I talked to a young man driving a continuous miner last year. He is 22 years of age and earning $700 a week. I do not deny him the right to earn $700 a week; he is working long hours under difficult conditions. I hope the industry can afford to pay that sort of money. Where else can young people have that sort of opportunity? During inspections at Paraburdoo by the Government's resources committee I talked to a couple of unemployed school teachers. They were girls who could not get jobs in Perth but who had the initiative to go up to the Pilbara mines. They asked why they could not drive the big dump trucks and eventually they were given a go. They are now employed as permanent staff, on $ 600 a week. What about the other wages that we see? They are flowing on. Even down the line, some clerical staff can be getting towards $20,000 for what is not much more than a typist's job. One of the problems of the resource industry is that these wage expectations are causing quite a lot of trouble in industrial disputation. My point is that all this benefit flows on to the regional communities.

We have recently seen in Singleton magnificent new housing estates. With due respect to my friend the honourable member for Paterson, there is no way in the world that Singleton would otherwise have been much more than a rural backwater for years and years to come. Now we see it as one of the most rapidly growing and developing centres, with Muswellbrook and associated towns, in Australia. There is a new civic centre.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government provided $2.8m for apprentices at Muswellbrook.

—As the honourable member for Paterson has pointed out, a big program has been provided for apprentices. Also, there has been a new water supply at Glennies Creek Dam. There has been long overdue attention to telephone services. Although at the moment these are heavily overloaded, that will be remedied. For the first time in years, the completion of the Sandy Hollow- Maryvale railway line is becoming a reality.
—They are all State government initiatives. You people are sabotaging them.

—I will tell the honourable member about the State Government initiative. It meant that the total bill for the railway line was to be met by White Industries. The line was also to carry other freight. I will tell the honourable member about some of the State Government's initiatives in New South Wales. They have just about crippled the coal industry in that State. I might ask also what Mr Wran is doing in relation to his navy-the 50 or 60 ships off the ports of Newcastle and Port Kembla-Wran's Navy. I will tell the honourable member what the record of the New South Wales Government is. Last year the coal industry of that State managed to increase its coal exports by 1.3 per cent. In contrast, what did Queensland do? It increased its exports by a mere 39 per cent .

SPEECH.PARA: The other day New South Wales lost a contract. It had the opportunity to be the sole and first supplier of a power station in Hong Kong. A bulk carrier which was sent by that utility to the port of Newcastle arrived on 13 December of last year. It was loaded two weeks ago. The power station was started up with South African coal and the utility will no longer look at New South Wales coal. At the moment Japanese buyers are negotiating with New South Wales colliers and have said that they will accept from New South Wales no more in quantity than its industry can guarantee to ship. They are saying: 'We are not interested in what you say you can ship, or in your port capacity. We want to know what you can actually ship. We will accept only the figure for exports last year'. I repeat, that represented an increase of a mere 1.3 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —The State is being sabotaged.

—It is being sabotaged by the people who stand to benefit most from the industry itself. I would like to mention also some of the benefits of this horrible, uncontrolled, export-oriented resource development causing, according to the honourable member for Reid, major regional dislocations and the economic decline of regions, as it relates to the area of Lithgow, Portland and Wallerawang. The multiplier effect on that area has already been seen. It may well be that in the next 10 years some 8,000 new jobs will be created in that area. That is nearly as many as are projected for the Hunter Valley. The multiplier effect can be conservatively estimated at 1 to 2 1/2 or 1 to 3. Already we have seen a tremendous demand for housing in Lithgow, where house prices have escalated rapidly. We have seen new shopping complexes and additions to the hospital. The Commonwealth Government, which the mover of the motion says has done nothing for the area, has provided special road grants for the development of some of the coal haulage roads. We have seen a bigger and bigger proportion of the Commonwealth tax sharing going to such cities as Lithgow and taking into account the additional pressures and needs that are being placed upon the coal industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us not overlook the contributions that are being made by industry itself, by the coal mine owners. They have to provide up-front payments which vary from $10m to $15m or $20m. Those up-front payments are not eligible for taxation deductibility because they are not devoted to capital development. The coal mine owners are required by the New South Wales Government to put up these sums in order to provide much of the infrastructure. Therefore, we see the coal companies producing much of that infrastructure-cultural and recreational facilities, new swimming pools and so on. Therefore, not only in Queensland are proprietors expected to provide such facilities; it happens in New South Wales also. I believe that if the motion were put before the coal miners of the Hunter Valley or those in my area of the western coal fields they would laugh it out of house and home.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for precedence to General Business has expired. The honourable member for Calare will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day under General Business for the next sitting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented and wish to make a personal explanation.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—I will be brief, because my colleague the Deputy Leader of the Opposition proposes to move an urgency motion. The honourable member for Calare (Mr MacKenzie) quoted selectively from my motion under General Business. He failed to mention that portion of the motion which states that unplanned and uncontrolled export oriented resources development is:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) . . . contributing to the economic decline of regions traditionally dependent on diverse manufacturing industries . . .

I specifically mentioned Bathurst and Orange in his electorate. Within that area , and particularly at Orange, manufacturing industries have been affected by export orientation that is unplanned and uncontrolled. My motion was submitted on that basis. The honourable member did not defend the Government from that assertion in any way. That is what I was talking about. The same thing happens in many other regions as well.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fry Mr K.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory, I present the Committee's Report on proposals for variations of the plan of layout of the City of Canberra and its environs (76th Series), together with copies of minutes of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This report covers 16 variations of the city plan and recommends the approval of works valued at $880,000. The Committee, in considering these proposed variations, took evidence from several individuals and community groups, as well as a member of the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly, during the public hearings held on 22 March 1982.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee has decided to withhold approval of two variations but has approved the remaining 14. In the 75th series of variations, the Committee withheld approval for residential development in Florey. It has decided to defer approval of the developments in Florey proposed in this series for the same reason as was advanced previously. Therefore, until the Committee receives adequate information about the new guidelines for the release of land in new residential subdivisions, and a statement setting out the responsibilities of private developers regarding servicing standards and marketing procedures, approval of the proposals is withheld. Further, the Committee believes that a decision on the cycle path at Bruce, variation 2 in the series, cannot be made without further information regarding the necessity for the removal and reconstruction of the cycle path.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government to provide leadership and guidance for the Australian people on the vital issue of world nuclear disarmament.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always left to the Opposition to raise in this Parliament any matter relating to disarmament. On the last occasion on which this matter was raised, about 17 September of last year, it was again raised as a matter of public importance by the Opposition. There have since been demonstrations, public meetings and marches throughout the length and breadth of this nation, also the world, urging that governments take action to guarantee that there will be no nuclear war, and that existing nuclear weapons will be removed. In the process there has been agitation and a proper submission to governments that there should be a freeze of nuclear weapons. But when we have a look at what action has been taken by the Australian Government we can see that there has been no leadership on this matter at all. I invite honourable members to have a look at the number of Australians who have been actively and intelligently discussing this matter, not just from the point of view of Australia but also from the point of view of the survival of the world. But not one Government Minister has been involved. There has been no enunciation on what the Government wants done to save the world.

SPEECH.PARA: There is just a complete blank on the basis that this matter has got nothing to do with this Government in Australia. Why is that so? It is because the Government is bereft of initiative and leadership at all levels. Apparently all it wants to do is sell uranium on the basis that we will get a few dollars for it. This Government could not care less what happens to the uranium; it hopes that everything will be all right. It is known that in the world at present as a result of uranium sales, perhaps ostensibly for peaceful and useful purposes, there has been a diversion into the production of nuclear weapons. The two super -powers, namely the Soviet Union and the United States have, between them, over 40,000 nuclear weapons. These two powers are not on very friendly terms. If either one decided to get involved in nuclear action it would destroy the world. We need only-I emphasise the word 'only'-about one tenth of the weapons which those powers have between them to guarantee that we will all be dead. The Speaker of the United States Congress, Congressman O'Neill, made the point that what we ought to be interested in is the path of life, not the path of catastrophe and annihilation. They are commendable words from a leader of the Democrats in the United States. Do we see that sort of statement made by this Government on this issue? Not at all.

Let us look at what has happened recently in the United States on a matter where we do have some influence. Let me make this point very clear. Statements which are made by the Australian Government should be taken notice of in the United States. I acknowledge that statements made by any political party representatives in Australia have no recognition in the Soviet Union. We have no influence there. Russia is just as guilty from the point of view of nuclear weapons and arms build-up as is anybody else. But we are talking about peace and what leadership in this field means.

It would be commendable if the leader of the Soviet Union said that he wanted a freeze on nuclear weapons and we entered into talks such as SALT-the strategic arms limitations talks-so as to guarantee that weapons are de-escalated, to use Kissinger's terms, or in our terms, removed altogether. But those sorts of talks are not taking place because the policy of the two super-powers has been that they have to get more weapons to deter each other from taking action. That is known as nuclear madness, because there is no guarantee that when the weapons are made somebody else in the heirarchy, whether it be the president of one nation or the other, will not decide to fire. We have no control over that sort of situation. But surely we have immense control from the point of view of what the people in Australia expect the leaders in this nation to say and do. For the leaders of this nation to say in forums right across Australia that they want a guarantee that all nuclear weapons will be removed would be an impressive stance .

The most impressive stance at the moment has been adopted by the Labor Party and other people in Australia talking about this matter. My colleagues and others have been involved in marches and have been urging that some sense of direction be introduced into international discussions on how to bring about the disarmament of nuclear weapons. I think that sort of action is tremendous, but from the point of view of what is happening about this matter, apart from rhetoric, this Government is completely silent. Nothing has been said over a period of years about what this Government should be urging on the Soviet Union and the United States, France and also other countries which have interests in nuclear weapons.

Let me make the point clear that it has been said that anyone who claims that the United States and the Soviet Union are merely building up weapons on the basis of a guarantee that there will be no war must either be working or involved in the manufacture of military products. Nobody with any common sense would say that there will be peace in or safety for the world because the super- powers are getting more weapons which will deter each other from taking action. That is not the way to bring about peace. If one looks at the budgets of both super-powers one can see the enormous amounts of their resources that are being diverted to the acquisition of nuclear weapons. In the United States, because of that diversion of resources and the fact that it is profitable to make weapons that destroy flesh and blood, there is a reaction, as one would expect in any sensible democracy.

In recent weeks in the United States six States, 31 cities, 257 towns, 160 congressmen and 24 senators have publicly called for a freeze on the manufacture of nuclear weapons. Is that action not to be applauded? Would honourable members not have thought that some members of the Australian Government at any level would have said: 'This is what we should be about'. If people in the United States can call for that sort of intelligent action to be taken, surely something should be done at the Australian level to encourage support for that position. We must stop the United States policy that says: 'Arms transfer can serve as a very constructive instrument in foreign policy'. Arms transfer as a constructive instrument in foreign policy is disastrous, and we all know it. In which country has the transfer of arms, once they have been used, been demonstrated to have been a constructive policy? I ask honourable members to recall what happened in Eritrea where unfortunately Eritreans are now being bombarded with Soviet Union weapons. Let us look at the nonsense in Latin America and the dreadful slaughter of people by weapons which certainly appear to have been manufactured in the United States. Honourable members should have a look at the position in Afghanistan and the Soviet Union's interest in weapons. The Soviet Union is also selling weapons to the Palestine Liberation Organisation. In Israel the United States is selling billions of dollars worth of weapons. It is also selling billions of dollars worth of weapons to the Saudi Arabians.

Why can there not be leadership in this country whose Ministers say: 'There is a need for greater progress in the United States and in the Soviet Union for SALT negotiations. There is a need for the creation of a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty. There is a need to develop the methods to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons among nations which currently do not have them, that is, to prevent horizontal proliferation. There is a need to study the relationship between disarmament and the developing needs of the poorer countries, and there is a need for the creation of regional arms control arrangments such as the Indian Ocean zone of peace'.

No body would dispute that sort of initiative and leadership. Do honourable members know that those propostions-a very worthy and great contribution-were made by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) not in Australia but in a speech on disarmament to the United Nations in 1978. We on this side of the House fully support them, but nothing has happened since 1978 in support of any one of those five criteria. This Government has not passed any resolutions urging that something be done in this area. In fact the SALT negotiations have not commenced . In fact, as I have said, they have been deliberately delayed because of the present incredible policy of the United States to build up its arms before it has talks on removing the arms. I cannot imagine anything more limited from the point of view of an intelligent look at the world. The Prime Minister said that there is a need for the creation of a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty. That has not happened. France is detonating many nuclear devices on Muroroa in the Pacific, but nothing is done by this Government. Why is France not being taken to the International Court of Justice-as we did and where it was convicted -on the basis that its actions could well be affecting the very lives of all the people and certainly the environment in the Pacific? Why could that not have been done?

What methods have been adopted to prevent a spread of nuclear weapons? We sell our uranium all over the world and give consent in advance to the reprocessing of the fuel. We are accepting somebody else's point of view. We sell uranium to Finland. It will be enriched and reprocessed in the Soviet Union. What gurantee have we that we can prevent diversion of that fuel? We sell uranium to France on the basis that it will be used for peaceful purposes. But not all French uranium is used for peaceful purposes. France is very active in the sale of armaments. It certainly is a destablising influence in the Pacific region, as I mentioned. Whilst we have 13 world treaties, we have no guarantee of what happens to our fuel. We just let it go.

I return to the thrust of my argument. What leadership in a true democracy be saying. Would it not be talking about the needs of the world? Would it not be saying the very things that the Prime Minister said outside Australia in 1978- that is, that we ought to be talking about the Third World and the needs of the Third World? The World is spending $1m a minute on armaments. Let us consider the needs of the Third World. One fifth of the population of the Third World is illiterate, half is starving and one third is in need of medical attention. A fraction of the money spent on armaments could be diverted to helping the Third World. France is doing nothing about it. France ranks very well in world arms sales. I am not just picking it out; it is not often mentioned. France sold $3.1 billion worth of armaments during 1980. It is running third in the sale of armaments race.

There is great business for both the super-powers in the sale of arms. What are we to do about it? Surely we could say in this Parliament that we deplore it, that we are against it. If a tank costs $2m surely we can say that that amount of money could provide at least a couple of thousand classrooms for the Third World to meet the needs of, say, 50,000 children. We should look at a report which was published as recently as October last year which studied the relationship between disarmament and the problems of the world. Six per cent of the world's finite resources are being used each year for the making of armaments. The Third World accounted for 75 per cent of all imports of arms during the 1970s. Since 1945 Third World countries collectively have spent an average of $19 billion a year on arms. Incidentally, about a quarter of the Soviet Union's foreign exchange earnings come from arms sales. So we can be balanced in this issue. The conclusions of the report are quite staggering. Between 50 million and 100 million people are now employed in the provision of military goods and services.

The world cannot last unless the leaders of countries, particularly democracies , realise the advantage of peace and, certainly, the horrors of war. The clear indication to our people is that if there were to be another war it would be a nuclear war. It would be a war of destruction of the whole of this universe. Surely when demonstrations and meetings are held and when Parliament holds debates on this issue resolutions can be made and active support can be given to the people who at present are marching throughout the length and breadth of the world urging governments to do something intelligent, to meet and discuss how nuclear weapons can be removed. I wait with bated breath for the Prime Minister to make one speech in Australia on his present views on immediate disarmament in the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful for this further opportunity to restate, for the benefit of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) and the Parliament, the Government's well- established policy on the vital issue of world nuclear disarmament. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition has put forward the proposition that the Government has failed to provide leadership and guidance to the Australian people on this vital issue. Such a proposition, as the Deputy Leader well knows, is absurd. The Australian Government has consistently drawn the dangers of the nuclear arms race to the attention of the people of Australia, the Parliament and the international community. It is equally absurd to suggest that the Government does not strongly support the ultimate goal of general and complete disarmament and the negotiation of balanced and verifiable-I stress those two qualifications -measures of arms control.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's policy on these crucial issues has been repeatedly and forcefully expressed in all multilateral negotiating and consultative bodies including the committee on disarmament. It is associated with the challenge that the continuing arms race presents to the international community. In June and July of this year this commitment will be futher advanced through Australia's active participation in New York in the United Nations Special Session on Disarmament. I hope to lead the Australian delegation to that important meeting. Notwithstanding the present unfavourable international political climate which adversely affects the negotiation of successful arms control measures, Australia intends to play an active role at the United Nations General Assembly's Special Session on Disarmament, UNSSOD II. UNSSOD II will provide an important opportunity to review progress since the previous United Nations Special Session was held in 1978, to impart fresh impetus to negotiations at present going on, to explore ways in which the present arms control agenda may produce results and , of course, to take stock of and reorder priorities.

The Government, in preparing itself for this and other important meetings on this issue, has also actively sought to involve the community at large, particularly non-government organisations with an interest in disarmament issues , in the preparatory process leading up to such meetings. Equally importantly, the Government has also actively participated in and fostered debate on this issue in the Parliament. An important part of this process has been the opportunity provided for debate by the Government's strict adherence to its policy of tabling all nuclear safeguards agreements with customer countries for Australia's uranium. In addition-in contrast to allegations of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition-this is the third time in the last six months that this issue has been debated in its own right in the Parliament.

The curbing of the proliferation of nuclear weapons is a primary plank in Australia's policy on disarmament. Australia strongly supports the Nuclear Non- Proliferation Treaty-the NPT-as the corner stone of the international non- proliferation regime. The regime established by the NPT, which includes full scope safeguards administered by the International Atomic Energy Agency over all nuclear installations in non-nuclear weapon states which are parties to the NPT, provides assurances of the peaceful intent of nuclear activities. These assurances are essential to the establishment of the climate of confidence needed for successful co-operation in the peaceful uses of nuclear energy. Australia is concerned that some states are not parties to the NPT. Australia wants to see all states party to the NPT. It is a matter of great concern to Australia that some states may have developed or may be developing programs, including the construction of unsafeguarded facilities, for the development of nuclear devices. Such activities clearly jeopard ise regional and international security. Australia looks to the nuclear weapon states to help contain the spread of nuclear weapons. In this connection Australia sees the conclusion of a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty as a significant step towards setting further restraints on existing nuclear arsenals and barriers to the further spread of nuclear weapons.

The conclusion of a comprehensive test ban-CTB-would make the development of new nuclear weapons and the improvement of existing ones considerably more difficult. This would help strengthen the NPT and lead to the fuller implementaion of that treaty. A widely accepted CTB would act as a restraint on those states which have not accepted the NPT and would help to inhibit the spread of nuclear weapons to additional countries. A universally accepted CTB would prevent the spread of nuclear weapons to additional countries. Australia is actively pursuing the goal of a comprehensive nuclear test ban. In this connection the Deputy Leader of the Opposition mentioned the French tests in the Pacific. As he would well know, we have constantly protested against these tests , most recently at the South Pacific Forum late last year. We have continued to make known our objections to them. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition mentioned taking this issue to the International Court of Justice. I have to inform him that some time ago France announced that it no longer accepted the compulsory jurisdiction of the ICJ. The situation now is quite different from when the previous case was taken.

I would also like to refer briefly to the question of chemical weapons. The Australian Government also gives strong support to the early conclusion of a convention to ban these weapons. Existing international instruments on this subject, including the 1925 treaty and the 1972 Biological Weapons Convention, do not of themselves completely ban chemical weapons. The need for a comprehensive and verifiable ban has become more pressing in the light of disturbing reports in recent years, and indeed in recent days, that chemical weapons have been used in certain parts of the world. Australia co-sponsored a UNGA resolution in 1980 which set up an impartial investigating team to examine the allegations of the use of chemical weapons in recent conflicts. Substantial progress on nuclear arms reduction and disarmament can take place only if a basis for confidence, trust and mutual respect exists.

As I said earlier, it is a matter of regret that the current international climate is not favourable to the successful negotiation of nuclear arms control agreements. The reason for this is the substantial build-up by the Soviet Union over the last decade of the whole range of its nuclear forces and the instability and anxiety it has created by such actions as its invasion of Afghanistan, its support of Vietnam's invasion of Kampuchea and the unrelenting pressure applied by Moscow towards the imposition of martial law in Poland. The Australian Government and the countries of the Western alliance maintain that there is a direct relationship between nuclear arms control and disarmament efforts and the maintenance of international stability and security.

The Government cannot accept the proposition inherent in Labor Party policy on this issue that different standards of behaviour can be applied to the actions of the East and the West. In a statement to Parliament on 24 March, I stressed that, either inadvertently or deliberately, there are always some people who, while they find it possible to remain silent in the face of huge military efforts on the part of the Soviet Union, raise the cry of war-mongering whenever the West shows any signs of matching that effort. The fact remains that, the United States has reduced or stabilised its military forces over the last decade , the Soviet response has been an unrelenting and threatening build-up in all theatres. Governments cannot be expected to hazard their security, and agreements to disarm have elements of risk in the absence of a basis for confidence and trust.

Some people have suggested that progress towards nuclear disarmament could be achieved by an immediate freeze on the numbers of nuclear weapons held by the Soviet Union and the United States. If such a freeze were to be accepted by both super-powers as leading unambiguously to verifiable reductions of nuclear weapons to equal force levels, this would be a major achievement. However, given the bigger Soviet weapons programs and the huge disparity in the makeup of the arsenals of the two super-powers in favour of the Soviet Union, it is not clear that an across the board freeze in the terms which have been advocated would provide the essential enhancement of security which must underlie any such proposals. A major criticism of some of the freeze proposals that have been advanced is that a mutual freeze by the USA and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics would tend to perpetuate an unequal and therefore unstable military balance. Its effect could be to reward the USSR for a decade of unilateral buildup and to penalise the United States for its restraint in weapons development over the same period.

This House will be aware that negotiations between the United States and the Soviet Union on reducing medium range nuclear forces in Europe have been going on since November. On 18 November 1981 President Reagan made clear that the United States was prepared to agree to a zero option outcome. That is, the United States and its allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation would cancel the planned deployment of Pershing II and Cruise missiles in Western Europe if the Soviet Union would remove the SS4, SS5 and SS20 missiles at present targeted on Western Europe. This United States proposal is supported by the NATO allies and has been particularly emphasised by the Government of the Federal Republic of Germany. Since the negotiations commenced, the Soviet Union has indicated that its preference is to engage in a propaganda campaign rather than to embark on substantive negotiations.

President Brezhnev's statement on 16 March at the opening of the Soviet Trade Union Congress is the latest example of the Soviet propaganda approach. Specifically, his reported offer to stop any further Soviet production of SS20 missiles would leave no fewer than 300 such missiles, each capable of carrying three nuclear warheads, targetable upon Europe. His suggestion that these weapons systems would be removed from the European section of Soviet territory has no meaning because the missiles could still reach western European targets and, in any case, the vehicles on which they are carried are mobile. In the Government's view, the Soviet Union should address seriously the zero option proposal of the NATO allies.

Clearly stated, this Government's policy on nuclear disarmament is that, first, the nuclear weapons powers must take effective action to limit and reduce their nuclear arsenals. Secondly, there must be an end to nuclear testing in all environments. Thirdly, the international non-proliferation system must be strengthened. This Government is unequivocal in its support for the achievement of these aims. This will represent the cornerstone of Australia's approach at the forthcoming United Nations Special Session on Disarmament in New York in June this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —The discussion is now concluded.

PETITION.TITLE: Mawson's Hut, Antarctica
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Mawson's Hut, Antarctica

To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia showeth that:

1. The late Sir Douglas Mawson was an Australian of world renown not only on account of his great scientific achievements, but also for his dedication and his courageous struggle against the elements, evidenced particularly by his leadership of the Australasian Antarctic Expedition of 1911-1913.

2. The hut which formed the base for his 1911-1913 Expedition, situated at Commonwealth Bay in Antarctica, is now dilapidated following many years of exposure to the harsh climatic conditions of the Antarctic continent.

3. The restoration and preservation of Mawson's hut in situ would not only provide a lasting memorial to Sir Douglas Mawson and his colleagues upon the continent where he devoted so much of his efforts, but also be a reminder to all of the significant contribution which Australia has made and is continuing to make towards the exploration and scientific investigation of Antarctica.

4. Such restoration and preservation would add to the efforts already made by representatives of our sister-nation New Zealand, resulting in the restoration of other historic buildings in Antarctica. It would also provide a fitting means of celebrating the 70th anniversary of Mawson's epic sledge journey in which his two colleagues gave their lives.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will take such action as it may to ensure the restoration and preservation of the hut formerly occupied by the Australasian Antarctic Expedition of 1911-1913 under the leadership of Sir Douglas Mawson.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Fry,Mr Barry Jones and Mr MacKenzie.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Seal Pups
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned young citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That there is an urgent need to take steps to terminate the inhumane, random slaughter of the baby fur seals in Canada, in order to prevent their eventual extinction.
Your petitioners urge that action be taken to:
(a) inform the Government of Canada of our opposition to the annual slaughter of fur seals as currently practised in that country;
(b) actively discourage any form of trading that involves goods or products derived (either wholly or partially) from the pelts of baby fur seals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Seal Pups
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia showeth:
That the present hunt for harp seals in Canada is carried out in a cruel and inhumane manner.
That the population of harp seals has not been clearly shown to be increasing.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government formally call on the Canadian Government to end the harp seal hunt and use its constitutional powers to halt the importation into Australia of products derived from the harp seal, Pagophilus Greenlandicus.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Day
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the 26th January, 1788, is the date of first white settlement in Australia , and therefore marks the beginning of modern Australia, and this event marks the most appropriate date on which to celebrate our national day.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament will determine that Australia Day is to be celebrated on the twenty-sixth day of January each year, and that a public holiday will be declared on that day, regardless of which day of the week is the 26th.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Anti-discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament in Canberra assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:
That since 1788 discrimination has existed in Australia on particular grounds including, inter alia, grounds of sex, race, ethnic origin, marital status, pregnancy and/or sexual preference;

That since 1788 such discrimination has been accepted and promoted by Australian laws and practices, particularly in the provision of work, in appointment to jobs, in promotion to positions of authority and lucrative incomes, in the provision of goods and services, in the provision of accommodation and generally in relation to political, economic and social institutions of power.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That adequate and appropriate laws be immediately formulated and passed through the Parliament to render unlawful discrimination in all areas over which the Commonwealth holds power, namely, in employment of all persons in the Commonwealth Public Service and employed in Commonwealth Statutory Authorities and other bodies, in the provision of Commonwealth accommodation and goods and services and also in all areas over which legislation for the Australian Capital Territory would be valid.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aruma Lodge Hostel, Broken Hill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth :

We petition the Federal government to subsidise Aruma Lodge of Broken Hill for provision of nursing care for residents who are not ill enough to be admitted to hospital but need the extra care of trained and semi-trained nurses.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
That part of the Aruma Lodge hostel be reclassified for nursing care patients as a matter of urgency.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Planning Association of Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should take action as it deems appropriate to ensure the continuing effectiveness of the Family Planning Association of Victoria.
In particular that:
Federal government continue to provide funding to the Family Planning Association of Victoria for clinical services to meet the growing demands of the community.
Increased funding be provided to the Family Planning Association of Victoria's Training, Education and Research Unit for educational services to the community.
All funding be provided on a triennial basis to enable cost-effective long term planning.
The federal government grant the Family Planning Association of Victoria exemption from sales tax and allow donations to be tax deductable.

That we, the undersigned, support the expansion of family planning services to ensure that adequate contraceptive information is fully available to all sections of the community, with special consideration given to disadvantaged groups.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
(a) that the Australian Government signed the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women in Copenhagen in 1980;
(b) that the Convention came into force on 3 September 1981;

(c) that Australian women suffer serious disadvantage in employment, education, accommodation, membership of licensed clubs, provision of goods and services including services relating to banking, insurance and the provision of grants, loans, credit or finance;

(d) that this disadvantage could be overcome by (i) making unlawful certain discrimination on the grounds of sex and marital status, (ii) eliminating discrimination on the ground of sex and marital status and (iii) promoting affirmative action for women in employment;
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Parliament pass the Sex and Marital Status Discrimination Bill 1981.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Broadcasting Licences
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth :
That Family Radio Ltd represents the largest single interest group in the community-i.e. Christians-who do not have a voice in public broadcasting commensurate with their representation.
That prime time access to existing broadcasts by Christian Groups is virtually non-existent, and access at other times is fast disappearing.
That, by comparison with other capitals, Brisbane is entitled to at least one more category 'S' FM broadcasting licence.
That there appears to be no prospect of the release of further category 'S' FM licences in the near future for Brisbane.
That satisfactory fulfilment of the aims of Family Radio and its expansion can only be achieved by broadcasting in its own right under licence.

That Family Radio has a responsibility to the large support groups which have contributed substantially to its development, to achieve the aims in broadcasting and community work for which it was established.

That there is an urgent need for the kind of service and support that Family Radio can provide to other community groups through the particular type of integrated programming proposed by the company under a full-time licence.
And that pruned government resources are obviously insufficient to advance the development of public broadcasting as orginally intended.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the government will support Family Radio's application for a broadcasting licence and will enable more category 'S' FM licences to be made available in Brisbane.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Parliament Assembled take action as it deems appropriate to ensure that the present Federal Government children's services program is maintained and improved, and the Child Care Act is retained as a legislative base for this important program.
In considering the recommendations of the Spender report, no recommendations put forward should be implemented without full consultation with community groups.

The present subsidy system to Child Care Centres should be retained. The proposal that monies be made available to subsidise child care in commercial centres is viewed with grave concern. The proposal to alter the present guidelines for subsidy in different programs and introduce a common means test is also viewed with grave concern, as the present arrangements are effective.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action on the abovementioned issues.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Registration Fee for Periodicals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned, respectfully ask that the Australian Government request Australia Post to review the recently introduced annual registration fee for periodicals.

With many periodicals produced for distribution to members in small numbers only, this new impost, together with the recent increases in postage rates, considerably adds to the administrative costs of small clubs and organisers, whose activities are non profit, and are directly involved in community activities.
Accordingly, we earnestly request this review, with a view to smaller clubs and organisations, at least, being exempted from the requirements of annual registration.
We thank you in anticipation of your support.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Highway, Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of North Queensland respectfully showeth:
That the National Highway is the responsibility of the Federal Government,
The Bruce Highway in North Queensland is of inferior standard for a National Highway,
Queensland has suffered a 15 per cent disadvantage over other states during the past ten years in road funding; and
The state of the Highway is deteriorating as maintenance expenditure is insufficient to maintain even the present standard.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament will allocate sufficient expenditure, to raise the standard of the National Highway in North Queensland to Department of Transport standards, in conjunction with the Queensland Government, within ten years.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Liquefied Petroleum Gas Subsidy
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Division of Mallee respectfully showeth that in respect:
(1) The current electricity supply crisis in Australia, and

(2) The one million household and business Liquefied Petoleum Gas (LPG) users in rural and provincial Australia who are already paying considerably more for their gas than those Australians, mostly in capital cities, who are connected to natural gas and who will be further disadvantaged if the Commonwealth Government does not renew the LPG subsidy of $80 a tonne which expires in March 1983.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will extend the LPG subsidy for a further three years and include a specific appropriation in the 1982 Budget so the subsidy can continue uninterrupted throughout the 1982-83 financial year.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Seal Pups
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned Citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners are outraged and disturbed by the inhumane slaughter of baby harp seals off the coasts of Newfoundland and in particular, the Gulf of St Lawrence and the Magdelen Islands.
1. That, as a people of a democratic society, we urge the Australian Government to halt all imports of seal products.
2. That we can be assured that the murdering of harp seals be discontinued in all forms at the real and perilous threat of the extinction of yet another Artic animal species.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government take heed of their petitioners' protest, and give seals the right to life.

PETITION.TITLE: Export of Live Animals
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned Citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners are outraged and disturbed by the exploitation of live animals for slaughter to overseas.
1. That, as a people of a democratic society, we urge the Australian Government to ban the export of live animals for slaughter overseas.
2. That the export of live horses to Japan for slaughter for human consumption be banned on the grounds that it is cruel and unnecessary.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourasble the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners are gravely concerned at the special privileges bestowed on the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, M.P. and the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon, M.P.-

(1) That in 1964 a Liberal/Country Party Government granted Mr Anthony, M,P., a Commonwealth Government Home Loan Mortgage of $17,964 for a period of 45 years at a fixed interest rate of 4.5 per cent and that at 1.10.81 the amount of principal outstanding was $15,005.

(2) That in 1970 a Liberal/Country Party Government granted Mr Nixon, M.P., a Commonwealth Government Home Loan Mortgage of $30,352 for a period of 45 years at a fixed interest rate of 6.25 per cent and that at the 1.10.81 the amount of principal outstanding was $28,404.

(3) Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government immediately extend these most generous terms to the many thousands of young couples in South Australia who are at present suffering undue hardship and financial embarrassment due to high interest rates.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Howard, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: — I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to provide, together with authorities available under other legislation, borrowing authority needed to help ensure that calls on the Consolidated Revenue Fund do not exceed amounts legally available to the Fund. Honourable members will be aware that expenditure from the Consolidated Revenue Fund cannot validly exceed moneys ultimately available to the Fund. Thus , for many years, successive governments have introduced legislation for the purposes of funding defence expenditure out of the Loan Fund.

In my Budget Speech for 1981-82 I announced that the prospective overall Budget deficit for this year was estimated to be $146m. Since the Budget was brought down, the outlook has changed. On current information, total outlays are now estimated to be of the order of one and a half per cent above the Budget estimate. The increase has resulted from larger than expected wage and salary increases, funding for new Government initiatives and inescapable cost and price increases arising since the Budget was prepared. In addition, total receipts are now estimated to be about one per cent below the Budget estimate, largely as a result of shortfalls, caused by industrial disputes, in revenue from the crude oil excise and rejection in another place of the proposed sales tax legislation to broaden the tax base.

The resulting increased Budget deficit has given rise to a possibility that calls on the Consolidated Revenue Fund might exceed moneys legally available to that Fund. Existing legislation permits certain expenditures to be funded either from the Consolidated Revenue Fund or the Loan Fund. Funding from the Loan Fund to the maximum extent could, indeed, if there are no untoward developments, avoid the prospect of a deficit in the Consolidated Revenue Fund. However, it is not certain that the margin currently available would be sufficient to meet contingencies such as, for example, further industrial action having additional adverse implications on revenue flows and on the deficit.

The simplest and traditional means of providing appropriate legislative authority to meet such contingencies is a loan Bill of the type I am now presenting. The Bill includes a specific limit to the amount of any borrowings that may be undertaken. That limit is $300m, which amount the Government considers reasonable to meet contingencies of a kind noted above and which compares favourably with the provision in the Loan Act 1980 of $900m. I commend the Bill to honourable members.
Debate (on motion by Mr West) adjourned.

STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1981 [No. 2 ]
Bill presented by Mr Fife, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill, which provides for the limited introduction of tuition fees in tertiary education institutions in the States and in the Northern Territory, was passed by the House of Representatives last year but rejected by the Senate. The Bill contains a provision for the Minister to make determinations as to the circumstances in which students should be charged tuition fees or be exempt from such charges. However, this provision is subject to a number of limitations specifically mentioned in the Bill. These include the following. First, students undertaking courses leading to first degree or diplomas cannot be charged fees. Second, the maximum fee is set at $1,000 per annum. Finally, students who have commenced courses before 1982 are to be exempt from fees charges for those courses.

The Bill provides, as a condition of recurrent grants, that institutions charge tuition fees in accordance with these arrangements and that they do not charge tuition fees in other circumstances. The Bill provides for recurrent grants scheduled in the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act 1981 to be offset by an amount equivalent to the money from tuition fees which those institutions will be required to charge. As it will not now be possible to introduce tuition fees before the beginning of 1983 it is the Government's intention, when this Bill is enacted, to introduce an amending Bill which will provide for fees exemptions for courses commenced before the beginning of 1983 rather than 1982.

At no time has the Government advocated the restoration of tuition fees for first degree or first diploma qualifications, but it continues to be the Government's view that those who wish to further their studies beyond a reasonable range of basic qualifications should make a contribution towards the cost of tuition. There are substantial benefits which flow to individuals from higher education and the Government believes that the community as a whole should not be expected to meet all of the costs. I commend the Bill to the House .
Debate (on motion by Mr West) adjourned.

AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL UNIVERSITY AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1981 [No. 2]
Bill presented by Mr Fife read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the limited introduction of tuition fees at the Australian National University. The principles involved in this Bill are essentially the same as those in the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1981. The Bill empowers the Minister to make determinations with respect to such matters as the categories of students liable to pay tuition fees, exemptions, the situation of overseas students, and the level of fees to be charged. Statistical information on student enrolments and fees chargeable is to be provided by the University. The University Council is empowered to make statutes in respect of tuition fees. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Hurford) adjourned.
CANBERRA COLLEGE OF ADVANCED EDUCATION AMENDMENT BILL 1981 [No. 2]
Bill presented by Mr Fife, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is intended to provide for the limited introduction of tuition fees at the Canberra College of Advanced Education and is a companion measure to the Bills to amend the Australian National University Act and the States Grants ( Tertiary Education Assistance) Act. The same principles are involved in this Bill as in the Australian National University Bill and the provision of the Bill relating to the introduction of tuition fees are in the same terms.

The Bill empowers the Minister to make determinations in connection with tuition fees on the same basis as with the University Bill and there is a similar obligation for the College Council to ensure that each student liable to pay tuition fees does so. The same annual limit of $1,000 is set. I commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Fife, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend two Acts-the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act 1978 and the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act 1981. Amendments to the 1978 Act will finalise adjustments to grants for the 1979-1981 triennium and are in respect of increases in the salaries and wages component of recurrent grants. This will involve the provision of a further $53.7m for the recurrent programs of universities, colleges of advanced education and technical and further education institutions in the States and the Northern Territory.

Amendments to the 1981 Act reflect the implementation to date of the Government 's decisions on the consolidation of colleges of advanced education. The Bill includes a transition provision to take account of certain name changes that have occurred as a result of consolidation of colleges of advanced education. On the understanding that consolidation is actively pursued during 1982, the Bill provides funds for 1982 for the Armidale College of Advanced Education, the Newcastle College of Advanced Education, the Milperra College of Advanced Education, State College of Victoria Hawthorn, State College of Victoria Institute of Early Childhood Development and State College of Victoria Melbourne . Funds are also provided to the Wollongong Institute of Education until the end of April when it will amalgamate with the University of Wollongong. I seek leave to incorporate in the Hansard the attached statement outlining the adjustments to the schedules of grants for 1982 for individual univerities and colleges of advanced education arising from these changes.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Outline of Adjustments to Schedules of Grants for 1982

1. The States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act 1981 provided funds in accordance with the Government's policy for the rationalisation of advanced education. By the end of 1981 acceptable arrangements had been received for 24 of the 30 colleges proposed for consolidation. Acceptable arrangements for consolidation are still required for:
New South Wales
Milperra College of Advanced Education
Armidale College of Advanced Education
Newcastle College of Advanced Education
Victoria
SCV Hawthorn
SCV Institute of Early Childhood Development
SCV Melbourne

2. On the basis that the consolidation of these institutions is actively pursued during 1982, certain adjustments have been made to the schedules of grants. These adjustments will ensure that the six remaining institutions are funded for 1982. There is no provision for their funding as individual institutions after 1982.
3. The details of the adjustments to the schedules of grants for 1982 are set out below:

In the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act 1981, some funds for advanced education purposes were identified as national unallocated monies. This Bill provides funds from the national unallocated monies for 1982 for the following colleges and amounts as specified:
Milperra College of Advanced Education-$3.027m

The funds provided for 1982 to the University of New England and the University of Newcastle included amounts for the programs conducted by the Armidale College of Advanced Education and the Newcastle College of Advanced Education. This Bill transfers funds from the scheduled 1982 grants for the University of New England and the University of Newcastle to the Armidale and Newcastle Colleges of Advanced Education respectively:

Newcastle College of Advanced Education-$10.13m

Agreement has been reached that the Wollongong Institute of Education will merge with the University of Wollongong from May 1982. To take account of the situation until then, separate funding for the Institute of $1.333m is provided from the funds originally provided to the University. The Bill also provides for amounts of $200,000 and $129,000 to be transferred to the Western Australian Institute of Technology and the Victorian College of Pharmacy respectively. These transfers implement requests made by the States concerned and in the case of the Victorian College of Pharmacy are to meet costs of administering a Staffing Information Exchange and Staff Placement Service which has been established by the State Government on behalf of colleges of advanced education in Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —Adjustments also have been made to the funds appropriated by the 1981 Act for research centres of excellence and community language courses to take account of allocations to the Australian National University which are appropriated separately. I commend the Bill to the House.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Nixon, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to establish a new and comprehensive legislative base for the export inspection and control responsibilities within my portfolio. Under existing arrangements, export inspection powers are drawn from the Customs Act 1901 and the Commerce (Trade Descriptions) Act 1905. This has created a number of administrative and legal weaknesses. Although these could be overcome by amending the existing legislation, the Government has taken the view that the most appropriate long term response is to develop new and separate export inspection legislation which ensures a more efficient and flexible legal framework.

The Bill provides for the application of export controls to goods specified in regulations; spells out inspection responsibilities and the authority of inspection staff to carry out these responsibilities; and sets penalties to apply in the case of fraud or deliberate malpractice. Whilst the inspection powers under the Bill are to be exercised by officers of the Department of Primary Industry, the Bill also provides for the Secretary to the Department to authorise carriage of such powers as are appropriate by other people. This is to cover the situation where officers of other Commonwealth and State instrumentalities, and in certain instances people under contract, carry out specific or specialised inspection functions on behalf of the Department of Primary Industry. Powers provided include all those necessary to ensure compliance with the relevant conditions and restrictions. These include appropriate powers of entry and search; powers to detain vehicles, ships or aircraft for this purpose; and powers to seize products within the scope of the controls.

Side by side with these powers are a range of safeguards to avoid abuses by inspection staff. Entry into premises, other than registered premises, can take place only within the consent of the occupier, or in pursuance of a warrant issued by a Justice of the Peace, who must be convinced of the need for entry. A time limit is to be placed on the currency of warrants. Powers of search of vehicles, ships or aircraft are tied to a requirement that authorised officers produce their identity cards. Similarly, people are not required to assist authorised officers in their duties unless such proof of identity is produced. Provisions are also included imposing a limit on the time seized goods can be held unless proceedings are instituted and also for the release, as appropriate, of such goods.

Strict penalties are provided for breaches of the conditions of the Bill and associated regulations. Major penalties of $100,000 or 5 years imprisonment or both apply to the exportation of prescribed goods in contravention of specified requirements, for the use of false trade descriptions and for unlawful interference with, or forgery of, official marks. Where appropriate, however, it will be possible to proceed against such offences by summary jurisdiction with lesser maximum penalties of $5,000 or 12 months imprisonment or both. The maximum penalty of $100,000 or 5 years imprisonment or both is the same as that which was approved by Parliament in the 1981 Budget session following the meat substitution issue. Its inclusion in this Bill will ensure that such a penalty applies to all export inspection and control activities under my responsibility. In addition, this Bill widens the coverage of the penalty by making it an offence for false trade descriptions to be applied to documentation, and for registered establishments to have in their possession an official inspection stamp without authorisation.

The Bill also increases the size of the penalty for a range of other offences, such as failure to submit a notice of intention to export, the penalty for which is up from $40 to $2000 or 12 months imprisonment, or both; and failure to provide assistance to, or the obstruction of, inspection staff, the penalty for which is up from $100 to $1,000 or 6 months imprisonment, or both. In the 1981 Budget session a penalty of $100,000 or 5 years imprisonment or both was introduced for false and misleading statements in declarations furnished in respect of meat. This was to ensure that the maximum penalty applied to offences relating to matters such as the exporter, species, age and slaughter dates which were not covered by existing trade description provisions. These are, however, descriptive matters which are more appropriately located under the trade description requirements. The Bill broadens the definition of trade description to encompass such matters and, as mentioned previously, the application of a false trade description has been extended to documentation. Offences against these matters still, therefore, attract a penalty of $100,000 or 5 years imprisonment or both. The false declarations provision in the Bill will cover minor breaches only and the penalty has been set at a level appropriate to this offence. The penalty of $2,000 or 12 months imprisonment or both is the level of penalty generally established in Commonwealth legislation for offences of this kind.

There are two new penalty provisions in the Bill. First, there is a fine of up to $50,000 for breaches of licensing provisions, such as those that exist for woodchips. It will, however, be possible to proceed against such an offence by summary jurisdiction with a maximum penalty of $5,000. Second, there is a penalty of up to $2,000 or 12 months imprisonment or both for providing any authorised officer, including officers of the Department of Primary Industry, with goods prepared or treated at a registered establishment unless the person in whose name the establishment is registered has the written approval of the Secretary of my Department. The issue of authorised officers receiving produce either free or at prices below those available to the general public has been raised several times in evidence before the Royal Commission into the Meat Industry. It is a practice which I have decided must be stopped. Concurrent with the penalties set out in clause 24 of the Bill, which apply to those who offer cheap products, the full force of the provisions of the Public Service Act will apply to Commonwealth staff who accept such products.

This change in policy will be notified to all establishments and authorised officers. The only conditions under which the Secretary of my Department will approve establishments to sell produce to authorised officers is where they have a discrete and separate facility for selling to the public, where the price to those officers is the same as that available to the general public and where the transaction is backed by a receipt which describes the product, price and the purchase date. This approval will be tied to the annual re-registration process with which all establishments must comply and will be strictly enforced by the compliance unit now being established in the new export inspection service. This Bill is the first fundamental step in providing an appropriate legal basis for export inspection in the 1980s and will be backed by new regulations and a system of ministerial orders which will allow us to respond quickly to changing requirements and conditions. These regulations and orders are now being drafted. I commend the Bill to honourable members.
Debate (on motion by Mr Hurford) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Nixon, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill sets out amendments to other legislation which are consequential to the passage and proclamation of the Export Control Bill 1982. Its main features are that it cuts the link between my export inspection responsibilities and the Customs Act 1901 and the Commerce (Trade Descriptions) Act 1905. It also repeals the Meat Export (Penalties) Act 1981 and the higher penalties for all foods which were incorporated in the Customs and Commerce (Trade Descriptions) Acts following the meat substitution issue. These higher penalties are now covered by the Export Control Bill. This Bill is to come into operation on the same day as the Export Control Bill 1982. I commend the Bill to honourable members.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Albury-Wodonga Development (Financial Assistance) Act 1973. Honourable members will be aware of the assistance that has been provided by this and previous governments for the development of the Albury-Wodonga growth centre, and for some time past the Commonwealth, New South Wales and Victoria have been reviewing the financial arrangements under which the growth centre was funded. Early in 1981 it was agreed between the three governments that the States would be relieved of their obligations to repay the loans and to pay interest on the loans provided by the Commonwealth. In lieu of repayments, it was agreed that the Commonwealth would have access to funds generated from development activities. The proposed amendments to this Act will enable the new agreement to be implemented. Special arrangements have already been negotiated with the States in relation to funds provided to them for on- passing to the Albury and Wodonga councils, and the arrangements relating to these funds are not included in the new agreement.

Only some $1.2m was provided for Albury-Wodonga development under this Act. The bulk of the funds for Albury-Wodonga-some $117m-has been advanced under the Urban and Regional Development (Financial Assistance) Act 1974 which does not require amendment for the new financial arrangements to become effective. The new financial agreement with New South Wales and Victoria will be tabled in the Parliament when it has been executed by the three governments. I commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek your indulgence. May I suggest that the House has a general debate covering this Bill and the Commonwealth Employees (Voluntary Membership of Unions) Bill 1982, as they are associated measures? Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering these two measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.
