TALK.START.PARA: —The House may well judge this proposed legislation, the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill, on the basis that it is introduced by the most disastrous Minister in an increasingly disaster-prone government. With the unerring instinct of a homing missile, he zeros in on those features which have been fundamental to the successful operation of the conciliation and arbitration system and seeks to destroy them at a stroke of his pen. In their place he would erect provisions conceived for political purposes and palpably likely to create further divisions between worker and worker, union and union, unions and employers and, indeed, between employer and employer.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill stands as a monument to the incompetence of the Fraser Government in the area of industrial relations. The Bill represents another fanciful scheme by the Government to manipulate industrial relations for the Government's own perceived political advantage. The Bill demonstrates the Government's complete lack of understanding of industrial relations and its inability to introduce sensible and constructive industrial reforms. The Bill has been presented to this Parliament by a man who is undoubtedly the worst Minister for Industrial Relations that this country has ever had. The main provisions of the Bill are a testimony to the abuse by the Government of the consultative processes of the National Labour Consultative Council.

Let us consider the fact that Australia has now had the best part of seven years of Fraser Government industrial relations policies. The Government cannot talk about an industrial relations system which reflects the philosophy or the workings of the legislation of anyone but itself. They have been proved to be policies based on ignorance, policies that have produced confrontation between Government, employers and unions, and policies that challenge the traditional industrial dispute settling procedures of the Australian conciliation and arbitration system. We may well ask now, after this long period since the end of 1975: Where have these policies got us?

Let us consider some of the Fraser Government's main initiatives in the industrial relations area. We have had the establishment of the Industrial Relations Bureau, a body that has been trenchantly and virtually universally criticised and condemned-certainly by employers and unions alike. We have had the introduction of section 45D of the Trade Practices Act, a section which has demonstrated its potential to cause serious industrial dislocation and which is now largely unused. The Government's effort to make this section workable by the provision in 1979 of a conciliation procedure has been a dismal failure. Not one State government, Liberal or Labor, has introduced the required complementary legislation. The failure of any government to introduce such legislation speaks for itself.

We go to the new laws relating to deregistration of unions and secret strike ballots. I ask the House to recall the flurry with which this legislation was introduced, respectively, in 1979 and 1981. Here we had parts of the panacea to improve industrial relations-it was said that it was necessary to bring them in- and neither piece of legislation has been used since its introduction in 1979 and 1981. We then go to the new laws relating to the deregistration of unions, which I have mentioned. We also go to the fact that the approach of the NLCC and the approach of the Government to consultation with employers and unions have been the subject of constant complaint by employers and unions. When we consider this point, it is important to remember that neither the Minister nor any other spokesman for the Government attempts to say that the criticisms in regard to lack of consultation spring only from the Australian Council of Trade Unions or the trade unions. The national employer organisations have been openly critical of the way in which this Government has sidestepped the intention and the intended practice of the NLCC.

In sum, looking at this track record of the legislation which has been introduced and the approach which has been adopted, we find that the Fraser Government, in its approach to industrial relations, has been nothing short of disastrous for this country. The preoccupation with confrontationist policies has led to a deterioration in industrial relations and has meant that opportunities to improve our industrial relations system through constructive reforms have been forgone. In those circumstances it is no wonder that there is disillusionment in the business community with the Government's performance. The loss of confidence reflects a growing awareness in that area that not merely are the policies of this Government not working but, worse than that, they are making the industrial relations scene in this country worse than it would otherwise be. This realisation by employers, unions and communities was elegantly expressed in an editorial in the Melbourne Age of 25 March of this year, which stated:
The state of Australia's industrial relations is serious enough to deserve a better approach and a far better Minister.

The main matters in the Bill and the proposal which was abandoned just before the Bill's introduction testify to the Government's incompetence in industrial relations and to the extreme policies that it is pursuing. On the whole, the Government's proposals are ill-conceived, they are against the wishes of employers and unions and they are counter-productive. To be specific, the withdrawal of the power of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to award preference to union members is contrary to one of the basic and most long-standing principles of our conciliation and arbitration system. The attack on union membership will lead to untold industrial trouble. The stand -down proposal is unnecessary, unfair to employees, and is likely-indeed, I would say certain-to lead to more industrial disputation.

The whole scheme for the encouragement of industry unions is based on a definition of industry. However, there is no indication of what that amounts to in the Bill. In other words, the whole concept is based upon industry, and that apparently is to be left to the question of regulation. The now abandoned proposal with respect to enterprise unions was undoubtedly the most stupid and most widely criticised of the Fraser Government's industrial relations proposals . The business journal Rydges, in the April issue of this year, had this to say about the proposal:

A charitable interpretation of the enterprise union scheme would see it as some kind of election ploy, a gesture to indicate that the Government does see some role for itself in solving Australia's industrial relations problems. But if one adds it to the object failure of the Industrial Relations Bureau, the only conclusion possible is that Fraser is simply out of his depth in this area. The sooner the industrial relations portfolio is given to someone who, like Mr Tony Street, indicates an intellectual grasp of the difficulties and the limited possibilities for reform of this area, the better it will be for all concerned.

I now look in more detail at some of the specific provisions in the legislation. I turn first to voluntary unionism and preference. A central feature of the Bill is the provisions relating to voluntary unionism, as it is called, and preference to unionists. The Bill withdraws the power of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to grant preference and provides an action for damages for a person who claims to have been discriminated against on the basis of non-membership of a union. These provisions clearly demonstrate that the Government is out of touch with industrial reality. One of the basic policies of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act since its introduction in 1904 has been the encouragement of union membership, mainly through providing for preference to unionist clauses to be inserted into awards in appropriate circumstances. This policy is based on an understanding of the industrial system and the recognition of the valuable role that unions play in the system, and of the importance of the existence of unions to the employers themselves. The policy of the Act and the criteria taken into account by the Commission in deciding whether to insert preference provisions into awards is encapsulated in section 47 (2) of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. This provision, with slight additions, has been in the Act since its inception in 1904.

I ask the House to examine closely and dispassionately what it is that this proposed legislation seeks to remove from the Act as it stands. I will refer to section 47 of the Act, particularly to section 47 (2), which is the section concerning the power of the Commission to grant preference to members of organisations. I ask you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to listen very closely to what you are being asked to eliminate from the legislation, because the very reading of this section shows the depth of the stupidity and the industrial unreality of what is being proposed by the Government. The Parliament is being asked to eliminate from the Act a provision which essentially has been in the legislation since 1904, when this Parliament first brought in legislation which has endured to this time. Sub-section (1) reads:

The Commission may, by an award, or by an order made on the application of an organization or person bound by an award, direct that preference shall, in relation to such matters, in such manner and subject to such conditions as are specified in the award or order, be given to such organizations or members of organizations as are specified in the award or order.
I ask honourable members to look particularly at sub-section (2). It states:

Whenever, in the opinion of the Commission, it is necessary, for the prevention or settlement of an industrial dispute, for ensuring that effect will be given to the purposes and objectives of an award, for the maintenance of industrial peace or for the welfare of society to direct that preference shall be given to members of organizations as provided by the last preceding sub-section, the Commission shall so direct.

In other words, the Parliament of this country and successive governments of different persuasions which have had infinitely more touch with the industrial realities of Australia have, for this period of nearly 80 years, said that it should be mandatory upon the Arbitration Commission to grant preference provisions in awards to achieve objectives seen by successive governments as likely to achieve those things which would be in the interests of the community. It has been regarded for nearly 80 years by governments of different political hues as an instrument to be used by the Commission, by the Tribunal, to achieve objectives on behalf of the community. I ask honourable members to think to themselves what those objectives are that have been identified over this period of 80 years as likely to be helped in their achievement by the Commission using this instrument of preference to unionists. I read those provisions again:
Whenever, in the opinion of the Commission, it is necessary, for the prevention or settlement of an industrial dispute-

In other words, successive governments over a period of 80 years have perceived that the use of this provision, of awarding a preference clause, may be useful- or necessary, as the legislation says-for the prevention or the settlement of an industrial dispute. That is the first category. The second category is:
. . . for ensuring that effect will be given to the purposes and objectives of an award . . .

In other words, for 80 years successive governments with people infinitely more attuned to the industrial realities of this country than this Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) or his acolyte will ever be have said that this is a relevant and useful instrument for ensuring that effect will be given to the purposes and objectives of an award. I come to the third category. For 80 years successive governments of different political persuasions have seen it as a relevant instrument for doing what? For the maintenance of industrial peace. The fourth category in which successive governments of different political persuasions for 80 years have seen as a relevant instrument is the welfare of society.

They are the four categories of purposes which, I repeat, for the best part of 80 years successive governments, conservative and Labor, have put to the arbitral tribunal in saying: 'Here is an instrument which you shall use to achieve these laudable fundamental objectives'. So, what do we have? We have the obscenity of a Prime Minister who would be more remarkable than any other Prime Minister in the history of this country for using industrial relations for confrontation rather than bringing people together, who has had no experience of the reality of industrial relations in the cloistered upbringing and experience that he has had, and his acolyte, acknowledged as the most disastrous Minister ever to hold this portfolio, having the temerity, after that 80 years of experience in which successive governments, conservative and Labor have said to the tribunal that it shall use this instrument to achieve these laudable objectives-and it has worked-to say, with their abundance of experience and with the miserable nature of their purposes to pursue political objectives, that the Government will throw out the window all that accumulated experience during which this instrument has been used by the tribunal to achieve those basic objectives-the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes, the ensuring that effect will be given to the purposes and objectives of awards, the maintenance of industrial peace and the welfare of society. All that 80 years of experience goes out the window at the behest of this Prime Minister and of this very transient Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner).

Let us see what has been said in the courts in respect of this so that we can abolish this proposition of equating the provisions for the granting of preference with some concept of compulsory unionism. The High Court has made it quite clear that that is not what these provisions are about. I refer briefly to what has been said in that respect by Mr Justice Menzies of the High Court, as he then was, in 1972, in the Altona Petroleum case. He addressed himself to whether this was a question of compulsory unionism.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the reference?
—I am reading from the Australian Labor Law Reporter, CCH, paragraph 7547. I will check that reference but I think that is correct. Mr Justice Menzies said:

SPEECH.PARA: Regarding the claims as I do, I reject the contention that either separately or together they constitute not a claim for preference but a claim for monopoly of employment.

The High Court in the Altona Petroleum case confirmed the judgment of Mr Justice Dixon in the Wallis case. In respect of section 47, Mr Justice Menzies said that it is an exclusive code in relation to the issue of preference. The section is limited to the granting of preference and the section does not authorise the granting of compulsory unionism. Again in this matter we have a series of decisions by the High Court, and successive statements in judgments and decisions by the Arbitration Commission that it is acknowledged that what is being done here is not giving effect to a system of compulsory unionism but using an instrument that has been in place for 80 years to give effect to those basic purposes contained in section 47 sub-section (2), which this proposed legislation asks us to abolish.

The policy of preference to unionists recognises the important role, in the conciliation and arbitration system, of unions in representing the interests of workers in that system. It recognises that the benefits of union action will flow through the award system to members and non-members alike. It recognises the view that those who benefit from the work of unions should contribute to the cost of that work.

On that point, let me say that all of the emphasis in the speeches of honourable members opposite has been about the rights of individuals not to join unions. Is there not such a thing as obligation? Has not the Australian community a view about people who take the benefits of the outlay and actions of others yet make no contribution thereto? Life is not just a matter of rights; life is a combination of rights and obligations. A person in the work place may stand aside and see his fellow workers put their hands in their pockets to pay their union dues. Out of the actions of the union wages go up or conditions improve. Can we intellectually satisfy ourselves that we have concluded our consideration of the situation by saying: 'That person has a right not to be associated with a union.'? Has he not an obligation? If he is associated with a union, in terms of having his or her hand out to take the wage increase or improvement in conditions of employment gained by it, is there not some obligation to be met by him?

This does not mean that we are arguing for compulsory unionism. What we are saying in the Labor Party, and in the ACTU, is not that we are in favour of compulsory unionism but rather that the question of union membership is a legitimate industrial issue. What do we say about a person who says 'No, I do not want anything to do with unions' but nevertheless lines up every time with his or her hand out and says 'Yes, I will have every wage increase; I will operate under every improved condition of employment that the trade union movement will get.'? Are we then to say that that person is not being hypocritical? Of course he or she is. Every time they accept a wage increase or improved condition of employment that the union membership has worked to obtain, they are indeed having something to do with that trade union. The only thing that they are not doing is facing up to their obligation to pay to be a member of the union. If such a person does not like the policies of the union he or she can democratically involve himself or herself in it. But let them not try to indulge in the luxury of saying that they are not going to have anything to do with trade unions when in fact, every day of their lives, they are by accepting the wages and conditions obtained for them by the trade union movement.

Our opposition to the Government's proposal signifies a rejection of the naive assumption that a long-standing and basic principle of our industrial system can be overturned by a new set of laws. It is especially naive when there is no significant support for them from employers, unions or the community. Our opposition also signifies that a more intelligent response to the competing factors relating to union membership is to leave the matter in the hands of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and, where necessary, to develop workable reforms through genuine consultation with employers and unions.

The Government's proposals would overturn the traditional policy under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. It would upset union membership arrangements entered into between employers and unions. Quite obviously, it would limit the ability of the Commission to settle demarcation disputes and, in the words of one employer spokesman, it would lead to untold industrial trouble. In the cause of good industrial relations the Government proposals under this head should be rejected.

I come next to the stand-down provisions. The Bill seeks to extend to employers a direct right to stand down employees who take industrial action, or who cannot be usefully employed as a result of industrial action. The power that the Government proposes to give all employers is one which has previously been conferred only after an independent examination of all of the relevant circumstances has been made by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Such an examination has safeguarded the interests of employees, while extending to employers in appropriate circumstances the power to stand down workers who cannot be usefully employed. That is a power to which the ACTU and the Labor Party do not object, but it is one which ought to be exercised within the ambit of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

The Bill seeks to change this position in a way which is completely unfair to employees and which is likely to be creative of industrial disputes. There would be no hearing before an impartial tribunal prior to employees being stood down. Nor would any appeal be available to employees to challenge the merits of the employer's action. An employer will be able to stand down employees even when the relevant industrial action has been caused by him. For example, that could occur over a safety issue. In those circumstances the arbitrary, autonomous power is given to the employer to stand down workers although subsequent investigation may show that the action of the workers in withdrawing their labour, in their own safety interest, was totally justified. There is no requirement that an employer notify an employee before a stand-down declaration has the effect of disentitling him to wages. The arbitrary nature of the power given to employers will certainly lead to disputation and disaffection.

The employers' response to the Government's proposal on stand-downs is indicative of their lack of enthusiasm for the new measures and their recognition of its potential for creating industrial problems. The employers wanted an assurance that they could elect to use the existing stand-down powers- or to use the new powers-in a stand-down situation. That right of election has been spelled out in the Bill. It would be in the best interests of all concerned if the stand-down question were left in the hands of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. If employers consider that they need a general stand- down power, nothing would then prevent them from seeking such a power by making an application to the Commission. In the 1950s the metal industry employers made such an application and were successful in having a stand-down provision inserted in the metal industry award.

I come to the question of industry unions. The Bill seeks to encourage industry -based unions by way of amendment of the registration and amalgamation provisions of the Act. Three comments may be made about the Government's proposal with respect to industry unions. Firstly, one basic flaw in the proposal is that it contains no indication of what constitutes an industry for the purpose of encouraging the formation of industry-based unions. This means that the proposal will remain inoperative until a satisfactory definition of ' industry' is devised.

Secondly, the relaxing of the present unreasonable restrictions in the Act on union amalgamations, on the basis of facilitating amalgamations where they would result in an industry union, will do nothing to assist to reduce the number of unions in Australia. Very few unions will be able to take advantage of such a relaxation. Relaxing the requirements on this basis was rejected by the National Labour Consultative Council in April 1978 as unworkable. If the Government wishes to do something positive in the area of union amalgamations it should implement the NLCC report on amalgamations, as it promised to do before the 1980 elections. Thirdly, the practical effect of the amendments is likely to be to create the means for an increase in the number of unions in Australia rather than a reduction, as new unions seek registration in relation to small developing industries. This will further exacerbate the problems that result from having too many unions.

I come next to the de-registration provisions. The proposals in the Bill which deal with the consequences of the de-registration of a State-registered union have been considered for several years at meetings of Commonwealth and State Ministers for Labour. The practical problems raised in those meetings about the proposals have been been resolved. However, at the insistence of the Western Australian Government legislation concerning it is being introduced now. This legislation is not directed to any real or pressing industrial issue.

I wish to refer briefly to certain other matters before moving the amendment that has been circulated in my name. The Bill inserts new provisions in the Act dealing with financial assistance. There are some problems with these provisions which suggest that they should be reconsidered by the NLCC. The only commendable aspect of the Bill is that which relates to an agreement, which has come out of the NLCC, concerning relatively minor matters dealing with casual vacancies and tenure of employment.

In conclusion, this is bad legislation. It represents a continuation of the disastrous confrontationist policies of the Fraser Government. It does not enjoy the general support of employers or unions. It seeks to make significant changes to our tried and tested conciliation and arbitration system, even though there is no community support for such changes. It is sponsored by a Minister whose inept performance in his portfolio staggers even his critics. The timing of the introduction of the legislation clearly demonstrates that it was an election ploy related to Lowe and Victoria. The Government should have learned some lessons from the results of those elections. Those lessons are clear. They are that the Government should abandon the present industrial relations policies, withdraw the controversial parts of the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill and dump the Minister responsible for the Bill. I move:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

'the Bill be withdrawn and re-drafted after full consultations in the National Labour Consultative Council directed to eliminating from the Bill those provisions clearly calculated to worsen industrial relations in this country'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Mr H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —While I was listening to the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) I thought, just for a fleeting moment, that for once we were going to get a considered contribution from him. But he soon ran out of substance and had to revert to the usual exhibition of histrionics and personal abuse which have become hallmarks of his contributions to debate in this chamber .

SPEECH.PARA: The two pieces of legislation that we are debating in this chamber this afternoon, the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill and the Commonwealth Employees (Voluntary Membership of Unions) Bill, are further initiatives of the Fraser Government in dealing with the vexed problem of industrial relations. The impact of industrial relations issues has been demonstrated once again in recent months. The combination of increased industrial disruption, large wage increases and shorter working hours is having a detrimental effect. It is increasing overall labour costs and hence the cost of production in Australian industry. This has been the major domestic factor contributing to the fall off in the performance of the Australian economy and the slow down in employment growth.

It is in the industrial relations sphere within the community that selfishness seems to be most rampant. Demonstrable selfishness is evident to some degree among all parties involved in industrial disputation-employers, employees and union leaders. But it is most dramatically exemplified amongst the militant union leaders.

Trade unions developed from the need to protect the weak-the employees-from the strong-the employers-in times past when employees often were forced to work in intolerable conditions. But with the growth in numbers and growth in the power of the trade union movement since those early times, the exploited have become the exploiters, if not in the guise of individual employees then certainly in the guise of the union movement as a whole when its role has been abused by some of those militant leaders. Some of the militant leaders seem selfishly hell bent on formenting industrial disputes, often to confirm their own position in union power struggles or because ideologically they are committed to the destruction of our present social and economic system rather than in the pursuit of justifiable wage demands.

Unless there is a marked change in attitude it will be virtually impossible to prevent unions led by such people from continuing to set a price for their labour well above what the level of productivity in this country can afford.

Failure to achieve this required change in attitude will ensure that Australia' s economy fails to perform to its optimum. The result of that will be increasing unemployment and Australian industry becoming less competitive in the international economic environment. Of course, that in turn will cause overseas investors and traders to look increasingly askance at Australia as an investment or trading prospect.

The persistence of this selfish attitude has been demonstrated over the last 12 months or so by the wage grab of 4 per cent in real terms, that is over and above the level of inflation, for the 1980-81 financial year and a serious increase in disputation. Four million working days were lost through industrial disputes in the calendar year 1981, the largest part of that being in the December quarter when days lost through industrial disputation increased by 160 per cent compared with the figure for the December quarter 1980.

In the light of the persistence of this unsatisfactory attitude on the part of union militants and, of course, the constitutional constraints on the Federal Government as far as its jurisdiction in industrial matters is concerned, the Fraser Government does have a credible record of performance in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would be joking.
—Just wait a moment and I will recall for the honourable member the record of the Labor Party between 1972 and 1975.
—Order! The honourable member will ignore interjections. I ask honourable members on my left to remain silent.

—The Constitution splits power over industrial relations matters between the Commonwealth and State governments. This has allowed jurisdictional fights and movement by unions between the Federal and State jurisdictions to obtain what the unions see as the best deal, and a multiplicity of unions and therefore the development of demarcation disputes and inter-union power struggles. The Federal Government's activity is also constrained by the absence of enforceable sanctions. The Government needs to rely, firstly, on persuasion and, secondly, on the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, which can act only after a dispute exists and that dispute extends beyond the boundaries of one State. So, allowing for these constraints, and notwithstanding that wages hike and increased disputation which I mentioned for 1981, the overall record of the present Government over the last 6 1/2 years in achieving wage constraint and relative industrial peace deserves commendation.

SPEECH.PARA: This is especially so when the record is compared with that of the previous Labor Government. In 1974, industrial disputes cost this country 6.3 million working days, and between March 1974 and March 1975 wages increased by 34.7 per cent as against the level of inflation of 17.6 per cent. There was a real increase in wages of nearly 17 per cent, which was way beyond what the economy could afford, and this destroyed business confidence, fuelled inflation and caused soaring unemployment.

We should also remember that that disastrous record was registered when the present honourable member for Wills was concurrently both President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and President of the Australian Labor Party, as a result of which the Labor Party claimed a special relationship with the trade union movement. It has a special relationship all right! Historically the Labor Party is the creature of the trade union movement and it is bound to do its bidding, to the detriment of the wider community. This is clearly demonstrated by the events in 1974 and 1975. The people of Australia should remember this in the light of present attempts by the Labor Party to resurrect its claim of having a special relationship with the trade union movement in order to gain electoral support. The present Government governs for the benefit of the whole of the population and its success in the industrial sphere is demonstrated by that stark comparison.

The passage of this legislation will further enhance that reputation. It will also allow the creation of an environment more favourable for the necessary change in attitude to which I referred earlier to occur. This legislation is a package relating to three major industrial relations matters and some minor ones . The legislation ensures, firstly that workers are not forced to join a union against their wishes by introducing provisions prohibiting the victimisation of or discrimination against a person who does not wish to belong to a union. The legislation also precludes the granting of preference to unionists. Secondly, the legislation gives employers the right automatically to stand down employees who have no work to perform because of strikes by other workers. This part of the legislation overrides any stand down provisions which may have been written into a particular award. An employer will be able to stand down an employee for any period, including part of a day. Thirdly, the legislation helps smooth the way for the establishment of industry-based unions.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is an industry?

—I will deal with that. The legislation provides the legislative framework to facilitate the restructuring of unions into fewer industry-based organisations. Thus, through this legislation a start is being made on what will be a difficult and lengthy process leading to the development of industry-based unions in the expectation that this will allow for better communication between employers and employees and reduce the incidence of demarcation disputes. The legislation specifically does not define an industry for the purpose of establishing an industry based union because we are breaking new ground. Therefore, it is far more appropriate that this definition be left to later regulation as the climate for the establishment of industry unions develops and as they work out in practice.

SPEECH.PARA: The three main themes of the legislation are: The protection of the rights of the individual; the provision of a better balance in the powers, rights and duties of employers and employees; and the opening of the door to movement from within the work force so that present union rigidities and monopolies are loosened and structures are created which are more suited to a modern economy and representative negotiations between employers and employees.

Voluntarism is basic to a liberal society. The notion of the closed shop, compulsion-even coercion-is anathema to a free society. In his remarks the honourable member for Wills talked about obligations as well as freedoms. That seems to be a new discovery for the Australian Labor Party to suddenly talk about obligations. Any obligation should be met voluntarily. It should not be required to be met by legislative decree. All people must be free to exercise their personal choice as to whether they wish to join an organisation, including an industrial organisation.

The honourable member for Wills talked about encouragement being given to employees to join unions. Certainly, encouragement is one thing but coercion is quite another. In practice the preference to unionists, which he talked about as being removed from the legislation, has almost inevitably resulted in compulsion . The honourable member for Wills claimed that the fact that this legislation regarding preference to unionists has been in operation for 80 years gave it some justification. In fact, retaining this preference clause would exclude in practice those not wishing to join the union movement in general, or a particular union, from obtaining employment in a certain area of work. There are numerous examples over that 80-year period to which the honourable member for Wills referred of the abuse that has been given to the preference provided for union members. He claimed that the legislation has worked. It has not. That is one of the very reasons the Government is introducing a change through this legislation.

The stand-down provisions will assist businessmen to minimise the effects of victimisation by unionists in one section of the business, or even in another business, who go on strike, thereby frustrating the productive capacity of other employees, but whose wage costs continue. By standing down those employees the businessman to some extent will be able to protect the financial viability of his business during that period of industrial disruption. It will also more directly bring home to employees the cost to the community at large of industrial disruption.

The transformation of the union structure from a craft basis to an industry basis will, as I have already mentioned, be a long and slow process. But considerable advantages are to be derived from the more rational structure that will result from industry by industry negotiations, arbitration and fewer demarcation disputes. The sections of this legislation which facilitate the establishment of fewer industry based unions are very welcome. The legislation should provide an environment in which there is more opportunity for more effective direct communication between employers and employees. That is an essential ingredient for better industrial relations.

Further initiatives are required for a more peaceful industrial relations climate to be assured in the future. Agreements reached by direct negotiation between employers and employees on an industry by industry basis must have enforceable sanctions applying to any party-employers or employees-breaking the agreement. Some of the recent large increases in pay and reduced working hours to some extent have been accepted by employers on the basis that the agreement reached would apply for 12 months; for example, in the case of the metal industry, or even longer-15 months-with regard to the building industry. During that time there is to be no application for further variations in the award and no action taken against individual employers on industrial matters.

Although a significant reduction in industrial disputes in these industries has occurred since the new agreements have been in operation, disputes have not been eliminated. Indeed, quite outside the spirit of this agreement the Builders Labourers Federation in the last fortnight imposed bans on companies involved in the deregistration proceedings against it. This clearly demonstrates that relying purely on the good will of parties to an agreement will not be sufficient to ensure the fulfilment of that agreement. Therefore, it is essential that substantial and effective sanctions be imposed on those breaking any agreement. The hope that these agreements give for a more stable industrial relations environment will not be fulfilled unless the penalties applying to those breaking the agreement are sufficient to deter such irresponsible action.

Another area needing attention concerns the concept of comparative wage justice . This is the concept that employees doing the same work for different employers or in different industries should receive the same wages and conditions irrespective of the capacity of that industry or employer to pay. The consequences of this concept are the flow-on and pace-setting effects. This fuels inflation and increases unemployment as employers shed labour in an effort to contain costs. Comparative wage justice had a major impact on the wages explosion of 1974-75, to which I have already referred, as unionists scrambled to restore relativities. There is a very real danger that a similar wages scramble will flow on from the recent generous settlements which have taken place in some sectors of the industry. The economy simply cannot afford this occurrence. Therefore, the concept of comparative wage justice must gradually disappear.

This is one area where the disciplines of the market must more effectively apply. Certainly, basic pay should be adequate. But beyond that, differences in industries, working conditions, location, demand for labour and, most importantly, profitability could be reflected in differences in remuneration from employer to employer. This is one way of ensuring that resources are devoted to the most productive sectors of our economy.

The legislation which we are debating today provides a considerable step forward for industrial relations. As I have mentioned, there is provision for voluntary unionism. That, together with a provision for stand downs and especially for the establishment of industry unions, paves the way for a more rational approach towards industrial matters in the future. As I have indicated, further issues need attention. I have highlighted two of those-the need for effective sanctions to be placed on employers and employees and the gradual removal of the flow-on effect which is based on the concept of comparative wage justice. A more responsible approach will be achieved only from the marked change in attitude to which I referred at the outset. I note that the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) interjects to support that fact also. There must be greater recognition that employers and employees have a common interest in minimising industrial disputes and maximising productivity.

This legislation and the further initiatives which I have suggested provide the framework within which that changed attitude and unity of purpose can be established. If we fail to achieve a sensible and equitable reconciliation of conflicts of interests, which do arise from time to time, and thereby fail to establish the overriding pre-eminence of this unity of purpose in maximising the wealth creation potential of our human and physical resources, inevitably this country will fall further and further behind other countries in its capacity to fulfil the economic and other expectations of its citizens. Therefore, I strongly support this legislation and strongly oppose the amendment which has been moved by the honourable member for Wills which I find entirely unnecessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Innes Mr U.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment. At best all the amendment could do would be to take the legislation away and, for the first time, endeavour to come to grips with the range of industrial relations problems that bedevil the community at this time. We have just heard 20 minutes of drivel. The honourable member for Kingston (Mr Chapman) did not speak about industrial relations to which this legislation is directed but sought to lay the blame for the economic ills and the mismanagement of the government on the salary and wage earners of this country. This phoney piece of legislation is in fact another piece of huffing and puffing that will go on the industrial relations legislative scrapheap, largely unused, as did legislation relating to secondary boycotts and the Industrial Relations Bureau. What an absolute disaster. The Government is the architect of all this legislation. It is yet another piece of legislation developed by the Government on negative industrial relations policy. It is designed to become more and more tyrannical and oppressive to the organised trade union movement in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The main thrust of the Government's policy is to undermine the traditional role of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission; that is, the settlement of disputes that extend beyond the limits of State borders and to use its expertise developed over many years to act in the best interests of the parties to a dispute and of the public and industry generally. Despite the efforts of the Federal Government, there is no significant support amongst the employers, unions or in the community for a departure from the present tried and tested system of industrial relations. The legislation, which seeks to amend certain sections of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, is particularly vicious as it strikes at the very heart of good industrial relations, provokes confrontation and, as I have said before, destroys tried and tested principles. It also promotes the interests of industrial parasites and saboteurs. These amendments follow on from previous legislation of a penal nature-such as that dealing with the Industrial Relations Bureau and the Commonwealth Employees ( Employment Provisions) Act-and they complement the penal clauses of the various awards that provide fines for unions and fines and gaol sentences for workers who breach the award.

The legislation provides an opportunity for deregistration of unions as a penalty, to the advantage of employers and their cronies. Although disputes will occur in relation to preference to unionists and award coverage for members of deregistered State unions, the Commission will be prevented by this legislation from dealing with them. It will hinder the process of settling disputes through the established disputes settling machinery in the interests of the parties and of the general community. There are several other problems with the provision to prevent the Commission from dealing with disputes involving members of deregistered unions. Deregistration has been shown to be an ineffective sanction and ultimately a self-defeating sanction for the industrial system concerned. Strengthening the sanction as proposed will only encourage unions to remain outside the industrial system with its controls and established dispute prevention and settlement procedures. If that is the case the result will be to provoke industrial disputes, not to endeavour to settle them. Employers will have the right to stand down employees without reference to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. That is a snide way of inflicting a no-pay situation on an employee at the whim of the employer. What a bludgeon that will be in the hands of an employer. Indiscriminate use of it would create absolutely intolerable situations. A declaration could be made and could be held by an employer to be used at his whim. What a devastating effect that would have on an endeavour to resolve an industrial dispute.

The deletion or repeal of preference clauses and the inclusion of the dubious principle of voluntary unionism will also create tremendous difficulties, without providing any link to the settlement procedures, to the proper authority to resolve such disputes. As I have already said, these amendments will protect the well-being of industrial bludgers, scabs and pimps and will provide the modus operandi for agents provocateurs to infiltrate unions and sabotage the organised trade union movement, in the interests of the Government and other reactionary vested interests in the community. I have spent a long time in the trade union movement. The individuals to whom the honourable member for Wills ( Mr Hawke) referred are prepared to take everything and contribute nothing. He rightly referred to them as the individuals who are basically protected by this legislation. They are the individuals, the pimps, who are on the periphery of this whole issue. People who have had any experience of the type of individual to whom I am referring-I am sure also honourable members in the chamber for this debate, some of whom have already left-despise these individuals as much as do other people in the industrial relations area. They have no time for people of that nature. They want to deal with organisations and their members who will contribute to the policy making and the determination of decisions along the way . The Government is seeking to take away the capacity to organise on that basis, to ensure that when people are negotiating issues of an industrial relations nature they talk to all of the people concerned, not just a saboteur who for all sorts of reasons may be there to undermine the negotiations. Enactment of that part of the legislation will be a retrograde step.

It seems to me to be spelt out clearly and unequivocally that the arbitration system whereby the gains made by unions and financed by union members flow to members and non-members alike has to be accepted. There is a recognition by many workers that, for them to be effectively represented and protected, all eligible workers should be members of the relevant union. The validity of the conciliation and arbitration system rests on the collective representation of workers through their unions and the preference of employers to deal with an organisation representing the industrial interests of its employees rather than to deal directly with the individual employees. The potential of questions relating to union membership to cause serious and prolonged industrial disputation has been a fact of life ever since I can remember. The arguments that ensue about people not facing up to their responsibilities are ongoing and can be cleared up only by everybody accepting his responsibility in the matter. My friend and colleague the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) will deal with some of our erstwhile sleazy lawyers in the chamber who, ever since I can remember, have contributed to a union because it has been compulsory to do so. We wonder whether they will be able to escape their obligations to the Law Institute of Victoria or its equivalent in other States. I know my colleague will deal with that aspect very effectively.

The subject of industry unions has been spelt out clearly and unequivocally by the Donovan Royal Commission on Trade Unions and Employers Associations in Britain. Surely industrial conditions there compare with those in this country. The Donovan Commission in Britain, where union structures are similar to those in Australia, took a similar view to that expressed by us. The Government, in adopting the procedures and systems that exist in Japan, West Germany and elsewhere which are not relevant to the situation in Australia, is proceeding along the wrong lines.

For instance, recently our friend at the table, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner), in his old inimitable style, the previous Minister who held the portfolio and the Government in general double crossed a tripartite conference. At that time they guaranteed to take forward a decision. As the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) has explained, they gave an assurance that amendments would be proceeded with, with the support of the employers and the unions, to amend the legislation to ensure that amalgamations could be streamlined, enabling positive steps to be taken, with the co-operation of the unions and the employers, to reduce the number of unions involved. The only way to proceed from that starting point is to ensure that any developments endeavour to improve industrial relations. Participation by those groups should not be restricted to industrial relations matters; there should be consultation on day to day problems. As the honourable member for Wills has spelt out time and again , if discussions on the economy could take place it would be fruitful and would assist in solving the problems that bedevil the Australian community at the present time. The Government has suddenly woken up. A Government announcement has been made by our erstwhile friend at the table. He wants the Australian Council of Trade Unions to produce a paper on the nation. Government members are pretty slow learners. I was a member of a parliamentary committee which inquired into specific learning difficulties. I reckon that the Minister would probably be a case history. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Minister for Industrial Relations have just realised that tripartite discussions should take place.

I return to the Donovan Royal Commission in Britain. Many workers such as craftsmen, clerks and technicians have an obvious interest in combining on an occupational rather than industrial basis, so that they are free to take their transferable skills from job to job while remaining in the same union. In many respects it is an impractical proposition to endeavour to change a situation such as that. It is almost impossible to have craft organisations contained within an industry unless proper guidelines are worked out. There would be more problems than anyone could possibly imagine if we endeavoured to impose industry unions on organisations of craft members whose skills were far and above those of process workers. How do we reach a situation in which we can come to grips with a range of problems by eliminating the representation of those organisations?

The real decisive objection to industrial unionism for the Donovan Commission was the drastic upheaval in the structure of British unions that would be involved in a move towards industry unions. For this reason the Commission concluded that there should not be a move toward the attainment of industry unionism, as it exists in the Federal Republic of Germany, and that the problems caused by a multiplicity of unions could be considerably eased by encouraging, firstly, mergers between unions; secondly, agreements between unions on matters such as recruiting and negotiation rights; and thirdly, inter-union co- operation on the shop floor. That is what the tripartite meeting indicated. When the matter was referred to the Minister he came up with this conglomeration of rubbish that will resolve absolutely nothing. In fact, the legislation highlights the incompetence of the Minister, who has the inglorious reputation of being the dunce of the most incompetent front bench in the history of this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will never get there.

—Neither will the honourable member. I was there. A very succinct description of the Minister's performance appeared in the Melbourne Age of 25 March, the same day as the article that announced the proposal for enterprise unions had been jettisoned. The Age editorial stated:

SPEECH.PARA: At last Mr Ian Viner has done something positive for our industrial relations. His decision yesterday to ''set aside'' his proposed legislation to allow the establishment of company unions in Australia is perhaps the pinnacle of his unhappy year as Federal Minister for Industrial Relations.
It is unfortunate that Mr Viner has not shown the same common sense with the other contentious parts of this new industrial relations package.
The state of Australia's industrial relations is serious enough to deserve a better approach-and a far better Minister.
Mr Viner's legislation would lock us further into this confrontationist style of industrial relations when our real need is to find a way out of it.
Our five-vote Minister-he would have got six votes but the Prime Minister told him to vote for the Treasurer (Mr Howard)-is the individual--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who told you that?

—I am not going to say. Under those circumstances it is ridiculous to pursue this legislation as it now stands. Of course, the only answer to it is the suggestion of the honourable member for Wills, who proposed that the legislation ought to be taken away, redrafted and referred to the tripartite group that was once dealing with such matters in an endeavour to come here with a composite proposition that would really work in the interests of industrial relations in this country. The legislation is obviously an endeavour to camouflage the incompetence of the Government by blaming wage and salary earners for the Government's failure to solve our economic ills. To say the least, it is an amateurish attempt. The implications of the legislation have never been thought through.

SPEECH.PARA: A general summation of this issue is that, despite the efforts of the Federal Government, there is no significant support amongst employers, or unions or in the community for a departure from the present tried and tested system of industrial relations. It is poppycock to talk about a system that is simply not going to work. All the aspects of deregistration of unions have been tried. The stand-down clause is there. By any democratic principle, one would have thought that an employer would be forced to go to an independent tribunal, establish his case as he has had to do in the past and then have a stand-down clause inserted in the award if that were necessary. But no, we are not going to do that. We are going to use the back of the axe. We are going to force unions to take a certain course of action and then use that situation to create an atmosphere such as that deliberately created in the Lowe by-election and the Victorian state election. The idea is that the unions will become so incensed that they will stand up and take the Government on.

One remarkable feature about the anti-union legislation introduced by the Fraser Government is that the legislation, as I have indicated, has had little or no effect. In some ways this is because the legislation has been so extreme or foreign to the accepted ways of conducting industrial relations in Australia that it has found little support from or use by employers and the community. For example, the Industrial Relations Bureau has been condemned by employers and unions alike. Our friend the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), who as Minister for Industrial Relations played some part in it, also condemned it for what it was worth. It is the greatest white elephant that ever existed. Under other circumstances the members of the Bureau would be pinched for loitering. They have nothing to do. They provide no useful service in the community and ought to be got rid of. The resources being devoted to them should be channelled into developing more workable industrial relations. So much for the Industrial Relations Bureau! The secondary boycott provisions of the Trade Practices Act are largely unused and the harsh deregistration laws and the new provisions relating to secret strike ballots have not been used either. All the huffing and puffing means absolutely nothing.

The future of industrial relations in this country is at the crossroads. We are going to have some pearls of wisdom poured into our ears by the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), who lives in the lap of luxury. If he was not getting $10,000 a week in his legal practice, I will go he. Everytime he appeared in court he took a junior with him to hold his hand or help him read the brief. I issue a note of warning.

TALK.START.PARA: —A member of a compulsory union, too.

—He was a compulsory unionist. Industrial relations in this country are at the crossroads. If this legislation is implemented because of the Government' s action, the organised trade union movement will be confronted with a challenge it will be forced to take up. It will fight with all the resources available to it the attempt to weaken the trade union organisation and its capacity properly to represent wage and salary earners, to maintain the right of unions to support claims with industrial action, to ensure that the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has the unrestricted capacity to fulfil its statutory role to resolve disputes. The Opposition proposal is a challenge to the Minister . He ought to accept the amendment. A load of rubbish is contained in the legislation and it will not work. It ought to be referred back to the tripartite body. He ought to seek some advice, as do practitioners in the industrial relations area in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Groom The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not comment on the contribution that has just been made by the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Innes), because I think it speaks for itself. The need to improve industrial relations in this country is obviously one of the foremost political issues of the day. It is very good to see that the Government is at least attempting by this legislation to overcome some of the problems that exist. I want to take this opportunity to talk about some general issues which I believe relate fairly directly to the legislation which is now before the House. I refer to the situation that exists now in Tasmania. As a Tasmanian I have witnessed in recent years the great harm that has been caused to our economy, to business and to individuals as a direct result of senseless and selfish industrial disputes. I refer in particular to the numerous disputes that have affected the waterfront, which is a vital link between Tasmania and the mainland. Those disputes and disruptions have caused great harm to many businesses in Tasmania, especially on the north-west coast, which is the part of that State I represent. The disputes have cost many jobs, especially the jobs of young people.

SPEECH.PARA: One would be entitled to believe that some sections of the union movement are out to drag Tasmania down to its knees. Why do not these people wake up and realise that the economy of Tasmania is fragile and cannot stand the sort of pounding which has been received in recent times from strikes brought on by selfish unions? I acknowledge that sometimes these strikes, disputes and stoppages are aggravated by stubborn employers who are not prepared to agree to some reasonable understanding with the unions involved. As I have said, strikes and stoppages are taking a very heavy toll and are costing jobs within the community. Unless these unions, and particularly the officials involved, do something about the situation, understand the harm they are causing and begin to realise that their actions are costing jobs within the community, I do not know where we will finish up.

We recently had a maritime strike on the north-west coast of Tasmania at a cost to local firms of between $1.5m and $2m. That is money that will never be recovered. This strike is causing job insecurity and job loss in many factories, farms and other businesses in the area. Honourable members may have heard about the strike at the Savage River Mines which is now in its fourth week. With the downward trend in world iron ore prices this strike is placing that enterprise, which employs some 500 people, in real jeopardy.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is it over?

—The employees are seeking a shorter working week and additional money. The problem is that these sorts of disputes so often affect the battler. They affect the ordinary working man. They often affect the person who has been put on most recently. They certainly also adversely affect the prospects of young school leavers of obtaining jobs. So I say to these officials, especially officials who belong to the radical part of the union movement, that it is about time they woke up to themselves. Why do they not get around the community and find out what the community feels about them and the sort of tactics they are adopting at the present time?

SPEECH.PARA: I do not profess to be an expert in this area, as some of my colleagues certainly are. However, I believe there is an obligation on all of us to take an interest in and to try to understand this subject and to assist in finding the answers, if that is at all possible. As I have mentioned, there is no doubt that the union movement has acquired a bad reputation in the mind of the average citizen. This is borne out by all the surveys that have been conducted into that issue. It is important to note that frustration and irritation at unnecessary and pointless industrial disputes is not felt only by employers and people outside the union movement but also particularly by people within the union movement, by ordinary rank and file members of unions.

Employees become justifiably upset and annoyed especially when powerful small groups within a larger work force adopt the strike weapon as their first option rather than seeking to negotiate a fair result in a sensible and proper manner. It is obvious that many Australian union officials-although I acknowledge that they are probably a minority-are power hungry and use industrial disputation and conflict to advance their own selfish causes, which are sometimes, unfortunately , political causes. They often take the action to feather their own nests in some way or other. Publicity recently was given to evidence put to royal commissions. It is obvious from some of that evidence that certain union officials are doing very nicely indeed out of the system. Many workers see this happening. They have a fair idea of what is going on but they go along with it and they do nothing to stop it because they do not want to be seen as rebels or perhaps do not care very much anyway. This is probably the same sort of apathy that we see in all kinds of organisations-even the apathy we see as far as local councils and even some governments is concerned. But even if individual union members do not want to use the opportunities available to them to influence management I am pleased that at least the Government is making every effort to provide the democratic control of industrial organisations to which their members are entitled. I mention briefly secret ballots, which are proving very effective in many areas and also the opportunity for union members to obtain information about the financial affairs of their unions.

I do not suggest that all of the blame for the present level of industrial disruption within the community rests solely with those who control unions. Indeed, much of the responsibility falls directly on the shoulders of Australian management. Many managers are, unfortunately, ill equipped to deal effectively with a dispute situation or to handle an industrial relations problem so as to avoid conflict developing in the first place. The skill, ability and understanding of present day middle management-and these are the people who often must deal eyeball to eyeball with union officials and employee representatives on the shop floor-is probably less than it was 20 or 30 years ago. With the growth in the size of government and the professions and the nature of education, the efficient manager of those days is today a university graduate, a school teacher, a public servant or a member of one of the professions. In the United States, Japan and Germany the profession of management is highly regarded and is well rewarded. But in Australia, by contrast, managers have been given a much lower status in the community and their real career earnings are much less than in the professions. This has resulted, regrettably, in a lower quality of management in this country. Top management-I am speaking of people right at the top of companies and organisations within Australia-has tended to leave industrial relations to the so-called industrial relations experts within organisations. Top management has tended to deal more with financial matters, with things like fund raising, project development and so on rather than with this vital area of personal relations. I think that is a bad thing. Those who are trying to negotiate a solution often do not have sufficient authority within their organisation to make decisions or to offer satisfactory solutions or proposals without frequent reference to the more senior people within their organisation.

The kind of legislation we are now debating helps to create an improved overall framework of increased protection for individuals but it does not, of course, of itself create a better industrial climate or good industrial relations. Like many others in this chamber, I am certainly convinced that industrial relations cannot be really improved by legislation itself. It depends almost totally on effective communication between employer and employee in the work place.

This Bill supports the principle of voluntary unionism and the restructuring of unions away from a craft and occupational basis. It also provides to employers the right to stand down employees who cannot be employed usefully as a result of industrial action. The principle of freedom to choose whether or not one wants to join a union has been Liberal Party policy for many years. I am pleased to see that this step is being taken along the road to greater freedom for employees. Whether, in practice, it works effectively and does very much to improve industrial relations is yet to be seen. I know there are some who will say that these measures will threaten the more responsible and moderate unions, and will aid and abet an increase in the membership and power of the more militant unions. But the main point that must be stressed-it is an important principle-is that this legislation provides a choice without applying pressure. Hopefully, responsible people will make responsible choices.

The honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) emphasised the fact that the provisions contained in the Act have been in place for some 80 years. This legislation was first created in 1904. That seems to me to be a classic conservative argument. The honourable member for Wills is saying that because it has been in place for that length of time it is a good thing. I think community feelings and aspirations have changed since 1904. There are many people in the community who do not particularly want to join a union. Why should they not have that choice. There is no doubt that many people who are now members of unions will want to remain members of those unions. They have that choice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you got a choice about whether to be in a law institute?

—The honourable member for Melbourne Ports mentioned law institutes. Obviously lawyers have to be registered. That is appropriate. I do not think it should be compulsory that lawyers be a member of a law institute or of a bar association. I have been a member of the bar association in Tasmania and the law institute but that is by choice. I am happy to be a member of the bar association and the law institute. There will be many people who will be happy to be members of unions and I say: 'Good on them'.
—Can you practise without it?
—The important point is that they will have the choice.
—Can you practise without it?
—Are honourable members opposite against people having a choice? What is wrong with individuals having a choice?
—Answer the simple question. Can you practise without it?

—The honourable member for Wills always favours compulsion. Why should not people have a choice about being a member of a union? Are we not living in a free society? This is an important freedom to which people are entitled.
—What about your own profession, you hypocrite.
—I ask the honourable members for Wills and Melbourne Ports to cease interjecting and I ask the honourable member for Braddon to stop replying to the interjections and provoking the situation.

—I think that sometimes it is important, with all due respect to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to develop some debate on these matters and to respond to interjections. It does develop debate and that is important.
—Order! It is contrary to the Standing Orders to reply to interjections and the honourable member should know that.

—I want to take this opportunity to mention a local issue, a matter that has arisen in my own electorate. I think it is relevant to this legislation . It concerns the certificates that are issued to conscientious objectors under section 144A of the Act. I raise this issue with the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) for his consideration. I refer to the case of a log truck driver who is self-employed. He was told by the Transport Workers Union that he had to be a member of that union. He did not particularly want to be a member of that union.
—Was he self-employed?

—He was self-employed. He had a genuine conscientious objection on religious grounds. I was satisfied with his objections after being given the relevant information. He also approached the registrar in Tasmania. Clearly the registrar was satisfied that he had a genuine conscientious objection. This person applied for a certificate under section 144A of the Act but his application was rejected. The registrar said that that particular section applied only to employees, that under the legislation only employees can obtain a certificate. The registrar indicated that although this person was a conscientious objector he could not give him a certificate. I think this is a matter which has to be looked at. Quite often the grievance of an employer conscientious objector is just as great as the grievance of an employee conscientious objector. Perhaps the Minister will consider broadening section 144A and other provisions that relate to conscientious objection. Perhaps also he will give consideration to whether the provisions of the Bill before the House might be extended to provide protection for self-employed people or employers who may be employing one or two people and who have been told by some union or other than they have to join that particular union.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation also contains proposals to establish, in the long term, industrial-based unions. Clearly-the Minister made this point in his second reading speech-there certainly will not be a sudden transformation of the union movement into industry-based organisations as a direct result of this legislation, but it is a step in the right direction. It is an important step. I believe there is widespread community support for the idea that we should have industry-based unions. I know that some people think that this kind of move could lead to more undemocratic left wing union takeovers and weaken the position of the moderates. That kind of concern has to be considered in the proper context. We need to have a more rational system than exists at present. No one could sensibly argue that what we have at the moment is satisfactory. There is little merit in suggesting that the status quo should be retained. Also , the nature of the more militant unions should change under the influence of others. Rank and file members of a union may join an industry-based union because they will have now increased opportunities to participate actively within their organisations in a democratic manner.

The Australian union structure was created in the late nineteenth century when industry was largely comprised of many small enterprises. It has changed very much since then. Most people are now employed by large companies or by governments. For example, employment in half the manufacturing industry is accounted for by 200 large firms, with the other half spread over about 30,000 smaller firms. In Japan there are 70,000 unions organised on the basis of one union for each enterprise. In Germany there are only 16 unions, based on membership within a total industry. In Australia, half the unionised work foce belongs to 16 large unions and the other half belong to 280 smaller unions. This creates all kinds of pressures for the unions themselves and also for management . A large scale enterprise often will deal with 10 or more unions at its major operating plants. Some may represent only a few employees but may have great strategic power. They use that power and force a hard bargain. Sometimes they close enterprises. This leads to demarcation disputes and destructive fights between unions. There is great common sense in broadening the base and having industry-based unions. A union is more likely then to recognise that the prosperity of the industry is vital to the prosperity of the union membership and is vital even to the livelihood of union officals. This kind of development in the long term, I believe, should lead to improved co-operation and also to improved productivity. That can benefit those who are employed and also benefit those who are not employed because it will provide a few more jobs within the community.

I do not see this legislation as confrontationist, as was suggested by the honourable member for Wills. I suppose that this is a matter of philosophy. The honourable member for Wills will always attack any measure that is put forward by this Government. I am convinced that most people in the community support the sort of legislation that the Government is advancing and support the sort of legislation that the Minister has brought forward over a long period. Legislation such as this helps to improve the industrial climate that we have in this country. It is a vital issue and steps must be taken in this field. I believe that this legislation should facilitate a more reasonable and a more constructive approach to industrial relations in this country. Therefore, it deserves the full support of this House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I always feel that it is, perhaps, a little hypocritical for members of the legal profession-and the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom) is one, I am one and my friend and colleague the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher) is one-who are also members of the greatest closed shop in Australia, to talk about people having a choice. We all have qualifications to practise our chosen professions. The honourable member for Braddon talks about people having a choice. He thinks it is all right if one is a wage or salary earner. He is very concerned about one's choice, and one's choice not to belong to a union. But he knows very well that for all of his professional life, he has had no choice. He could not practise his chosen profession unless he was a member of the professional association in his State. Let me say, as one who has practised law for probably a longer period than the honourable member for Braddon, that the legal profession might be a professional association, but it is like every other professional association; it is a glorified union to protect the salary levels, charges and professional fees of its members.
—The Minister is a professional.
—I am reminded of the Minister's profession. I was mentioning only the distinguished lawyers in this place; that is why I forgot to mention the Minister.
—That is a bit unfair.
—Is it unfair? What we are talking about--
—Of course it is unfair.

—I have listened very carefully to all of this debate. I invite honourable members to go through the second reading speech of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner). Nowhere will they find in that speech or in any of the speeches thus far made the simple direct explanation of how this legislation will work in practice to reduce the level of industrial confrontation in Australia. That is the issue. What is the reason that the Parliament has to deal with this legislation? We are told by the Minister in his second reading speech, as we were told by the honourable member for Braddon, that it is a matter of Liberal Party philosophy. I ask honourable members to think about that. This bunch of farmers, this bunch of smugglers-
—And hypocritical lawyers.

—And hypocritical lawyers, have now become, God help us, philosophers . We are getting this legislation as an exercise in philosophy. We have Malcolm Fraser, the new Plato of the Liberal Party, and five-vote Viner, his apprentice.
—And you, a ten times loser.
—I will say this for the honourable member for Franklin. He never opens his mouth in this place but someone thinks he has an apple in it. He would do a lot better if he did keep an apple in it.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us get down to this philosophic exercise. That is what we are told it is. I suppose that any government is entitled to enact legislation which it regards as fundamental to its philosophy.
