However, when dealing with the tendentious issues of industrial relations and the complexities of the operations of our laws dealing with conciliation and arbitration, philosophy alone is not enough to justify critical changes in existing legislation and practice. It is not enough because these changes do not take place in the cloistered atmsphere of a philosophic tutorial at a university. They take place within the framework of an on-going society. They take place against the background of an economy which is in a downturn. They take place as we are confronted with double digit inflation, the highest number of unemployed in our history and the highest interest rates to confront home purchasers and the commercial sector-all this has occurred as a result of this Government's economic philosophy. They take place in a situation in which the average wage and salary earner is battling on a daily basis to maintain his standard of living and in which he is caught up continually in attempts to obtain an increase in his living wage in order to make ends meet.

I get heartily sick and tired of the situation when honourable members opposite , when dealing with increases in salaries for judges, senior public servants and , indeed, members of Parliament, take as the criterion of movement the general cost of living. It is good enough for the fat cats in our society, but there is something that some honourable members opposite regard as essentially indecent--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about your super- annuation?

—I was part of a superannuation scheme, as is the honourable gentleman. There are many Liberal parliamentarians in Victoria about to claim larger superannuation entitlements than I have ever claimed, and not one of them will be giving it back. Not one of them will be saying, 'I think that you are giving me too much money. It ought to be paid on the basis of productivity.' If it were paid on that basis, they would starve.

SPEECH.PARA: What we get in this Government's approach is yet again an exercise in the double standards that permeate continually and flow through the House when honourable members on the Government side talk about the living standards of the average Australian worker and the average Australian trade unionist. The average trade unionist has as much right to his slice of the economic pie as has any other sector of the community. Let us look at the way in which the average worker has been able to improve his living conditions in the history of this nation's development. No one in the House, of whatever view, and no matter how reactionary the attitude of honourable members opposite is, can doubt that the undeniable and indisputable fact in Australian economic development is that the existing living standards of the average worker were not given to him on a plate . They came about as a result of long years of very hard struggle, organised through the trade union movement.

The trade union movement is part of our whole conciliation and arbitration process. That movement fought long and hard to achieve those conditions. It has cost average unionists million of dollars to produce the legal fabric of entitlements, whether in workers' compensation legislation and its interpretation, long service leave legislation or the basis on which people work under awards. Within the framework of the conciliation and arbitration system there are provisions, which are seldom used, concerning the rights of conscientious objectors.

If this government were concerned to reduce the level of industrial confrontation in our society, if it were concerned to make our arbitration processes really work, and if it were concerned to listen to the views of not merely the trade union movement but organised employers-there are many organised employer groups which have a much more sophisticated view of how one approaches and solves the problem of industrial relations than we are likely to find within the ranks of this Government-this House could listen with some sympathy and comprehension to amendments that come before it as a result of the processes available to the Government through its capacity to confer with, to consult and to receive the advice of both the organised employer groups and the organised trade union movement in this country.

Let us deal with just the issue of voluntary unionism. Where in the second reading speech of the Minister for Industrial Relations, where in the speeches of the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Chapman) and the honourable member for Braddon, do we see a single reference to the effect: 'Because we have been requested by responsible employer organisations to deal with the question of voluntary unionism, we feel compelled to give their views and to provide an opportunity for reaction to their proposals. That is why we have introduced this legislation'?

That would not be an unreasonable proposition, but where is it? Does the Minister say, does the honourable member for Braddon say, does the honourable member for Kingston say-indeed, does any spokesman on that side of the House say -that any single responsible employer group in Australia with any experience at all in industrial relations has asked this Government to produce legislation in this form? Of course, one is greeted with silence because honourable members opposite know that when this matter was raised at the most senior level of industrial advice available to the Minister-employers and unions were equally represented on this occasion-and when these proposals were thrown on the table as a result of the philosophy of the Government the employers sat mute and slightly horrified. The employers knew, as the trade union movement knew-as any experienced industrial advocate knows-that this legislation was yet another formula for industrial disaster and industrial confrontation. That is what it will produce. The average Australian wants a lessening in the level of confrontation. No Australian, and no Australian unionist, would not prefer to maintain his standard of living or to negotiate for improved living conditions through an orderly process of conciliation and arbitration rather than by the drag down, knock-out situations which often arise just because of the general way in which our society operates.

That is why, when we ask ourselves the reasons for this legislation, when we ask ourselves what its purpose is, what groups it is supposed to benefit and who asked for it, that we are greeted with silence and told it is a matter of philosophy. In my view, that is no basis for introducing such legislation. The honourable member for Braddon is entitled to his philosophy, I do not object to that. However, I object to his hypocrisy. We have looked at the question of preference to unionists and unions as contained in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. It has been there since 1904. My colleague the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) referred to section 47 of the Act, which is the basis upon which that preference provision can be written into an award, and he pointed out quite properly that it is only exercised by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission when it is necessary to prevent an industrial dispute, to secure industrial peace, to secure the effectiveness of an award or to secure the welfare of society. It has been in place since 1904.

I challenge the Minister or any spokesman on the Government side to indicate a single occasion since 1904 when that provision has been wrongfully used or misused by the Commission. The Government is not taking the power away from the trade union movement; the legislative amendment is designed to take the power away from the Commission. Can it be said that this is an excessive power? Can it be argued that this is a power which has been used wantonly, without justification, by the Commission; that the Commission, when exercising the power , was thoroughly misconceived in regard to its application? We are told in an article in the Australian Trade Union by Mr M. Wright, entitled 'Union Preferences and Closed Shops', that these provisions are not included in all Federal awards. Wright has estimated that only 279 out of some 800 Federal awards contain preference provisions. So, there is no record of wrong use or of excessive use and there is no record of any request from a responsible employer organisation saying that, since it was introduced in 1904, it is time that we changed this provision. What does it come down to? It is a matter of philosophy.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.

—The honourable member might say it is right but I say to him that those who are experienced in industrial affairs, both on the side of the trade union movement and on the side of employers, and indeed this Parliament, would be told by the Commission, if it could speak, that industrial disputes will not be lessened if this section is taken away but another occasion for further industrial confrontation will be created. If that is the logical consequence of the Government's philosophy, I ask whether that is the social consequence that the honourable member for Braddon wants to produce in Tasmania. Is it the social consequence that this Government desires in terms of its industrial relations approach?

SPEECH.PARA: Non-union members do have rights. No one will argue with that. But I have yet to meet the non-union member, the man of principle, who when there is an increase in the award wage says: 'No, I will not take it'. I have yet to meet the widow of a non-union member, whose husband has died on the job, who says: ' Look, I do not want to pursue my workers compensation claim because that right was gained as a result of exercises by the trade union movement, by the expenditure of millions of dollars in every workers compensation tribunal in the land and before every appellate court including the Privy Council'. I have yet to meet the non-unionist who says: 'Look, because of my attitude towards trade unions, although I recognise that they won in my industry long service leave entitlements I will not take them'.

It is time in Australian society that we examined the basis of our industrial legal system. We need to understand that the conciliation and arbitration process rests on two principles, that is, that there will be organised employer groups and there will be organised worker groups. The process of conciliation and arbitration can work and can survive only as long as Australian workers are members of unions and those unions are registered under the Act. When one strikes at the fabric of that concept one strikes at the whole process of conciliation and arbitration itself and exposes this community to potentially great industrial turbulence. That is what this legislation is designed to do. It is false and it is hypocritical. It will be rejected by the trade union movement and it is being rejected by responsible employer organisations. If this Government had any sense of decency and honour it would withdraw this legislation now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address attention to something that has not received much attention so far in this debate. I refer to the subject of industry-based unions. We are talking about a variety of complex issues. This is one that I believe to be exceedingly important to the future of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Before coming to that question I wish to make one or two points by way of introduction. It is sometimes suggested on the other side that no one on this side has any sympathy whatsoever for trade unions, that no one here has had any direct experience with the trade union movement. For my part, I have always had the view-it is one that I have expressed and propose to express again-that trade unions are a part of the fabric of this country; that they have contributed greatly to the lives of their members and that they will remain a part of the fabric of this country. I add that I have been fortunate enough, as a lawyer-I realise that the very existence of lawyers in these halls arouses in the breasts of some a great feeling of animosity-to act for three of the five largest trade unions in this country. I refer to the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Association, which is I believe the nation's second largest union, to the Australian Workers Union, which is the oldest union in this country, and to the Federated Clerks Union of Australia. My political views were well known at the time. Indeed, very recently-I have been to court precisely three times since I entered this House-I was asked by the Federated Clerks Union if I would appear for it. I said I would and went back before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in a case in which the union was seeking an award in a particular industry.

I might add that I was fortunate enough to meet Mr Dolan, who, on one occasion when he was Vice President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, instructed me in a case on behalf of the Electrical Trades Union of Australia. It was a small, technical case, but all of this adds to one's knowledge, so I regard myself as very fortunate to have had firsthand experience of working with trade union leaders and coming to understand some of the considerable pressures under which they operate, the very great difficulties that they have to encounter- difficulties which in no small measure are contributed to by the very complex system of laws that we have in this country.

That having been said, one must acknowledge that one of the problems we face in Australia is the existing structure of the trade union movement. This is no one' s fault. It just happens to be the way in which trade unions have grown over a long period. I believe that view is common to both the Government and the Opposition that industry-based unions would be an improvement-some would say a vast improvement-on what we have at present. Stripped of all political rhetoric, the real differences between the Government and the Opposition on the subject of industry-based unions would appear to be twofold. The first concerns the level of real commitment to the concept of industry-based unions. The second concerns how best to go about putting such unions on the industrial map of this country.

If one looks at the constitution of the ACTU, which sets out its objectives, one sees that one of those objectives is the socialisation of industry. If one then turns to the methods by which this is to be achieved-this is important because it illustrates the very way in which the ACTU approaches the subject of industry-based unions-one finds that they include:
The closer organisation of the workers by:
(a) The development of the trade union movement towards an industrial basis
(c) Amalgamation of unions where practicable to establish one union in each industry or sector.

The ills of the present system are well known. They were set out by the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) in a paper that he delivered recently to the Institute of Chartered Accountants in Australia. I have read the paper and much that he said I agree with, although there are points on which we have obvious disagreement. At page 19 of the paper, from which I propose to quote because it describes the present situation, he states:

Although we also have a smattering of general and industry-based unions, our unions are essentially based on trade or craft divisions. This usually means that more than one union will be functioning in an industry or a company and that a single union will often encompass a number of firms or industries. This has been a constant source of inter-union conflict in the form of demarcation disputes (about which union membership will perform certain work) and jurisdictional wrangles over coverage of workers in a firm or industry. Such needless examples of disputation have often occurred in critical areas of the economy-the most notable recent examples being the dispute between the Builders' Labourers' Federation and the Federated Ironworkers' Association over work carried out on important construction sites, and the membership wrangle between the WWF and other unions operating on the waterfront.
In the same address, with reference to the legislative proposal-which had not been put in concrete form-foreshadowing industry-based unions, he said:
The encouragement of industrial unions is to be commended.
He also said:
The proposed legislation would also mean that amalgamation proposals which do not lead directly to industry-based unions would still be subject to the restrictive provisions currently operating.
This is an unacceptable approach, since other forms of general union amalgamation may be just as conducive to greater rationality in the industrial structure and improved industrial relations.

What the honourable member did not do was elaborate on what he had in mind. He gave us no clue as to what means were to be adopted, as to how other forms of general amalgamation of existing unions could be just a conducive to a more rational industrial structure. I might suggest two reasons as an explanation of this somewhat uncharacteristic silence on the part of the honourable member. In the first place I ask: What is the real level of commitment of the Opposition to industry-based unions? In this area the Opposition runs headlong into certain facts of political life. The Australian Labor Party, as the only Australian political party that is affiliated with unions, is, by the very fact of that affiliation, limited as to the political action that it can take in matters which affect unions. The ACTU consitution speaks of amalgamations, where practicable, to establish industry unions. It says nothing of establishing industry-based unions by means other than amalgamation. Certainly, it says nothing of employing means that may affect the structure and powers of existing unions. I do not say that in any critical sense but that is simply the position under the constitution of the ACTU as it stands.

One can understand that, from the Opposition's point of view, actions that might disturb existing unions and the distribution of power within the union movement and the Australian Labor Party could well involve high political risks for members of the party who espoused such actions. Thus, there is first a political reason to be somewhat disinclined to take action that will change the structure of the union movement, for the purpose of achieving a different basis. Secondly, and perhaps more fundamentally, there is the question of the existing structure. As the honourable member must know, amalgamations under the existing structure can only achieve larger unions. They cannot result in any greater rationality of that industrial structure. This, as I say, results from the actual structure of the unions. Let us look at that structure and in particular two areas of it. Let us consider first the number of trade unions and the distribution of membership between them. Let us consider secondly the industry or job coverage.

We have in Australia-I am quoting the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures for December 1980-316 reporting unions with 2,943,900 members. Of that number 14 unions each with 50,000 or more members accounted for 44.2 per cent of total membership; 41 unions with 21,000 or more members accounted for 75.6 per cent of total membership. At the bottom end of the scale, 36 unions with 100 or fewer members accounted for a minuscule 0.1 per cent of total membership.

What is the industry coverage, that is, the coverage which each union has and in which it can operate? I refer here specifically to federally registered unions. As is known, in the infancy of the union movement what happened was that men and women got together to form a union, and it was usually formed to protect a particular calling, to protect fairly narrowly defined industrial interests. For example, I think the Australian Workers Union was originally formed to protect the rights of shearers and to advance their industrial interests. But with the passage of time, improved communications, a heightened sense of national identity, growth and diversification in traditional industries, the formation of entirely new industries and the proliferation of new technologies, so unions themselves grew and changed. Frequently, a union which was formed to protect clearly defined interests, such as the interests of shearers, would over the years find its industrial coverage greatly enlarged so as to include members in varied, separate and disparate industries scattered throughout Australia.

This can be well illustrated by looking at the constitutional industrial coverage for two unions-the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union, the largest union in this country, and the Federated Engine Drivers and Firemen's Association of Australia, which has a de facto living together arrangement with the AMWSU. Both of those unions, I understand, intend at some stage in the future to amalgamate. Let me cite the industry coverage of one of those unions, the AMWSU. I summarise what is said in Huntley's excellent book Inside Australia 's Top 100 Unions. The AMWSU itself came out of a number of amalgamations. It has members in all types of engineering, including the steel industry, ship building and repair, rolling stock manufacture, structural steel, the lift industry, air conditioning and ventilation, cannister making, rail and road transport, plastics, space tracking, mining, aircraft and National Roads and Motorists Association road maintenance mechanics. It has members in every industry where there are machines. If one looks at the industrial coverage of the FEDFA, which emerged out of the mining actvities in the late nineteenth century, one finds just as varied a situation. It covers boiler/firemen, various classes of stationary engine drivers including refrigeration, steam and turbine engine drivers, all classes of crane drivers, all classes of earthmoving equipment drivers, oil refinery operatives, locomotive engine drivers in private industry and drivers of heavy equipment in open-cut coal mines and those in other mining activities.

An amalgamation between those two unions could produce only one thing-a larger union. Could it be seriously suggested that an amalgamation between those two unions would, to use the words of the honourable member for Wills, produce greater rationality in the industrial structure and improve industrial relations ? The answer is that it could not. It could not because of the structural problems that the unions face. And certainly if one looks at the history of the AMWSU over the last few years one would find no reason for thinking that it, as a product of amalgamations, is a union whose structure is conducive to greater industrial peace, and it is industrial peace that we are here concerned with.

The easy amalgamation of unions-and that is a constant theme of the Opposition- would be more likely to compound existing problems by producing larger unions with even more diverse coverage and make it more difficult in the future to rationalise the structure of Australian trade unions. To use an analogy, if you have a box in which you have an apple and a pear and you add an orange, a cauliflower and a cabbage, you do not get a different fruit; you have a box which has more fruit and vegetables in it. That is a problem with easier amalgamations or with amalgamations which do not take into consideration structural change.

How then are we to produce a system of industry-based unions? I think there are only two ways. How, for example, can we get an industry-based union for the waterfront industry or the automobile industry? The question of the definition of industry-this has been raised by the honourable member for Wills-is of course sensibly left to regulation because of the complexity of defining the industries or group of industries for the purposes of identification as a single industry such as the waterfront industry or the automobile industry.

There are really only two ways, as I have said, to produce a system of industry -based unions. The first is by the means proposed in the Bill to amend the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. Let me say that at best it will be a slow road . There cannot be any doubt about that. But it does provide a means, which employees can resort to or ignore as they wish, for the formation of industry- based unions. The other means of forming industry-based unions is to use the kind of mechanism which is to be found in section 142A of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. Broadly stated, that section permits the Commission, if it thinks it is in the public interest to do so, to give a union a right of exclusive representation of employees-exclusive, I emphasise, from the rights of other organisations. As presently framed, section 142A is too narrow to be used to facilitate the formation of industry-based unions. But amendments could be made to it to introduce into the Commission power to form, from existing unions, industry-based unions. It is obvious that such a power would need to be exercised with the greatest of care. It is also obvious that in the exercise of such a power adjustments in a wide range of matters between the unions affected would need to be made, including of course membership and industry coverage.

I do not underestimate the difficulties that would face the Commission if it were to have the sort of power that I have described-a power which should, of course, be exercisable in the public interest and in the interests of employees; a power to create industry-based unions out of existing unions. But to place that power in the Commission would have the benefit of providing a means for the creation of industry-based unions under the supervision of an independent and impartial body.

Let me emphasise that no one is to blame for the present state of affairs. But at some stage we have to move towards a restructuring of unions in Australia. It is perfectly ludicrous that we should have the number of unions that we have with the disparity in size, in coverage and in membership-such as a union with 160,000 members as compared with a number of unions with fewer than 100 members. I do not think anyone in this House disputes that statement but unless we start to make a move towards a restructuring of unions-towards greater rationality, towards forming unions to cover an entire industry, which would work against demarcation disputes and probably put an end to them, which would make industry negotiations very much simpler-we are simply postponing for later generations, for later parliaments, the whole problem of the restructuring of the Australian union movement. That is a subject in which we all have a common interest. It is in the common interest of us all to improve the union structure and by that means to put in place a better basis for industrial relations and reduced industrial conflict. We will never have a perfect world but we need to move towards something better.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Four honourable members opposite preceded me in this debate. Three of them are lawyers. It is indeed a great honour for me, having a humble working class background, to follow such erudite gentlemen who were not only born to rule but also trained to rule us. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner), who introduced the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill, is a barrister. The honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom) is a lawyer. The honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), who preceded me, is a barrister also. They all belong to a fraternity, a union, a very closed shop-a law institute-which achieved tremendous pay for them. They receive $1,000 a day- not a month or a week but a day. Not only is their pay good but also their conditions are excellent. They ought to know something about unionism. They do not have to dirty their hands. They start work at 9 o'clock or 10 o'clock in the morning and have a two-hour lunch break, with an excellent imported Rhine riesling or Bordeaux red.

SPEECH.PARA: Wait until I tell my mates in the factories or on the railways where I used to work how these eminent and learned colleagues of mine wish to tell them, the Australian workers, how to conduct their affairs! When they hear that they will be so honoured and awestruck that they will all resign from their union branches , ask the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to deregister their unions, and send deputations to their bosses to request that they be stood down! I am sure they would do that but for their natural suspicion that the erudite gentlemen opposite are telling them what to do, not in the interest of workers and employees, not in the public interest or the interest of employers, but for some ulterior motive which I will explain in a minute. By now it will be obvious to everybody that whenever this Government is in trouble it resorts to union bashing to divert the attention of the people from its inability to manage the country's economy.

The Bill before us serves exactly such a purpose. Of course, whenever the present Minister for Industrial Relations is in trouble-that is more the rule than the exception; he has been in so much trouble lately that we do not know whether he will still be the Minister in a week to two-he comes up with some amendments to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. This Act has been amended over 70 times. This is the sixteenth amendment which has been introduced since this Government has been in office. The number of times that the Fraser Government has amended the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, without succeeding in reducing industrial disputation, proves to us the futility of the Government' s attempts to interfere with the legitimate and traditional practice of conciliation and arbitration. Let us not forget that the real aim of the Fraser Government is to provoke industrial disputes so that it can blame the unions for the economic chaos caused by its policies. The Bill before us is no exception. It is not designed to reduce industrial disputation but to create industrial chaos.

The Bill is divided into four sections: Firstly, voluntary unionism; secondly, the stand down of employees; thirdly, the creation of industry unions; and, fourthly, deregistration. There are a couple of minor window dressing amendments dealing with the terms of office of union officials, casual vacancies and financial assistance. Except for these minor items the four major parts of the Bill have the effect of reducing the power of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, of taking matters out of its hands and of introducing anarchy and confrontation into industrial relations.

Firstly, I wish to deal with so-called voluntary unionism. The removal of the power of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to award preference is a clear departure from historical encouragement of orderly unionism. Everybody who has had any experience in industrial relations knows well that a modern industrial society cannot exist without the trade unions. Putting this in simple terms, so that even the Minister for Industrial Relations can understand it, if there were no trade unions-no employee organisations-there would be no one with whom the employers could negotiate. The Commission knows, the employers know and the workers know that without trade unions our economic system would not be able to function. The workers and their organisations are as much a part of the capitalist system as are the employers. The smashing of trade unions will not necessarily increase the profits of employers as the simple-minded members opposite presume. On the contrary, it will lead to industrial anarchy and will inflict great losses on employers and employees alike. It is beyond doubt that the workers' organisations contribute to the industrial equilibrium and that the Commission's function is to reduce industrial disputation.

Why is it then that this Minister and this Government wish to discourage unionism and reduce the power of the Commission? The only argument that the Minister and honourable members opposite can produce in relation to this section of the legislation is that they are safeguarding some sacred right of an individual to refuse to join a union. They forget that many more individuals who are members of a union have the same sacred right to refuse to work with a scabbing individual. The Minister wants to defend the right of one individual against the rights of many individuals. He knows very well that if this Bill is passed-I hope that it will not be-the number of industrial disputes will increase. In addition, the Minister proposes to remove the power of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to deal with such disputes and wishes to place such matters in the jurisdiction of the Federal Court of Australia. The Minister wants scabs or provacateurs to sue unions or employers, or both, for damages in cases where employers prefer to employ unionists or where unionists, quite frankly, refuse to work with scabs.

The Minister has talked about redress against employees and unions but he knows that the industrial reality will be that such action will result in prolonged and unsolvable industrial disputes with consequent damage to the nation's economy. After introducing such an inane Bill, it is no wonder that the Minister could not muster more than six votes in his own party. It is true that he received only five votes but I give him six as I know his own vote was commanded elsewhere by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). I wonder who are the five members opposite who support this Minister. They are not sitting behind him in this chamber. Let me briefly deal with the other provisions contained in this Bill. The Bill introduces new stand-down provisions in case of strikes or bans. The Minister said in his second reading speech:
The decision to stand-down will be the decision of the employer according to the circumstances with which he is faced.

This means that employers will be able to stand down employees at any time during a dispute, even when such dispute has been provoked by management, without referring the matter to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. This is also a retrograde step as it removes the Commission from its function of conciliation and enables management to exacerbate, prolong and extend disputes and starve workers into submission. The present Act has adequate provisions whereby employers can apply for stand-down provisions to be inserted into awards . This amendment is unnecessary. It will also provoke disputes and prolong and widen existing ones. It is not acceptable to the trade union movement as it gives complete freedom to employers to stand down workers capriciously. In view of the fact that nearly 50 per cent of industrial disputes is caused by management, it is a paradox to offer the same management the absolute rights of stand-downs.

This proposal, as with the previous one, is not designed to assist speedy resolution of industrial disputes. It is designed to widen them. Government members, when speaking overseas, often point to the fact that our rate of industrial disputes and their duration compare favourably with other industrialised countries; yet back home they resort to union bashing which is their usual political tactic. The Minister for Industrial Relations, when speaking recently to employers, freely admitted that nearly half of industrial disputes are caused by management. If we add to this the number of disputes caused by demands for adherence to safety regulations or protection of workers' health, demarcation disputes, just wage demands and other reasons we find that very few disputes are caused by some insatiable greed by unionists, as the Minister would like the Australian public to believe.

Now let us look at the third matter that has been introduced-the establishment of industry unions. The honourable member for North Sydney, who preceded me in this debate, spoke at length about this. But he somehow missed one point-that of the historical background of unionism in Australia. We cannot create unions by ministerial edict or by lawyers' suggestions. Creation of unions is an historical process; that was the point that was missed. This part of the legislation seems to be a revised version of the grand idea of the Minister to establish enterprise unions, an inane notion which was aborted before it hit the deck. Judging from the Minister's performance, it will not be long before he is aborted, too-by the Cabinet.

To get back to industry unions, institutions in our society such as trade unions are not created by Ministers, nor by the member for North Sydney who preceded me, but are the result of historical development. Because Australian trade unions followed the pattern of British trade unions, which developed along the line of craft unions, Australia today has about 300 unions. Even though the honourable member for North Sydney said that the Australian Labor Party or the unions are opposed to upsetting some political balance in the unions, that is not correct. It is obvious that the reduction in the number of unions is desirable. Amalgamation of unions, where there is community of interest, should be facilitated. This is the view of trade unionists. It is the view of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. However, the Bill does not provide for that. It wants to foist on to the trade unions-an institution that grew out of our history and developed on the basis of free association of workers-a structure which is alien to them. I have to repeat that time and again so that even the Minister for Industrial Relations can understand that we cannot by legislation force the Australian trade unions into acceptance of new structures.

But that is not the only thing that is wrong with the Minister's proposal. The new concept of industry unions will not reduce the number of unions. On the contrary, it will create new unions, more unions. In addition it will increase disruptions. It will cut across historical and peaceful development of trade unionism and, of course, it will be unacceptable to the Australian workers. As members opposite are somewhat slow, I reiterate that a reduction in the number of unions in Australia can be achieved only through mergers between unions and voluntary amalgamation of unions where there is a community of interest. This can be brought about only by discussion of membership and free negotiation and not by introduction of new unions by the Minister.

If ever there was a recipe for disaster in industrial disputation, this Bill certainly is such a recipe. The Government has yet to learn that industrial relations cannot be managed by the bludgeon of legislation but has to be approached with common sense and with a spirit of conciliation. Of course, this Government and this Minister do not want industrial peace. It would not suit their sinister purposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —What sinister purposes?

—Their sinister purposes are to create disruption and to divert people's attention away from the Government's inability to manage the economy. That is what the Government wants to achieve and that is what it tried to do in Victoria but the Victorian people gave their answer. In every other field members opposite advocate less government interference and small government yet they want to amend the Conciliation and Arbitration Act for the seventy-seventh time since 1904. It was previously amended at the rate of once a year, but under the Fraser Government it is being amended three times a year.

SPEECH.PARA: Since a number of my coleagues want to speak, I will cut short my remarks. In conclusion, let me illustrate that I am not alone in accusing the Fraser Government of intrusion and interference in the industrial relations field with the aim to create chaos. I quote from a speech by the former Minister for Industrial Relations, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). At page 2829 of Hansard of 28 May 1981 he stated:
The Conciliation and Arbitration Act has been amended over 70 times since its enactment in 1904-14 times under the present Government.
That was last year. He continued:

I have to say that this represents lack of direction and lack of consensus, over many years on direction over time and the fallibility of legislation. This Act has surely reached saturation point. The cumulative effect of legislation on industrial relations is largely a matter of conjecture and often ill-informed assumption. There is a need for the Act to be simplified into a useful tool for the practitioner in industrial relations-not complicated by further legislation. Proliferation of legislation is, after all, a form of so-called big government that must be reduced. Problems cannot be consigned wholesale for government solution; nor should government unnecessarily intrude. Industrial problems should mainly be resolved by those most involved. Government must create a background by making its views clear and acting only if necessary to reconcile competing interests-including the public interest. Legislation should be undertaken only if it is necessary to ensure the outcome and there is confidence that it will do this and only this.

If that is not an indictment of this Government's record in industrial relations , and an indictment of this incompetent Minister's record, I do not know what is . This Bill is the Minister's swan-song. It is an ugly composition and a song very much out of tune with the community and the electorate. It was no surprise that this Bill was introduced here by the Minister with great enthusiasm some 10 days before the Victorian elections as part of a union-bashing exercise. It is pursued now with somewhat dampened zeal by members opposite who are stunned by the verdict of the Victorian people.

I advise the honourable gentlemen opposite to stop this cheap gimmick of union bashing and to apply themselves instead to the economic management of this country and to do what they were elected to do and on which they have failed so miserably. No amount of union bashing will detract the attention of the Australian people from the bleak economic conditions brought about by the Fraser Government. It will be in this field that the Fraser Government will be judged by the people, found guilty and removed from office at the next elections, whenever they are held.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the beginning of his contribution to this debate my colleague the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom) made the point that the state of industrial relations in Australia today is probably the most difficult matter that this country has to deal with. I fully agree with that conclusion by my colleague. My view is that the state of industrial relations in Australia is perhaps the greatest economic and social scourge with which we have to deal in this country. It is a disgusting commentary, or reflection on all of those people who dare to call themselves practitioners or participants in the industrial relations scene. Anybody-be they honourable members on either side of this House, people outside this House, in industry or unions-who dares to say that the industrial scene in Australia is working well is trying to deceive himself, others around him and people in the community generally. It is a disgusting commentary on this Parliament, on unions and on employers that our country is being torn to pieces because our industrial relations system is simply not working properly. For honourable members on the opposite side of this chamber to claim that the problem is being caused wholly and solely either because of legislation passed by this Government or because of the attitudes of employers or honourable members on this side of the House is to deceive themselves and to try to deceive the people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem of industrial relations pervades the whole of our community. If my friends on the opposite side of the chamber wish to contribute in any meaningful way to solving that problem I urge them to extend their minds above party political dogma and to think of Australia instead of thinking of pre-selections within their party. Another point that has come through to me in the course of this debate was spurred on by a comment by the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent) when he mentioned the legal qualifications of my colleagues the honourable member for Braddon and the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender). I was reminded of the legal qualifications of the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) and the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding), both of whom have participated in this debate.

It seems to me that one of the main problems with industrial relations in this country at the moment is that industrial policy, industrial relations as such, is being determined by lawyers under the law. That means that industrial relations must of its very nature be a combative process, that there must be gladiators with drawn swords, that at no stage through the industrial relations procedures can there be harmony. The fact that there may be harmony of opinion between employers and employees does not seem to enter into the debate at any stage. Surely the interests of employers must be paralleled with the interests of employees. If a company goes out of business it cannot provide any jobs. If a company is not profitable it cannot provide better pay and conditions for its workers. Obviously, the objectives of both the workers and employers must be common. However, at no stage in the industrial relations procedures under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act-be it in the court, before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, or at any other stage-is that harmony of objectives ever recognised. It is about time it was. But it will not be recognised while the processes of industrial relations are determined by law. Inherent in that process of law is that there must be opposite sides and that the participants and parties under the law must be combative.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should have been a detective.

—I remind my friend from Melbourne that perhaps the best way of resolving our industrial problems at the moment is to create a more harmonious climate between employers and employees. Surely the best place to resolve disputes is at the point where those disputes occur and that is at the work face level. It is not before the Commission; it is not before an arbitrator. It is not worked out third-hand between lawyers who represent different parties. The best way to resolve disputes is between the parties themselves, the employer or his foreman and the people who are working at the shop floor level. That means a more harmonious working relationship between the two parties. Certainly if we had a more harmonious relationship between people at the shop floor level lawyers would not get a quid when they appeared representing people. It would mean that trade union officials have more difficulty in justifying their jobs to their members, but it would certainly mean that people at the work level, employers who are trying to provide jobs, would have a much better climate in which to pursue their objectives.

SPEECH.PARA: In this respect I must admit that I am critical of large sections of management in Australia. One of the key objectives in providing a climate for better industrial relations is to provide job satisfaction for people at the work level . But that does not seem to occur to very many people in management. I do not criticise the economic management or the fact that accountants can work on calculators; that is their job. However, one of the prime functions of management should be to create a harmonious working climate within their establishments so that a business or enterprise can go about its functions and can provide both the economic and the social satisfactions that are necessary within the community. It is not a combative process. There are common objectives and it is about time we in this Parliament, unionists and management recognised those common objectives and started working towards them rather than working towards those things on which there is disagreement. Let us look at the areas on which we agree and start working towards them.

Having made those introductory comments, I turn now to the provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill, which we are debating today, and more particularly to some of the comments that have been made by earlier speakers in this debate. I remind the House that this Bill contains three major provisions: One seeks to remove from the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission the right to include preference clauses in awards; the second seeks to provide an easier mechanism for standing down employees who cannot be gainfully employed because of industrial action; and the third seeks to provide an easier mechanism to establish industry based unions. I will reverse the order of those matters. I expect that, from a philosophical point of view, there is no dispute between members of this House about the provision of industry based unions. I fully expect that members of the Opposition, together with the trade union organisation, fully support the concept of industry based unions. I am delighted that we have little dispute on that. The concept of industry based unions is far more preferable in this country to the present process of craft based unions. Obviously, if we can reduce the number of unions and can reduce those areas in which there can be conflict between unions it must go a long way towards minimising the number of industrial disputations in this country. I will not comment further on that because we agree, and I think it is good that we do agree. The mechanism for organising industry based unions and for changing the present structure of craft based unions will be difficult to determine. Certainly it will not be resolved quickly. However it is good that we are agreed and that we will progressively work towards that objective.

Let me now come to some of the more controversial aspects of this legislation which relate to preference clauses. We must recognise that on the matter of removing the option of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to include preference clauses in awards there is very largely a purely philosophical difference of opinion between honourable members on both sides of this House. It seems to me from listening to arguments from the Opposition, that the Opposition is saying that unions should have the right to request from the Arbitration Commission that a preference clause be written into an award because it is the inherent responsibility of a worker to join a union. That seems to me to be the whole basis of the argument. However what that argument excludes is the right of free choice-the right of a person to decide whether he wants to join a union.

The argument seems to be that if a person wants to work he joins a union but if he does not want to work there is no necessity for him to do so. I cannot agree with that philosophical argument, because a fundamental basis of our whole Western democracy is that people must have a right of free choice and an option under law to pursue their free choice regardless of the field of society or economics involved. When we take away the right of people to exercise a free choice we take away part of our democracy. On that basis I cannot support the arguments of the Opposition.

I was intrigued by some of the arguments presented by the honourable member for Wills. I commend the honourable member for the homework he has done. But he spent much of his time explaining to the House that provision for preference clauses was incorporated in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act in 1904. He argued that because that provision had been in the legislation for almost 80 years it should remain. I must admit that I cannot follow the logic. That argument ignores the fact that times change, that economic circumstances change, that the thinking of people changes and therefore the law should reflect those changes. I am sure that the honourable member for Wills and others on the other side of the chamber would agree that the economic conditions in Australia and the social conditions in Australia are totally different now from what they were in 1904. That may have been an appropriate provision in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act in 1904. But if circumstances have changed, it should be removed . I quite agree with that proposition.

The honourable member for Wills and, I believe, other Opposition speakers made the point that the removal of this provision from the Conciliation and Arbitration Act would lead to widespread industrial disputation. The logic seems to be that we will have less industrial disputation if we leave that provision in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. Very obviously no account has been taken of the decisions given recently by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to allow the Waterside Workers Federation preference in its award. Already we have been given notice by other unions which represent workers on the waterfront that there will be widespread industrial disputation because that one union has been given a preference clause. If waterfront unions naturally engage in widespread industrial disputation because the Commission has allowed a preference clause in one award-and one logically could expect that this would happen in other areas-how can the claim be made that the removal of this provision will lead to industrial disputation? Obviously the provision will lead to widespread industrial disputation if it remains in the Act and is used by the Commission. I think very obviously our whole democracy, our whole way of life, demands that people should have the right of free choice. They should have the right to exercise that free choice as their conscience determines, not as any overbearing bureaucratic organisation determines they should act.

Let me briefly comment on the stand-down provisions that have been included in this Bill. I would like to make reference to a comment by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) when introducing this legislation. The Minister, in his second reading speech, said:

If unions are to have, as a basic principle, the right to strike then it is surely not unreasonable for employers to have at their individual disposal, the right to protect their commercial interests in circumstances where they are put at risk by union action.

I think any logical, thinking person would agree with the Minister's conclusion and not with the Opposition's conclusion on this matter. We are saying that at the moment industrial relations are going to be determined under the process of law. Very obviously, if we have a law, that law has to be fair and impartial to all parties. We cannot have one law for one group of people and a totally different and conflicting law for another group. Such a proposition is illogical and cannot work. The Minister is saying: 'Let us have a law, let us make it simple and let us make it uniform for all people. If we are going to have that law, let us make it impartial so that everybody must comply under that law'. What the Opposition and what the trade union movement are saying is: 'We do not care two hoots what law you have got. We will comply with the law only when it suits us. But at the same time we insist that everbody else under that law must be bound responsible to that law'. That sort of principle cannot operate in Australia or in any other democratic society. It may operate in places where the law can be enforced at the point of a gun. But it will not operate in a free democratic society.

We on this side of the House agree that organised workers, through their trade unions, should have the right under a free democracy to withdraw their labour if that is what they democratically choose to do. We support and uphold that principle. At the same time the same privilege must be extended to the employer. If it is not we are not being fair and reasonable. The employer must have the same rights as the employee. If for reasons of industrial disputation people at a workface level decide voluntarily to withdraw their labour for whatever reason they determine by democratic means, that is fair enough. But the employer must have the same right in protecting his interests to stand down other employees who cannot be gainfully employed. It seems to me that the philosophy of the Opposition in this matter is that money paid to employees is in fact not the rightful property of the employer but some sort of public property. That philosophy is wrong, because money to be used for wages is the legal property of the employer. If that money were stolen from the employer the person who stole it could be pursued under criminal law. The Opposition is saying that in some mystical way the employees have a right to the money of the employer whether they work for it or not. That proposition cannot be held up by any logical commonsense argument. Obviously the employer has an obligation to pay his employees for the work that they do. But if they do not work he should have no obligation to pay. That is only logical and commonsense.

The provisions which have been introduced by the Minister must be supported by any logical, commonsense, thinking Australian. The provisions are logical and can stand up to commonsense argument. This Parliament should support these measures. I believe that the whole Australian community will do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Mr S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address myself to two provisions in this legislation. Firstly, I want to deal with the provisions which allegedly allow an employee the right to join or not join a union and remove from the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission jurisdiction to award preference to unionists. I also wish to refer to the other area of the Bill which seeks to provide employers with the direct right to stand down employees who allegedly cannot be usefully employed because of the effects of industrial action by other employees of the same employer or, for that matter, any other employer. Clause 6 of this Bill is designed to give the employer the power to stand down workers who, it is claimed, are not able to be usefully employed as a result of industrial action. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) states that he is concerned for the employer whose operation is affected by strike action, who has no power to resort to industrial action and who is affected by industrial action because his wage bill is mounting.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) also supported this position. He took it a step further last month when he suggested that the aim of the proposal was the protection of employers who were not involved in industrial disputes but whose financial position was affected by strikes. Are workers who face the possibility of being stood down not seen by the Government as individuals too, individuals whose rights the Government is claiming to protect in other sections of this Bill? What effect does this have on the concept of a better balance of powers and on the rights and duties of employers and employees that the Minister for Industrial Relations is crowing about? Let me answer that question. In this Bill the balance of power is being handed to the employer whose rights to make a profit seem, according to the rationale of this Government, to make him more worthy of protection than the worker. That this is the way this Government interprets individual rights can be confirmed when one asks the question: Who will decide whether workers are able to be usefully employed when a firm is affected by industrial action? This legislation proposes to take the power of determining whether a stand-down clause is justified, in the case of a strike, away from the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and to give employers the automatic right to stand down workers as they see fit.

The proposed new section 33B (1) to (12) is the most broadly based power in relation to stand-downs ever handed to employers in this country without recourse to a federal or State court. It provides employers with direct stand- down rights over employees who allegedly cannot be employed usefully because of industrial action. It refers not only to industrial action taken by members of the same union, perhaps working in the same firm, but also to action taken by members of the same union outside that firm and, indeed, by members of any union involved in any industry even remotely linked with the employer in question. Nothing could be more calculated to increase disputation. Workers who are not involved in such a dispute and who take no part in the decision to strike will most bitterly resent being stood down at immediate notice when they are not involved in a strike or have had no part in the decision to take that strike.

This Bill gives the employer power to initiate or provoke industrial disputes at times when a temporary closure of his or her firm would offset inefficiencies in the management of that firm. Employers will have the power to stand down workers for any period, as long as the strike is maintained. Under existing stand-down regulations workers are unable to be stood down for less than one working day. In addition, the existing stand-down clauses in industrial awards will become invalid because they apparently conflict with the terms of this legislation. Furthermore, the Commission will have no future power to insert stand-down clauses in awards. In other words, the body whose name implies that it was established to ensure that industrial disputes are waged and settled fairly is being stripped of the power to prevent employers from imposing short, sharp, shock tactics on workers in terms of removing them from and disrupting their labour for small but important periods. This provision abolishes the ability of that body to protect workers against the tactics of employers whose main aim could be to protect their own profit margins.

This Bill does not simply protect innocent individual employers who may be unduly affected by strikes. It is designed also to protect major corporations and to allow them to stand down workers, perhaps to compensate for managerial blunders by temporarily shedding labour. This Bill directly sanctions the persecution of people who may be innocent third parties, while employers are also given power to provoke or to sustain industrial battles to suit their own economic positions or their own industrial relations policies. For the duration of any dispute, the employer has the power under proposed new section 33B automatically to stand down all unionised employees whom the employer claims cannot be usefully employed. In the case of a firm affected by industrial action in another firm these workers can be laid off until normal production is possible.

Perhaps the most insidious aspect of this provision is clear when one asks the question: Is the worker employed by a firm, not engaged in industrial action, but who is stood down, able to claim social security benefits? The answer is yes , provided that the worker is not a member of the same union which is engaged in industrial action. So the workers who may be innocent victims of a dispute, and these automatic stand-down provisions, may be denied sustenance although they have had no part in the original dispute or the decision to go into disputation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't striking unionists think of that themselves?

—That may be so but the Minister cannot get away from the truth of what I am saying. Innocent third parties are involved and the Government is willing to persecute them. This implies that blame always--
—They ought to think of the consequences of their actions. You want to get strikers to think of other people for a change.
—If you listened to me for a change instead of prattling away over there you might learn something of the realities of having to work for a living.
—Don't you think I have ever done that?
—You have worked for a living in a very closed and protected situation of the solicitors' shop and the Bar Council-a very unionised shop, if I might say so.
—Order! I ask the Minister to cease interjecting and I ask the honourable member for Cunningham to address the Chair.

—This whole scenario implies that blame always lies with the union or the trade unionist involved and never with the employer. That is nonsense. Many disputes, apart from wage disputes, are perfectly justifiable and are provoked by employers. I refer to safety disputes and disputes initiated by the employer because of a run-down in stocks or because of some economic situation relating to his or her particular firm.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to clause 20 which amends section 144A, allegedly to protect the right of an employee to choose to join or not to join a particular union. If this clause in the Bill is passed non-union labour will stand a better chance of receiving fair and equal treatment than unionised labour. It will be an offence to favour unionised labour in any way but, within the terms of this legislation, it is possible for employers to discriminate effectively in favour of non-union labour when employing people. For example, despite the fact that the employer is prevented from discriminating against unionists in his or her employ, the employer can decide to hire only non-union labour; an employer could decide under this Bill to hire only non-union labour and if a union took action or ever threatened action to persuade the employer to hire union members or to persuade the new non-union workers to join the union, that union or its representatives would be in breach of proposed new section 144A.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.
—What the Minister is saying is that it will allow employers to discriminate in favour of non-union labour.
—To protect them.
—Even if the non-unionists em- ployed were less qualified than the union labour which applied, this case would remain the same because of this proposed new section.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to what this Government refuses to consider. Let us examine the major causes of disputes. In reality, that is what the Bill is all about, if the Government says that too much time is being lost by disputation and that employers are losing too much money through having to pay workers who are not gainfully employed as a result of a strike. Obviously this legislation does not relate to any examination of the causes of disputes in an effort to try to eradicate those causes. One of the prime causes of disputation is the current inadequacy of the Government's wage policies. Rather than attacking trade unionists and rather than encouraging scab or non-union labour, this Government should be implementing a national wage or a national adequate and equitable prices and incomes policy. But no, the Government has not done that; nor has it ever considered it.

The Government has destroyed centralised wage fixation. It has destroyed wage indexation. Now it professes to join the financial gurus of the Australian Financial Review in professing to believe in collective bargaining. I shall return to that subject shortly. As regards indexation, in late 1975 this Government promised to support wage indexation. Up until early 1981 there were 15 cases and the Government opposed wage indexation 15 times. Of the last 11 cases, the Government went before the court for no increase at all 10 times. To prove the truth of what I am saying, Mr Deputy Speaker, I ask that this table of all the indexation cases, the Government's responses, the results and the court' s decisions be incorporated in Hansard.
