TALK.START.PARA: —This Government, having destroyed wage indexation, now advocates collective bargaining. It says that collective bargaining results in fewer wage- related strikes and a more flexible wage structure. Well, it certainly results in a more polarised wage structure, if not a more flexible one. But I do not agree that it results in fewer wage related disputes. Those who advocate collective bargaining in today's economic situation as an alternative to centralised wage fixation and who say in support of that argument that it produces fewer wage-related disputes are not telling the truth.

SPEECH.PARA: Under centralised collective bargaining between 1965 and 1967, the number of wage and benefit-related disputes, which includes disputes over wages, hours, leave and other benefits, averaged 362 a year. Between 90 per cent and 95 per cent of those disputes were wage-related. In 1968 the number of these disputes rose to 544. In 1969 it rose to 684. By 1970, the figure had more than tripled to 1,228 benefit-related disputes. This was in a situation of non-centralised wage fixation. This level of disputes was maintained at an average of 1,051 between 1971 and 1974. In the turbulent industrial year of 1974, the total number of such disputes was 1,235. But in the following year, when wage indexation was introduced, the number of wage and benefit-related disputes fell to 540.

The history of wage and benefit-related disputes under wage indexation is far better than that simply under conciliation and arbitration. In 1977 wage and benefits-related disputes totalled 558; in 1978 the figure was 628; in 1979 the figure was 679; and in 1980 the figure was 667. Despite the problems with wage indexation, one can virtually say that chaos resulted after indexation was abolished early last year. For the June quarter of that year, wage and benefit- related disputes totalled 222. For the September quarter, the figure rose to 326 . That is, just under half of the total number of wage and benefit-related disputes for the entire year of 1980 were recorded in one quarter.

To oppose indexation in the light of this track record seems absurd, but that is what the Government has done. It exemplifies that this Government will extend itself in order to implement the illogical ad hockery that it calls policy. By abolishing wage indexation, the Government destroyed a centralised wages policy. The results of this decision are clear enough, as I have just enunciated. Also, collective bargaining ensures that polarisation occurs, particularly in resource development and construction areas. The workers who are going to gain out of collective bargaining are those who belong to large powerful unions located in the more profitable industries or in construction areas where there is greater capacity to pay.

This is exemplified by the situation in areas in which highly profitable industries or development projects determine the local economy. For instance, in Singleton, New South Wales, staff at Warkworth Mining Ltd are paid award wages, open-cut allowances and margins for skill, as well as a bonus of $160 a week. This occurs across the plant. Less profitable areas, such as local councils and county councils, cannot hope to hold their labour and compete. The same situation occurs at Morwell in the Latrobe Valley, at Gladstone and in other areas.

What happens when the workers go out to work for power station contractors or coal mines and earn their $500, $600 or $700 a week? Firstly, it means that the local councils and local small employers cannot hold their labour. There is a shortage of skilled labour in those areas. But then inflation occurs. Up go the rents and prices, and the poor workers who have been left behind in those areas, and who are not getting the high wages paid by the contractors and in the coal mines, get the lower wages from the small employers that the Government reckons it is going to protect, and workers in the local councils, which cannot afford to pay, have to pay the high prices and high rents which are occurring in those developing areas. If the Minister for Industrial Relations cannot see that that is resulting from his policy of support for collective bargaining, he should not be the Minister for Industrial Relations-and, of course, he should not be.

The truth is that this Government is in a mess. Unemployment is up. Interest rates are up. Inflation is up. The Government has relied on a resource boom to stimulate employment-a boom that never was. Now, because it is in such economic trouble, it seeks to divert the workers of Australia from this economic mess that it has created by trying to create more strikes. Exports are down. Imports are up. The current account is in a horrific mess. Capital is flooding in, and the Government is relying on it because it is like a drug to the Government.

There is a very great need for an expansionary economic policy, not for this sort of industrial ad hockery. We need to expand the Budget outlays to create employment and to reduce interest rates. But with these policies, of course, an industrial relations policy of collective bargaining would be disastrous. We can expand the economy, but only if we have a working and equitable prices and incomes policy, a broad ranging wages policy which can centralise wage fixation equitably, which can restructure the tax system and which can implement a social wage, which will include a proper health insurance scheme, proper social security benefits, taxation reform and adequate price control mechanisms.

That is the sort of prices and incomes policy that the Australian Labor Party will be able to deliver at the next election in conjunction with an expansion of the economy. We can fix up the mess. We do not have to rely on this sort of ad hoc, dispute-creating, provocative industrial relations policy, which gives employers the right to stand down labour in the name of protecting their own profits and assures the rights of non-unionists to employment.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question put:
That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Hawke's amendment) stand part of the question.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 and 2-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 3 (Objects of Act).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee should understand the nature of this proposal. This clause seeks to amend the objects section of the legislation, and to do so in a most unusual fashion in that sub-section (f) of section 2 of the Act is to be deleted. There seeks to be inserted a new provision, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: to safeguard the freedom of persons to choose whether or not to be members of organizations of employees so registered . . .

The unusual feature about this provision is that it relates only to the membership of organisations of employees. Wherever else reference is made, in the objects section or in the legislation generally, to the membership of organisations, it is so indicated that it is an employee or employer organisation. Here, it is to safeguard the freedom of persons to choose whether or not to be members of organisations of employees so registered. Why is there a distinction in regard to organisations of employees and not organisations of employers? Is it suggested that circumstances do not exist where there may be some coercion of employers to be or not to be members of employer organisations? Clearly the provision is deficient in that regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill is directed to the question of voluntary unionism ; that is, the right of an individual to join or not to join a union. The problems of the closed shop or coercion to join a union and discrimination or victimisation against a person who does not wish to join a union but nevertheless wishes to work, to carry on his trade, calling or occupation of whatever kind are of a completely different character from the matter of employer membership of an employer organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been surprised at the stand taken by the Opposition with regard to the principle of voluntary unionism because, so far as the Government is concerned, this legislation gives full and complete respect to what is a fundamental right. To draw upon some authority for my proposition I turn to a speech by a member of the Opposition in another place, Senator Gareth Evans. In a paper delivered to the Industrial Relations Society of Victoria on 20 June 1979, published in monograph series No. 9 of that society, Senator Evans said-I invite Opposition members to listen to it:

It must be accepted that a logical corollary to the undisputed democratic right of free association is the right not to associate. As a matter of first principle, no one should be forced to join any organisation against his or her will. If that right is acknowledged in principle it ought to be capable of enforcement in practice, if necessary by statutory means.

That is the major premise upon which Senator Evans proceeds to argue the morality of conscientious objection. I do not accept his following arguments, because he then seeks to convert the fundamental freedom of association to a compulsion to join a union, and then to argue for relief from that compulsion by the granting of acknowledgment of conscientious objection. That seems to me to be turning logic on its head.

I was interested also to draw some authority for the proposition that unions in Australia are based on the principle of voluntary association from His Honour Mr Justice Murphy, of the High Court. In the case of the Queen against J. B. Sweeney, ex parte Northwest Exports Pty Ltd, reported in 35 ALR at page 135, His Honour said-I quote from page 150:

It is open to Parliament to take the view that employers should have no influence on whether or not an employee joins an organisation of employees because this would tend to detract from the voluntary and representative nature of the organisations . . .

I suggest that that is an accurate statement by Mr Justice Murphy of what this Bill proposes. It takes the view-I am sure that Parliament will pass this legislation and thereby express the same view-that employers should have no influence on whether an employee joins an organisation of employees because that would tend to depart from the voluntary and representative nature of the organisation. I go one step further than His Honour and say that Parliament would take the view that unions likewise should have no influence upon a person by way of discrimination or victimisation, who chooses not to join a union. Indeed, if one needs further support for the fundamental principle of civil liberty, as expressed by Senator Evans, one need only turn to the 1981 Congress statement of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Under the heading 'Human Rights' the following appears:
Congress pledges its support for the achievement of basic human rights including freedom of assembly and the right of workers to organise free trade unions.

What we believe we are doing is giving expression to this fundamental civil liberty, the right of the individual to choose to join or not to join a union. I believe that if one asks the population one will find that the bulk supports the expression by this Government, through this legislation, of that fundamental principle. That is what we seek to express by this clause amending the objects provided in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government would have us believe that its concern is for the rights of the individual. That is the whole thrust of the Government's proposition. I propose to refer to the annual report of the Government's own Industrial Relations Bureau to show that adequate provision is already made for those who seek not to join unions. That is only one part of a number of matters that the Government should take into consideration. It should realise that there is no need for what it is proposing. According to the Government's own report for the year 1979-80, under section 144A, which relates to the right to opt out and not belong to a union, the IRB dealt with 27 such complaints and inquiries, out of a total of 410. In the following year, 1980-81, the IRB dealt with 50 such complaints and inquiries, but that was out of a total of 740. According to the report for that year, only 7 per cent of the cases dealt with were individual rights matters.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the other area in respect of which the Government claims that workers need protection and therefore do not have to join a union. I refer to section 188 of the principal Act. In 1979-80 the number of such complaints and inquiries dealt with by the IRB, the industrial arm set up by the Government, numbered only 23 out of a total of 410. For 1980-81, the figures were 58 out of a total of 740. Again I do not think that in any way, shape or form the Government can justify the fundamental change that it seeks to make to the Act, that of attempting to alter its chief objectives. That is what the Government is really trying to do. That argument cannot be sustained by the Government if it uses the figures from its own Bureau as to the number of problems that occur.

The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) has said that that is the main thrust of the legislation, that the right of the individual is paramount. I repeat, in regard to two aspects, the section dealing with the right to opt out, to take a conscientious objection, and that which deals with complaints on the part of people who have refused to take part in industrial disputes-ever under the Government's own legislation, which was toughened up to give this kind of scab an out-only the small number of complaints to which I have referred has been made in two years of operation. What the Government is really about is trying to change a system that is based on representation. It is important that we should consider what this Government is about in its attempt to change the chief objects of the Act. In fact, if we spend a little time to consider them, we note that the chief objects of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act of 1904, as set out in section 2, are:
(a) to promote goodwill in industry:
One certainly will not see that emerging from what the Government proposes. The second objective is:
(b) to encourage, and provide means for, conciliation with a view to amicable agreement, thereby preventing and settling industrial disputes;
We will not see that result either from these propositions. In particular, sub- section (e) provides:
To encourage the organisation of representative bodies of employers and employees and their registration under this Act;

As I said, the whole Act relates to a system that is based on representation. In order to work under it, employers and employees must be represented by their organisation or association. That is the whole basis of the Act. It deals with good will and encouraging people to join industrial organisations. But the Government would seek to destroy that very concept. I believe the Government, whether it knows it or not, is aware of it or cares, is putting in jeopardy the rights that an employee might well have under an award.

There have been a number of cases involving individuals, that is, the people that the Government would seek to provide for, who choose not to belong to a union. I put it to the Government and to the Minister that an employee who chose that course would in fact be depriving himself of rights under an award, determination or agreement. There have been a number of cases in which this has clearly been shown to be the situation. Such workers have attempted to appear before the Commission and the Industrial Court to seek to secure the advantages of an award of the Commission. The Court has ruled against them and has said that they have no right to be before the Court or before the Commission. Is this what the Government is about? It is trying to con these workers into this position where they would be denied certain rights? If the Government is going to facilitate and encourage non-unionism, it had better go the whole hog and tell them about the rights that they are going to lose.

In 1973 there was before the Industrial Court the case of Tziortis v. ACI Australian Glass Manufacturers Co. On the Bench were Spicer, Joske and Smithers. They ruled against the rights of an individual to have the protection of or share in the gains of an agreement that had been made between the secretary of the union and the employer. There have been a number of other similar cases-I can recall being involved in one myself-in which the employer sent a number of employees to the Commission to try to disrupt the claims being put to the Commission by the union on behalf of the workers. The Commission ruled against them and said they could not be heard, that the only people who could be heard were the unions or their agents, and the employers or their agents. They were the people who made the awards, the respondents to the awards, and therefore the workers who were not in the union did not have the right to representation. If the Government is trying to pull the wool over the eyes of workers it should address itself to that proposition. I think it is far more important to point out that the Government is attacking the fundamental principle behind the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, that is, a system based on representation, not one that is prepared to accommodate scabs and people who are not prepared to pay union dues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take a few minutes before the suspension of the sitting for dinner to speak on a couple of grounds against the Government's proposed amendment in clause 3. Firstly, the Government is not in touch with reality today. Secondly, this clause is discriminatory. It is clearly aimed only at employees and it does not relate to employer organisations. When we look at the debate that took place this afternoon at the second reading stage it is not hard to understand that. A couple of the main speakers from the Government side are members of the law institute. I do not think the Government could raise its head if it proposed legislation which gave people power to break the hold that people in those types of unions have. The employer unions, the higher paid areas that support the Government side, are not affected by this Bill. It is strictly aimed at employees. It is another piece of legislation that will only cause problems.

SPEECH.PARA: Another reason why this clause should not be supported by the Parliament is that it will not be supported by the people. It is quite clear in the political world today that this Government is not receiving the support of the public for the types of legislation that it is bringing forward. In fact, it is not receiving the support of a solid bloc within its own party. For example, at a meeting held recently one-third of the members of the Government parties voted solidly to express their view that they wanted a change in direction. But this is not a change in direction. This is headlong down the road of disaster. If the Committee wants a clear indication of how much out of touch the Government is with the public and not only with the public but also--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Chair is obliged to remind the honourable member that we are discussing clause 3 in Committee and he is required to be more strictly relevant than he is presently.

—The clause itself is a straightout change to the Act supposedly to safeguard the freedom of persons. What I am saying is that the Government is so far out of touch that the general thrust of the clause is not in the best interests of this country. One only has to look at the report of the president of an organisation in Victoria to see what the general feeling of the people is towards this type of clause and this type of legislation. One only has to look at the President's report to the central council of the United Dairyfarmers of Victoria, not an organisation that is affiliated with the Labor Party but an organisation which is expressing the views of the public about this type of legislation. At annual conference after annual conference it has been making decisions. I would like to read from the President's report of April 1982. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: We all know that at every annual conference we have had, everyone has been in favour of compulsory membership, yet we have got exactly nowhere with the proposal.

What that organisation is saying is that it was not able under the Liberal Government of Victoria to achieve the aims which were adopted at its own conferences, that is, compulsory membership. The general feeling in the community today is the same as it is in all organisations. The cost of running organisations today and looking after members is something that has to be shared by everybody right across the board. This type of legislation is clearly designed to allow sections of any organisation, and in this case worker organisations, not employer organisations, to opt out of their responsibilities. Those responsibilities are not imposed on them by law. The Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has had this in its charter since 1904. It has been used wisely for many years. It has been recognised, as the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) has said, by many governments over many years. There is no logical reason, except the politics of the situation, why this clause has been brought in. There is no support for it from employer organisations. It does not reflect the view of the public and there can be only one reason for it, and that is that this Government is determined to go headlong into oblivion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have only one point to make. We are talking about voluntary unionism as compared with compulsory unionism in law. The whole objection of the Opposition appears to me to demonstrate its supporters' profound doubt that without this provision in the Act the union movement could not attract membership. If that is not the problem, what are honourable members opposite worried about? They should not have a worry. If the unions are so good, the workers will flock to their doors and they will pay the money with pleasure. Let us face it, that is what honourable members opposite are worried about, and nobody knows that better than the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke). He offered them their own grocery and clothing store in the middle of Melbourne, but it went broke because the people would not flock there. The problem is exactly that and I put it to the Committee that there are no problems whatsoever with this clause. If the union movement can attract members, it does not need intimidation or compulsion by law. I do not know what honourable members opposite are worried about. If they are convinced that the operations of the trade union movement are so good they should have no problem whatsoever once this piece of legislation is in place.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.
Clauses 4 and 5-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few brief comments about these two clauses. Clause 4 proposes the addition to the definition clause of various definitions which relate to the substantive amendments to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. Of particular importance are the proposed definitions of ' prescribed business' and 'prescribed corporation' which will apply to the new stand-down and voluntary unionism provisions. As can be seen, the definitions of 'prescribed business' and 'prescribed corporation' attempt to provide as wide as possible constitutional support for the operation of the provisions relating to stand-downs and voluntary unionism.

SPEECH.PARA: The clear implication here is that the normal constitutional provision-placitum (xxxv.) of section 51 of the Constitution-would not be sufficient to found the expansion of powers in the legislation. Accordingly the clause seeks to draw upon these other possible heads of power to sustain the expansion of the Government's intentions in this regard. I suggest that this raises the question of the likelihood or the possibility of constitutional challenge in that regard to these issues. This is one of the reasons that the national employers have expressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) and to the Government very serious concern about what they are doing here. Obviously if it were upheld that the invocation of these heads of power would sustain the exercise upon which the Government is engaged here, it would follow that this Government, or any government, would on the same basis be able to use those heads of power to legislate directly in the area of wages and conditions of employment. That concern has been expressed to the Minister and to the Government.

Clause 5 introduces a new section 4B into the Act which provides that the Act will not apply to claims or industrial disputes involving preference to unionists or to claims or disputes relating to members of a union that has been deregistered by a State industrial tribunal. The effect of the clause, if it were to become law, would be to deprive the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission of jurisdiction to deal with these matters. I believe that it is appropriate and indeed necessary to put on the record the basis of our fundamental objection to what the Government is proposing here. What it means is that although disputes will continue to occur in relation to preference to unionists and in regard to award coverage for members of deregistered State unions, the Commission will be prevented from dealing with such disputes. This removes a further area of industrial conflict from the jurisdiction of the Federal tribunal, which has a statutory responsibility with respect to the prevention and settlement of disputes. Obviously if this power were taken away from the Commission it would not stop the existence of disputes but it would take away the power of the tribunal to deal with them. In those circumstances there would be nowhere for those disputes to go. The provision would hinder the prevention and settlement of the disputes in the interests of the parties and of the general community through the established dispute settling machinery.

If one looks at this clause one will see the classic illustration of the Government creating a position which is not likely to lead to a reduction of disputes. Firstly, more disputes are likely to occur as a result of what the Government is doing. Secondly, and in a sense more importantly, the Government is removing any possible locus of decision for those disputes. How even this Minister could start to explain the sense of that situation-firstly, creating more disputes and then, secondly, removing any place where those disputes can be settled-defies the imagination. I suggest that it is a classic illustration of the basis of this legislation, which is not one which reflects the requirements and the decisions of those involved in the industrial relations field on the side of the employers, the trade unions and other concerned commentators, but reflects-as I and other speakers have said-the continuing intention of this Government to use this whole area of industrial relations for perceived political purposes rather than to make a deliberate and considered approach to it calculated to try to reduce the number of disputes and increase the possibility of the existing machinery dealing with those disputes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —What we have just heard from the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) establishes that, far from people on this side of the chamber being the confrontationists in industrial relations, it is people such as the honourable member for Wills, with the views which they represent, who are the confrontationists. All that he has said with regard to the removal of jurisdiction of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission with respect to preference and deregistration of State unions presupposes that he, those behind him and those belonging to the union movement believe it is the right of the union movement consistently to dispute and disrupt the orderly flow of trade and commerce of this nation. We need an institution to settle disputes only when we believe that one or other of the parties involved in labour relations will create disputes. Of course, this is the whole fallacy of the attitude of the union movement to industrial relations in Australia. One sees that through the declared policy of the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. They declare in the most unambiguous terms the absolute and untrammelled right to strike and embark upon industrial action. That is the threshold of the creation of industrial disputes.

SPEECH.PARA: What is required in Australia is not a change of attitude by members on this side of the chamber-the Liberal and National Country Party side of the chamber. What is required is a change of attitude within the Labor Party and the union movement as to what is required for peace and good government in industrial relations. If only the the union movement would accept that it has an obligation to the people of Australia to see that the life-blood of the prosperity of Australia-that is, the free flow of trade and commerce of this nation-is important then we would have a much better industrial relations climate. In dealing with clause 4 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill the honourable member for Wills made reference to the use of the corporations power and the trade and commerce power of the Constitution.

TALK.START.PARA: —The banking and insurance power.

—And the banking power and the insurance power, where it is necessary to draw on them. I remind the honourable gentleman that the amendments which this Government introduced to the Trade Practices Act, by way of section 45D in particular, were based on the use of the corporations and trade and commerce power. Section 45D is directed to the use of secondary boycotts by the union movement against employers in order to throttle them commercially, to put them under commercial pressure to further what is said to be the legitimate industrial interests of the trade movement. It has been a very important legislative provision which has aided employers when they have been threatened in that way. There have been a number of instances in which companies have resorted in the civil courts of this land, under section 45D, to seek legal remedies against the use by unions of the secondary boycott as an industrial weapon. That has been used, and used effectively. One thing is very clear and that is that the union movement in Australia will do its very best to prevent the courts of this land from showing that unions are subject to the law in the same way as anybody else, whether an individual or a corporate. We believe that the use of the corporations and the trade and commerce power under the Trade Practices Act has been important and to the benefit of this nation.

SPEECH.PARA: Likewise, when unions demand the free and untrammelled right to strike or to take industrial action irrespective of the commercial interests of the company concerned, or the personal interests of the employees of that company, it is important to give employers some rights which will equalise both the bargaining position and their position within the industry of this nation. It is quite understandable and quite proper for this Government to have sought to draw on the corporations and the trade and commerce power available to it under the Constitution.

The other comment I make is that by clause 5 we have withdrawn from the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission jurisdiction to act in certain areas. Of course, notably in the area of preference, we have given legal rights to the individual. The important thing in this situation is for an individual to have a legal remedy available if he is harmed or injured by the industrial action of a union which seeks to discriminate or victimise him because he does not wish to join a union. We have given such persons that legal remedy by giving them access to the Federal Court of Australia to sue for any loss or damage that they may suffer by being denied, for example, the opportunity to work or the opportunity for promotion because of discrimination or victimisation by a union. The answer to the honourable gentleman is that, whilst jurisdiction is withdrawn from the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, it is given to the Federal Court of Australia to entertain suits at the hand of an individual who is deliberately harmed or injured in his right to work, right to promotion or right to continue in work when he does not wish to join a union.
I think it is about time that the Australian Labor Party acknowledged that one of the fundamental civil liberties of this nation of ours is the right to work.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the half a million unemployed? What right to work have they got with all your policies? You have denied the right to work to half a million Australians. What utter hypocrisy.

—If that right is denied to a person who wants to work, then let it be on the head of the honourable member for Wills. It always amazes me that members of the Australian Labor Party parade themselves as the saviours of the civil liberties of this nation, but when one analyses it they in fact seek to destroy the civil liberties of the people of this great country of ours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner), in his remarks regarding this clause, mentioned the interest of the Australian Labor Party in maintaining people's right to work. That is exactly what we are doing in this Parliament. We are trying to get the Minister and his buddies off the Treasury benches so that we can put half a million Australians back to work. That is a principal consideration of the Labor Party. But let us get back to the disputes and the jurisdiction of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission that is withdrawn by this clause 5. By taking disputes out of the conciliation area and putting them under the jurisdiction of the High Court the Minister intends to create disputes. That in itself would not be so bad because disputes can be resolved so long as they remain in the industrial area. But how will a dispute be resolved when people will maintain their right to withdraw their work and not to work with scabs? The scabs will then go to the High Court, take the matter to a completely different arena, and try to find redress there. An unsolvable dispute will be created. The High Court will not settle industrial disputes in this country. Traditionally industrial disputes are settled not by learned lawyers such as those sitting opposite but by people aware of the realities of the job. Lawyers get thousands of dollars; they do not care. A High Court action by a few scabs and provocateurs placed somewhere to create a strike results in a banquet for lawyers. But thousands and thousands of dollars will be lost in wages and hundreds of thousands of dollars lost in production. That is what this clause will do.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses agreed to.
Clause 6 (Powers of employers in relation to industrial action).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 6 is one of the central features of the proposed legislation. It is one to which, on behalf of the Opposition, I indicate our strongest possible opposition. To put it briefly, clause 6 introduces a new section into the Act, section 33B, which confers very extensive powers on employers to penalise employees taking part in what is described as industrial action or who cannot be usefully employed as a result of industrial action. It is absolutely certain-there can be no question or argument about this-that the proposed new section will give rise to practical and legal problems for employers who seek to make use of it. I remind the Committee of what I said at the second reading stage-that sections of the employers were so strong in their objection to the proposals, and so percipient of the difficulties that could arise, that they insisted with the Government that the existing stand-down provisions in the legislation should remain.

SPEECH.PARA: It is appropriate that I should spend a little more time than I was able to devote at the second reading stage in pointing out the difficulties and the problems associated with the proposals contained in the clause. It is an extreme provision which provides employers who are silly enough to try to use it with very extensive powers to penalise employees. As has been pointed out, it is not tempered with appropriate safeguards for the rights of employees who may be affected. This certainly is likely to lead to industrial disputation about the use of the power. As I pointed out, it is not necessary to bring in this legislation because, under the law as it stands now, there is a power for employers to get stand-downs.

On behalf of the Opposition, and on behalf of the trade union movement, I make it quite clear that we are not saying that there may not be circumstances in which an employer should be entitled to seek a stand-down. They have that right now. It can be done in one of two ways. A general power to stand down has been in the metal industry award for a very long time. Also, there can be a more particular approach by an employer to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It may be that there can be some argument that the Government could have been told that, in respect of those existing powers, where the employer has to go to an independent tribunal and justify his argument for standing down employees-after all, denying people a livelihood is a very significant thing-the experience is that as the law stands now too much delay is involved. If that had been the case, and we had been made aware of it, that would have been a legitimate matter to ask this Parliament to consider. There has not been a scintilla of evidence to suggest that that is the case.

Instead of dealing with what may be a real position, an entirely provocative and very extreme measure has been introduced. The proposed powers in clause 6 extend beyond so-called stand-down powers. In relation to employees engaged in industrial action, a declaration under section 33B may allow an employer to apply the 'no work as directed no pay' principle. Employees who place a ban on the performance of certain duties, for example, because of safety considerations , but who continue to perform all their other duties, will not be entitled to any wages for the entire period that the ban continues. Of course the result in those circumstances is that an employee may be put in a no pay position almost at the whim of his or her employer.

I again remind the Committee of the circumstances that I referred to in an earlier debate of what happened in the Latrobe Valley in regard to the Loy Yang situation on 12 February and 20 February. The men stopped work because of a severe industrial accident on two successive occasions. They took the view that the responsibility for those accidents, which caused serious injury to an employee, was the employers who had shown extreme derelection of duty by not abiding by the procedures to which he had previously agreed. The men stopped work because not merely the safety but also the lives of men were involved in this issue. Subsequently their action was shown to be justified by the employer who, in fact, indicated that he had to accept the responsibility. The men who used industrial action in that form were paid for the period involved. That illustrates not merely the absurdity but also the immorality of the situation that has been launched into this House.

All that is being done is that an employer is being given the power to declare that there is industrial action and he cannot employ people despite the fact that they may have continued to do all their normal work but decline to use some piece of equipment because it was endangering the lives and safety of themselves and their fellow workers. An employer is being given the autonomous right to declare that he is being affected in this way and to deny any pay to his employees who are in that situation. The extreme powers given to employers are not tempered by any reasonable safeguards accorded to employees concerned. For example, there is no provision for hearing before an impartial tribunal such as the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission which must be held under the way in which the existing provisions apply. There is no provision for appeal to be taken on the merits of the making of a declaration unilaterally and autonomously by an employer.

Even where the relevant industrial action was caused by the employer concerned the employer may make full use of the powers under section 34B to protect himself against the consequences of the Action and to penalise his employees. There is no requirement that an employer notify an employee before the declaration has the effect of disentitling the employee to wages. An employee may continue to work, or attend for work, even though by virtue of a declaration of which he has no notice he will not be paid for such work or attendance. There will be scope for challenging the use of section 33B powers in the courts due to the complicated procedures provided under the section.

However, we have a situation which has worked. Not one scintilla of evidence has been put to this House which shows that those provisions which involve the utilisation of the independent and impartial Arbitration Commission, where the employer can argue his case for a stand down provision, are not working or why, if that is the case, there should not be some improvement in facilitating the exercise in that situation. After all the very guts-if I can put it that way-of what the conciliation and arbitration system is about is that if an employer has a case, or if a worker and a union have a case, let them argue it. In the case of a stand down, if employers cannot usefully engage employees, because of an existing situation, time after time it has been shown that the Commission will grant the case. Here we are opening up a situation where workers would have to take action to defend their safety. The provision can be used by a maverick, malicious or thoughtless employer to bring about a situation where lives will be put at risk without any possibility of a hearing before an impartial tribunal. I suggest on an impartial examination of this matter there can be no justification for this drastic change from a system which has worked reasonably well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe there is a very short but compelling answer to the proposition of the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) that the right to stand down must necessarily be subject to the determination of an independent and impartial body. Of course the union movement will not allow itself to be subject to an independent and impartial judgment before it determines that it should strike or embark upon industrial action. Industrial policy of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, as passed at its 1981 Congress, declares the right of unions and unionists to take industrial action. The policy of the Australian Labor Party is to the same effect. It is a rather hollow argument by the honourabe member for Wills to demand that an employer, who is suffering commercial harm because of the industrial action of others who may not even be employed in that employer's plant, must go to what he calls an independent and impartial body. However the ALP denies positively, unequivocally and consistently that no such control mechanism should be put upon the industrial action of unions. As I have said, the honourable gentleman's argument is hollow and the Government believes that employers of this country should be put in at least as equal a position as we, as a Government, can through the legislation of this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's position on this matter could be misunderstood by the general public if it was made aware of the fact that a large number of awards currently have stand down provisions. An earlier speaker referred to the metal industries as being one of the key areas where there are alleged to be industrial problems. There have been stand down provisions in the metal industries award for some considerable time. I think it is important that the provisions be referred to here. They are:

SPEECH.PARA: Notwithstanding anything elsewhere contained in this clause:

(i) The employer shall have the right to deduct payment for any day the employee cannot be usefully employed because of any strike or through any breakdown in machinery or any stoppage of work by any cause for which the employer cannot reasonably be held responsible.

I have no doubt that a large section of the public listening to the Government's rantings on this question would not be aware that unions have had to cope with these provisions for a long time. There have been numerous occasions when employers have used these provisions in a very capricious way to turn worker against worker. Workers in one section who make claims in respect of wages or conditions have been virtually blackmailed by employers through the threat of standing down thousands of production workers. This scenario is well known in the car manufacturing industry and is used constantly by employers.

Let us get the balance correct. If one were to listen to the current Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) one would think that it was the unions which needed discipline. I suggest that it is the employers who need discipline. This morning the current Minister handed down the twenty-fifth annual report of the President of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission for the year ended 13 August 1981. It is convenient that the document was handed down today because it is worth reading. The document puts the lie to the rubbish that we have heard here from this Minister and the five, or is it four, henchmen behind him who have attempted to support him. The document contains a table which deals with the notification of disputes under section 25 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. According to that table 1,772 dispute notifications were made to the Commission. We are informed that there were only 27 stand downs. I ask honourable members to compare 27 stand downs with a total of 1,772 dispute notifications. How can the Government suggest that there are great problems in the real industrial world in respect of employers and employees when its own report shows that there were 27 notifications of disputes under the stand down provisions out of a total of 1,772? I suggest that the current Minister and the Government are not serious or genuine. They are merely union bashing, as they have been doing for some considerable time.

I wish to place the seriousness of this problem in perspective. Unions often go into a dispute with an employer over safety issues or accidents. I have had 12 years' practical experience, not on $1,000 a day as a rich lawyer but working in a factory with workers and dealing with these kinds of problems. I have had to go into factories after people have been killed. The Minister thinks this is funny. This Minister is irresponsible because he is totally one eyed anti-union-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will come back to the question before the Committee. We are dealing with clause 6.
—I will do just that, Mr Chairman.
—Well do that.

—I ask the honourable member to be quiet. I ask that you, Mr Chairman, instruct the Minister to cease smiling and laughing humorously about a very serious matter. He still thinks it funny. I will ignore the clown who is currently the Minister and deal with the very serious situation which exists when unions go into a dispute and employers invoke the stand down provisions which currently are found in many awards. Many unions go into a dispute because there has been an accident, often a fatal accident. If this Government is serious about the economy and about trying to get things moving it will deal with this problem in a serious way.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw attention to a report in the Australian of 24 March this year which deals with the situation to which I have referred of employers using stand down provisions following a dispute with unions. I will read this not for the benefit of the Minister, who seems to think this matter is humorous, but in the hope that the young people in the public gallery, who may be fortunate enough soon to have a job, will start to realise the kinds of problems that unions and honourable members on this side of the chamber have in trying to protect the interests and health of workers. The article in the Australian states:
Industrial accidents are costing more than the national defence bill, according to a safety expert.
The Victorian president of the National Safety Council, Mr Max Eise, claims that the cost of work injuries will exceed the defence bill of $3,540 million.
He predicts the national bill for workers' compensation will be as high as $ 5000 million this financial year.
This figure includes workers' compensation premiums paid by employers, claims for loss of production due to work injuries, and medical costs.
Mr Eise said yesterday: 'There are more than 500,000 serious injuries at work across Australia each year. Ninety per cent of these are avoidable'.

That is the kind of situation that union officials, shop stewards and workers have to face day in, day out. I ask the Minister to take those figures into his thick head if he can. We are talking about half a million workers being seriously injured each year. It costs $5 billion. These are the kinds of issues that cause disputes. I have been in situations in which employers have acted capriciously and used such a situation as an excuse to stand down or threaten to stand down thousands of production workers. An employer takes such action when a small group of tradesmen, perhaps, goes into a dispute because of serious situation in a factory. The company concerned threatens to stand down 1,000 or 2 ,000 workers. One could fill this chamber with headlines and stories from newspapers of threats, in particular by car companies, to stand down 1,000 to 2, 000 workers if a dispute is not resolved. This is the kind of situation we are faced with all the time. I think the Government's argument has been hollow-it has been shown to be hollow. This legislation is merely a further exercise in the Government's union bashing campaign. This action will get it nowhere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to support briefly the remarks on this clause made by speakers from this side of the chamber. In many ways, having any sort of conciliation and arbitration Act in this country is something of an anachronism if we are to be compared with equivalent nations. That we can have that system at all depends to a very considerable extent on an acceptance by both sides that the legislation brought in under those various heads of the Constitution is to be applied equitably. If that conviction does not exist there will be one of two results: Either the clauses that are not perceived as equitable by all sides will be totally ignored or those clauses for a period will themselves be the source of very considerable industrial dispute. This is one of the clauses in the Bill to which I think the second of those two possibilities applies. After the second of those two possibilities has applied for a considerable period probably the first will apply. After an experience of utilising this power, after those employers who use it see in the end that what it has created for them is more loss and more trouble than it is worth, probably this power will fall into disuse. Probably it will not have the amount of time that would be required for it to be exercised, as unquestionably it will be one of the things in this Act that will be amended by a Labor government on taking office.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the question of equity which has been raised. There is no way that the trade union movement could regard this particular clause as an equitable act and as a contribution to the equity of the arbitration system. The trade union movement must see it as a direct attack upon itself. The clause includes, if one likes, a legalisation of lock-outs. It gives to an employer a unilateral power. There are very few sections of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act which give anybody unilateral powers. This clause will give such power to one side in industrial disputes. It sits on this Bill like a carbuncle and, like a carbuncle , it will be lanced by the Labor Party when we get into office.

As has already been pointed out by spokesmen on this side of the chamber, ample provision exists in awards and ample access to the Arbitration Court for employers to stand down workers where they have a serious economic need to do so . Those provisions exist in awards-even though there is a considerable degree of objection to the exercise of those awards, as the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott), who spoke before me in this debate, said-largely because when they have been put into those awards they have evolved as part of a process of bargaining over time between the unions in a particular industry and the management in a particular industry. They have applicability to those industries because through what is essentially an organic process that is not readily subject to law in reality-that is, the system of industrial relations-there has been, if not agreement, at least acquiesence from both sides that both sides can live with the various provisions of those awards until perhaps a distribution of power that occurs naturally within the industry shifts or changes and those sections of the awards are removed. So, they have an acceptability.

This is an imposition from outside the system. It is an imposition from a body- the Government-which, if it has any value at all in the system of government, should be an essentially harmonising influence. Essentially, any intervention that it makes in a dispute should be constructive intervention. Its laws should be constructive. Its laws should seriously contribute to the harmony of industry . This clause will not do that. This clause will be a provocation. It may well be used in a period when the workers in a particular industry are weak. It will probably cause considerable grief to those employers who use it over a period. When those employers who use it understand that, they will cease to use it and it will become redundant. In the meantime, the general public will have suffered a great deal as a result of it.
Question put:
That the clause be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 7 (Power to grant preference to members of organizations).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the more objectionable features of the debate up to this stage has been the gratuitous observations of the transient Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) to the Labor Party about the attitude that it should adopt towards industrial relations and the proposals in this legislation in particular. I remind the Minister that he made his second reading speech prior to the Victorian State election. The people of Victoria have certainly had an opportunity to take into account, in their considerations of the political scene, the relative proposals and approach of the Government, the conservative parties, and of the Labor Party on this issue. There could not have been handed down a more decisive verdict than theirs.

SPEECH.PARA: The provisions in clause 7 taken in association with those in clause 20 are basically the most objectionable features of this legislation because they involve a complete turnaround of the fundamental principles that have been involved in the operation of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act since its inception in 1904. The fundamental of the system of conciliation and arbitration has been that it operates upon organisations, not upon idividuals; that is, organisations of employees and organisations of employers. As I pointed out in my speech on the second reading, an essential feature of giving effect to that has been section 47, or its equivalent, since 1904, which has given power and indeed instruction to the Arbitration Court, as it then was, and to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission subsequently, to use the instrument of awarding preference to unionists as a way-one way-of strengthening the organisations which are at the very basis of the operation of the conciliation and arbitration system. As I indicated, that system has operated for almost 80 years, and it is futile in the extreme for a couple of honourable members to get up, as they have done in this debate, and say that the fact that it has been there for 80 years does not mean that it is sacrosanct and that, really, we are being very conservative in asking for something to remain in the Act simply because it has existed for 80 years. That reveals the futility of mind of those who have contributed to the debate from the other side of the chamber.

Our argument is not that one should retain the provision simply because it has existed for 80 years. Of course, one examines why it has been there, what have been the purposes of its being there, how it has been used, and how it has been interpreted by the Commission and the High Court. When one subjects to examination a provision that has existed for 80 years, and which has recomended itself to governments of different persuasions, and when one asks oneself why it has stayed there and relates one's question to those particular issues, one sees precisely why it has been kept. One would have thought that if the Government comes before this House and says: 'We shall take out a provision which has been there for the best part of 80 years', that one would be provided with some argument as to why that should be done.

No argument has been put, except the pitiful, plaintive proposition that this move represents Liberal Party philosophy. As I have said, that philosophy had ample chance of being judged by the second most populous State on 3 April, and a very decisive mandate was given to the Labor Party, which, as part of what it was putting to the people of that State, adopted the opposite proposals and the opposite philosophy to that which is embodied in this legislation.

One point I make in passing is that what this legislation will do is take away from the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission a very important power in regard to the settlement of a particular sort of dispute, which is acknowledged by everyone who knows anything about industrial relations as being the most pernicious sort of industrial dispute-the demarcation dispute. Everyone who knows anything about the scene knows that the demarcation dispute is the worst sort of dispute. The way in which arbitration tribunals have in the past often dealt with the settlement of such disputes is to award the work to a particular union, which involves, in its essence, the provision of preference to members of a particular union. This provision will make it more difficult.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not at all.

—We should take no notice of the ravings of this man. He will not be a Minister for many more days, because he is the greatest disaster in the 80-year history of this legislation. He can grin and be like an ape, but his record speaks for itself. He will not be here in his present capacity when the Parliament resumes.
—Order! I suggest that the honourable member for Wills take his own advice and ignore the interjection.

—I am ignoring it, Mr Chairman. Given the fact that we have only a few minutes left and that some of my colleagues wish to contribute to the debate, I conclude my observations on this point by saying that the Government simply has not faced up to its obligation to bring forward evidence, even a scintilla of evidence, to justify the abolition of a provision which has served this country so well for 80 years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's action in repealing this section of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act indicates what Liberal philosophy has become, more than what it is. It indicates the substantial and substantive move to the extreme right by the Liberal Party throughout the nation. Only when a government has gone beyond the pale in terms of trying to create industrial confrontation will it introduce a clause such as it has introduced to repeal this important section.

SPEECH.PARA: As regards the preference that has been given to unionists, we have heard much from the Minister about the consciences of people who do not want to become members of unions. But the fact is that it is the unionists who have been fighting and struggling for better conditions for all workers. What the section does is to recognise that fact in law before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. If one removes that situation, one is basically saying that those people who have fought for the rights of workers, the unionists and the union movement, are to be demoted before the Commission, and that all those people, those who have not participated in the struggle, those who have not been members of a union, are to be treated in exactly the same way before the Commission.

How will this work in practical terms? As the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) mentioned, this section is extremely important in demarcation disputes, because at present the Commission can resolve those disputes by saying that a particular union has preference for a particular type of work. By repealing this section we shall be creating a situation in which any group or association can claim to be the particular union responsible for a particular type of work. We shall create conflicts between workers. This Government wants that, because it wants to create an atmosphere of industrial confrontation in order to have some basis-it has no other basis, in terms of its record-to try to win an election. The people will judge the Government on the basis of its creation of conflict and crisis which will arise as a result of the clause.

This clause ties up with clause 10, which concerns industry-based unions. I am sure that other honourable members will talk about the absurdity of that. However, one can see how the two clauses relate. With clause 10 we shall get not industry-based unions but a situation in which groups of workers will be confronting other groups of workers, with different groups claiming to represent the rightful owners of a particular type of work. So what will the Arbitration Commission do in these instances? It will not be able to do anything in these instances because by our removing section 47 it will not be able to give preference to particular unions and there will be chaos in the industrial relations scene. The fact is that, as the honourable member for Wills has mentioned, this clause has served us for 80 years. I know that some of the people opposite totally oppose this legislation but they do not have the guts to stand up and be counted. These provisions will create an industrial relations atmosphere the like of which we have never seen in this country.

The Minister for Industrial Relations has been trying to save his neck by coming up with some provisions which neither the employers nor the unions want. This is one of those clauses that neither group wants. The employers want to know who they are dealing with. When this section is removed different groups of workers, unionised and non-unionised, will be able to go to the court and say: ' We represent this type of work; we are the proper group that you should be dealing with in regard to the awards'. Chaos will be created as a result of this and we totally oppose the abolition of this section.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody could suggest that there is a black and white view about these kinds of things. After having listened to some of the pearls that have dropped from the other side I am compelled to make one or two comments. First of all, it would appear that the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) finally has come to the realisation that one of the most pernicious problems that plague this country is demarcation disputes in industry. There is no doubt that that is so, and the waterfront situation illustrates it. What is offered in place of that? What has been put up by the Australian Council of Trade Unions? What has been done, for example, to sort out the waterfront? Nothing at all.
—The amalgamation provisions.

—As the honourable member would well know, amalgamation provisions create things like the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union. If the honourable member does not know that he should not be here and should not be speaking on this subject. Let us put that to one side. One of the things that is just a little troubling to a charitable person like myself, who listens to what has been said by the other side and takes the view that we are all Australians and we all have a common interest in trying to improve things, is that time and again people talk about the union movement. Is there anybody on the other side who is not afraid to speak against what is considered to be the view of the union movement? I freely concede that we err from time to time. Do honourable members opposite not concede that in matters of principle they might err from time to time; that from time to time they have acted out of nothing less than fear of the consequences as a result of the tie to their political affiliations? I give an example of the industrial realities of preference clauses. I do not say that it is always wrong to have a preference clause. I do say that there is a very strong argument against such clauses, based on two principles. First of all, we have the principle of the freedom of choice.
—Why don't you let the courts decide?

—I have an answer to what the honourable member for Willis has in mind. The freedom of choice concerns the philosophy that a person should be entitled to choose who he wants to work for. Why should a person have to be a member of a union if he does not want to be? A person may be in favour of unions or against unions but surely it is fair that he should have an opportunity to decide for himself. Secondly, I give an example relating to the uranium mining industry in the Northern Territory. I doubt very much that honourable members opposite will listen but those who know anything about it will know well what the position is. There was for many years a dispute between two unions, one of which I represented, the Australian Workers Union, about who would be entitled to build the mines and to mine in the Northern Territory. In the end it was a question of whether or not one union should be allowed effective control over mining operations. Do honourable members opposite think that is fair? Do they think that that is the answer to Australian industrial life? Do they think that the right way to go about things is to say: 'Look, fellows, it is a very simple choice; you can decide for yourselves. I emphasise that this is a completely free choice. Either you join us or you don't work'. Is that what the Opposition stands for? If it is, it should put out that message loud and clear to the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Mr Bourchier) agreed to:
That the question be now put.
Question put:
That the clause be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite clearly, the Government's accumulated amendments are intended to deny the right of unions to the preference clause, to deny the right of employees to have the collective security that is so essential to workers in an industry. It can be seen only as a move by the Government to cater for the Lathams of this world. These are the freaks who believe that everyone is out of step except them. These industrial mavericks are usually the very first to put their hand out for wage increases, for more annual leave, sick leave and all of the other benefits gained by unions when they are able to speak with one voice for the workers that they represent. This is truly anti-union legislation. The proposition that the Government is floating regarding the elimination of preference flies in the face of-
—I rise on a point of order. We have dealt with preferences, have we not?
—Clause 20 is relevant.
—The honourable member knows that that is not so. We are on the next clause. I suggest that the honourable member for Hindmarsh move on and join us.
— I believe that the honourable member's remarks are reasonably relevant at this stage.

—I point to the current Act and especially the provisions of section 47 , since they deal with the preference clause that the Government intends to delete. Sub-section (3) of that section also deals with another matter that is about to come up-I refer to section 144A-so it is very relevant. Maybe it is a question of these people not wanting to have their position exposed. It cannot be stressed too hard and often that unions have to prove their case before the Commission in order to obtain a preference clause to have unionists or workers united under the one union, or unions, as prescribed by the Commission. In fact, the Act also makes provision for those who have a conscientious belief so they too are covered.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to show how out of touch with modern thinking this Government is. In fact, a government of similar persuasion, the Liberal Government of South Australia, recently commissioned a report by an industrial magistrate who, I repeat, was appointed by the Tonkin Liberal Government in South Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear, and doing a good job too.
—I am glad the honourable member said that.
—You want to stop the airport. You want to stop our tourist industry.
—Order!
—It is all right, Mr Deputy Chairman. I must assume that the honourable member has had a good red tonight.
—Order! The honourable member for Hindmarsh will address his remarks to the Chair and not to interjectors. Also, the honourable member for Barker will cease interjecting.

—Mr Cawthorne was appointed by the Tonkin Government to review independently South Australia's industrial commission under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. We have it on record now that several members of the Liberal Party think that he is a good fellow. That is fine. He was an industrial advocate for the South Australian Chamber of Manufacturers and the Metal Industries Association of South Australia, so his credentials cannot be questioned. On the question of preferences to unionists and the position of unions in industry he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The issue of preference is a highly emotive one and viewpoints differ markedly as to its desirability.

However, all things considered, it is suggested that unless one views unions and unionism in an entirely negative way-which is totally inappropriate-it can be fairly argued that industrial commissions should have within their discretionary armory the power to award preference.
Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind Government supporters that that is what was said by one of their own kind after 14 months of independent inquiry. Government supporters have vouched for his credentials and I thank them for so doing.
—For Mr Tonkin's credentials.
—It is clear that Mr Cawthorne's credentials are above reproach.

—Mr Deputy Chairman, I rise again to direct to your attention that the honourable member for Hindmarsh is talking about preference clauses. As I think the honourable member for Wills would agree, and I hope you will yourself, we have dealt with the preference clauses and have passed on to the next subject .

—I have allowed the debate to be reasonably free-ranging although I agree that we are in Committee. The honourable member for Hindmarsh has been given a great deal of latitude on this point. If he wishes to continue his remarks he will leave that section and direct them to the remainder of the Bill.

—I did try to show the relevance of the matter of preference and the position of the unions under the provisions of the Act. If honourable members opposite wish to gag me, it is obvious that they have something to hide. What I have been saying is relevant because the rest of the Act goes on to deal with the penalties that apply. It is very important. What Cawthorne has said flies in the face of the proposition that is being put by the Government. He is a highly respected person. He conducted an independent inquiry over 14 months. He was not appointed by a Labor government. His credentials are impeccable. He has brought down the view that it would be far better for industrial relations and harmony in the work place if in fact the Commission had the power. This is the relevant point: The unions still have to go through the Commission, they have to present their arguments, in front of lawyers who are on $1,000 a day, to prove their case. In those circumstances preference should be available to them. I think it is relevant to this clause. Thank you, Mr Chairman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak only briefly to clause 10, which concerns the formation of industry-based unions. The question is: What will be the result of this amendment? Will it result in the kind of rational structure which the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) spoke about? It certainly will not. It will result in an increase in the number of unions; that is, of course, if it works at all. I think there is good reason to believe that there is no way in which it can work. It is a totally impractical and absurd proposition. But even if it is able to work it will divide the union movement and create more unions. There will be enormous squabbles. The Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission will have to decide questions such as: What is to count as an industry under the Act?

SPEECH.PARA: According to the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner), the Bill defines 'an industry' for the purpose of registration of an industry union as the business, trade, manufacture, undertaking or calling of employers. If honourable members opposite can make sense of that they are better than I am.
Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had more training in conceptual and linguistic matters than most honourable members opposite have had. I challenge any honourable member to give the Committee a coherent explanation of what an industry is supposed to be. What will happen is that the Commission will be faced with all kinds of complex questions in deciding what is an industry. This clause will have to be read in conjunction with another clause, which is very important. That clause provides that the Commission will determine that in fact it is a majority or a significant majority of members of the union.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us suppose, for example, that the steel industry in a particular city wants to be defined as an industry. Is the Commission to consider that as one industry or will it consider the steel industry throughout Australia as one industry? There are no guidelines on this. There is no way of determining whether it is one industry or many industries. What will be the position in respect of the steel industry in the same city? Will the steel industry in the western suburbs of Melbourne count as one industry and the steel industry in the southern suburbs count as another industry? There is absolutely no coherent process whereby the Commission will be able to determine what is an industry.

If the Government were serious about creating a more rational union structure and an evolutionary process towards more industry-based unions, it would have introduced legislation and it would have followed up that legislation for the general amalgamation of unions, rather than adopting this process which seeks to create new unions by pinching members from different unions and putting them together in such a way that it will create chaos and confusion. What the Minister has done in this provision is to put an onerous burden on the Commission. I am surprised that the lawyers opposite who have read these clauses have not raised the sorts of objections that we have mentioned. They, using their legal minds, have chosen to refer only to certain matters and to ignore other matters.

It is quite obvious from the definition of 'industry' that there will be total confusion. Groups in the community will think that they can set up a union simply because they consider themselves to be an industry under the definition in the Act. They will find they are not an industry. What will be the process that is to be followed in forming such a group in the first place? Are they supposed to go to members of existing unions and say: 'Look, Joe and Fred, you sign this and we will form a new industry union'? Honourable members can see that such a process will create enormous strife and tensions within the union movement. Of course, that is the very intention of the Government. As I mentioned earlier, the Government cannot go to the people on its record. It is seeking to create industrial disruption in order to divide the nation. It will try to blame this on the Australian Labor Party, but we will stand on our record . We oppose these provisions. They will not work and we will be able to say in a few months: 'We told you so'.
Motion (by Mr Bourchier) agreed to:
That the question be now put.
Remainder of the Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
