SPEECH.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Honourable members by now will be familiar with the practice of introducing an omnibus miscellaneous amendments Bill during each period of sittings of the Parliament as an expeditious way of making amendments of a non-controversial character to a large number of Acts. The Attorney-General (Senator Durack) said in another place on 25 November 1981 that, provided this form of legislation is properly confined to non-controversial matters, it is a convenient way of approaching the situation. That has been the guiding principle in preparing the present Bill. The short title of the Bill has been numbered No. 1 to indicate that a further omnibus Bill will, in the normal course, be introduced later this year in the Budget sittings. The numbering takes up a useful suggestion to this effect made by the Opposition in this House on 17 November 1981, when the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Amendments) Act 1981 was being debated. Some of the amendments are made by the Bill to correct printing or drafting errors. Others make drafting or other technical amendments. These provisions do not call for particular comment. Other provisions go into matters of sustance in varying degrees. I propose to explain in some detail the nature and effect of those provisions. In addition, a detailed explanatory memorandum covering all the clauses of the Bill has been circulated.
ACTS INTERPRETATION ACT 1901

In a statement to the Senate on 26 May 1981, the Attorney-General advised that the Government has decided to give effect to a member of recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances on matters relating to parliamentary disallowance of delegated legislation. The amendments proposed by the Bill to the Acts Interpretation Act give effect to two of those recommendations. One is to ensure that upon the dissolution of the House of Representatives, after a notice of motion for disallowance of a regulation is given in the Senate, the regulation shall be deemed to have been tabled on the first sitting day of the Senate after the dissolution of the House of Representatives. The amendments in paragraphs (a) and (b) of clause 4 of the Bill have that effect. The other matter is to provide that on the disallowance of a regulation which repeals, in whole or in part, an earlier regulation the repealed regulation will be revived from and including the date of disallowance of the repealing regulation. This is dealt with by paragraph (c) of clause 4 of the Bill.

Paragraph (c) also deals with another matter. In the course of its preparation a question was raised, whether the effect of sub-section 48 (3) of the Acts Interpretation Act upon a failure to lay regulations before each House of Parliament as required by paragraph 48 (1) (c) is to make such regulations void ab initio. If it did, any rights or obligations which accrued under the regulations between the date of making the regulation and the final date for tabling would be lost. The Bill clarifies this situation by amending sub-section 48 (6) to ensure that, upon the voiding of a regulation under sub-section 48 (3) , the regulation is regarded as having been repealed. The provisions of section 50, in relation to the repeal of regulations, would then apply. The principles contained in these amendments have also been applied by this Bill to the tabling of ordinances and other instruments of a legislative character under the following Acts: Ashmore and Cartier Islands Acceptance Act 1933, Australian Antarctic Territory Act 1954, Christmas Island Act 1958, Cocos (Keeling) Islands Act 1955, Coral Sea Islands Act 1969, Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974, Environment Protection (Nuclear Codes) Act 1978, Heard Island and McDonald Islands Act 1953, Norfolk Island Act 1979, and Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910.

Finally, I mention that the Bill applies sections 48, 49 and 50 of the Acts Interpretation Act to rules of court by the High Court, the Federal Court of Australia and the Supreme Court of the Australian Capital Territory. These amendments are also intended to give effect to the general policy referred to by the Attorney-General in the Senate on 26 May 1981 that there should be uniform application of the provisions of Part XII of the Acts Interpretation Act in relation to the tabling and disallowance of statutory instruments. It is considered that such provisions should also apply in the case of rules of court. The amendments to this effect are contained in clauses 67, 155 and 161 of the Bill.
ADMINISTRATIVE APPEALS TRIBUNAL ACT 1975

The Bill makes a number of changes to the membership structure of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and to the provisions governing the mode of operation of the Tribunal. The changes reflect the growing status of the Tribunal and its increasing work load. Many of the changes will give effect to recommendations of the Administrative Review Council and proposals of the President of the Tribunal.

The Tribunal now has jurisdiction to review decisions made under more than 100 statutes. It covers decisions in fields such as social security, immigration, repatriation, Commonwealth employees' compensation, patents, Customs, air navigation, superannuation and export grants. The Tribunal's case load grew from 227 in 1979-80 to 652 in 1980-81 mainly because of additions to its jurisdiction of social security and Commonwealth employees' compensation matters. Its case load is expected to increase substantially in the current financial year. The already increased work load and the further increases expected from the freedom of information legislation have highlighted the need to make changes in the membership structure of the Tribunal.

One of the main purposes of the changes now proposed is to rationalise the membership structure of the Tribunal, having regard to the role played on the Tribunal by judges of the Federal Court of Australia. Although both judges and non-judges may now be appointed as Deputy Presidents, in fact, only judges of the Federal Court have been so appointed. The Act as it stands does not distinguish between the roles of judges and of non-judges. The judges of the Federal Court who have been appointed as Deputy Presidents have played a valuable role, particularly in some areas of the Tribunal's jurisdiction. With the increasing work load of the Tribunal it is necessary to have additional members of Deputy President status but there is, of course, a limit to the extent to which judges of the Federal Court can devote time to sitting on the Tribunal. Consequently, one purpose of the proposed amendments made by clauses 8 , 9 and 40 will be to distinguish those presidential members who are judges from Deputy Presidents who are not judges, and to reserve certain critical powers for presidential members who are judges. At the same time, the Bill recognises the existing practice of appointing a judge of the Federal Court as President of the Tribunal, by requiring that the President shall be a judge of the Federal Court.

The greater part of the jurisdiction of the Tribunal is, in fact, exercised by the senior non-presidential members, either sitting alone or as chairman of panels of the Tribunal. Full time senior members are presently appointed for terms of years only. It is now proposed that full time senior members be appointed to the age of 65 years, to emphasise their independence in performing their functions on the Tribunal. That is clause 10. Further, the role of the senior member in dealing with questions of law requires that he ordinarily have legal qualifications. This is recognised in the amendments made by clause 9. Provision is to be made by clauses 14 and 38 for those members appointed to the Tribunal in future to take an appropriate oath of office, to mark the importance of the jurisdiction they will exercise. The present complete bar on outside employment by full time members of the Tribunal is to be replaced by a provision expressly authorising service with the Defence Force, and permitting other employment to be undertaken with ministerial approval. That is clause 15.

Clause 22 of the Bill makes certain changes regarding statements of reasons under section 28 of the Act. First, the Tribunal is to be empowered to review a refusal by a decision-maker to give a statement of reasons for a decision when requested to do so under section 28 of the Act. The Tribunal is also to be empowered to review the sufficiency of a section 28 statement. Secondly, a number of other changes to section 28 will bring it, so far as appropriate, into line with the equivalent provision in section 13 of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. In future, a certificate by the Attorney-General preventing disclosure of certain material in a section 28 statement will not result, as at present, in the whole statement being withheld, but only so much of the statement as is covered by the certificate. The whole statement may be withheld only where omission of the matter covered by the certificate would render the statement false or misleading. The working of the Tribunal will be aided by the provisions giving the President a wider power of delegation (clause 13), authorising a wider class of members to exercise interlocutory powers ( clause 17) and to give procedural directions (clause 26). The agreement of all the parties will no longer be required to the holding of a preliminary conference (clause 27).

Clause 25 of the Bill will empower the Attorney-General to intervene in proceedings before the Tribunal where the Commonwealth has a special interest in the proceedings and would wish to put argument on relevant matters to the Tribunal. Provision is made for payment by the Commonwealth of any increase in costs attributable to such an intervention. The Act provides for the President of the Tribunal to rule on certain claims by the Attorney-General to privilege in respect of documents and oral evidence. Because this jurisdiction is given at present to the President as such, and not to the Tribunal constituted by the President, the right of appeal to the Federal Court from a decision of the Tribunal does not apply to such a ruling. The effect of clauses 30 and 31 of the Bill will be to vest the power to make such a ruling in the Tribunal which will be required, for this purpose, to be constituted by a judge of the Federal Court .

It is often convenient for the Tribunal to be able to hand down a decision, with oral reasons for the decision, without the delay involved in the preparation of a written statement. As the Act now stands, it is doubtful whether this may be done, even where a written statement is provided later. Accordingly, clause 33 of the Bill empowers the Tribunal to give either oral or written reasons at the time it hands down a decision. If it does not then give written reasons, it must do so if requested to do so by a party to the proceedings. This provision is designed to avoid delays that now occur in the decision of the Tribunal being available in those cases where it has come to a conclusion at the end of the hearing, but must now delay the handing down of the decision until reasons for the decision have been reduced to writing. The change will be of particular benefit in many social security cases, where an early decision is desirable. The remaining amendments to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act are largely consequential to those I have already mentioned, or make minor changes to facilitate the working of the Tribunal.
AGED PERSONS HOSTELS ACT 1972

Part IV of the Bill amends the Aged Persons Hostels Act 1972, which is to become known as the Aged or Disabled Persons Hostels Act 1972. The key amendment is made by paragraph (a) of clause 45, which amends section 5 of the Act to extend to disabled persons as well as to aged persons. The amendments will enable organisations to accommodate disabled persons in hostels originally approved or constructed with grants under the Act for accommodation of aged persons only. Accordingly, the amendments also provide that where an organisation has made an agreement with the Director-General of Social Services undertaking to continue to use a hostel as a home for aged persons only, the undertaking will be deemed to have been given with respect to continued use of the hostel as a home for persons who are aged or disabled.

These amendments will bring the Act into line with the major legislation in the Government's program to house aged and disabled persons, the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954, which was amended in 1974 to extend its coverage to disabled persons. The amendments will allow organisations greater flexibility in the operation of homes funded under both Acts 'under the one roof' and will materially assist disabled persons in those areas, especially in the country, where the only available form of specialised accommodation is a hostel built with a grant under the Aged Persons Hostels Act. Introduction of these matters of substance also affords an opportunity to make a number of formal amendments.
AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY SUPREME COURT ACT 1933

Part VIII of the Bill makes several significant amendments to the Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court Act 1933. First, the designation of the Chief Judge of the Court is changed to 'Chief Justice'. This brings the designation into line with the Supreme Court of all the States and the Northern Territory. Secondly, clause 65 makes it clear that a judge of the Federal Court of Australia who is appointed to the Supreme Court of the Australian Capital Territory is not entitled to double salary. His primary salary entitlement will continue to arise from his Federal Court appointment. Provision, however, is made to ensure that, if the Supreme Court entitlements exceed his Federal Court entitlements, he will receive the higher amount and ensures that if the salary or annual allowances to which he would be entitled as a judge of the Court exceeds the salary and annual allowance by which he is remunerated as a judge of the Federal Court of Australia, he shall receive as a judge of the Court, an additional amount by way of salary or annual allowances equal to the excess.
AMENDMENTS OF THE CO-OPERATIVE COMPANIES AND SECURITIES SCHEME

The amendments proposed by Parts XV, XVI, XXVII and XXXVI relate to the package of legislation which comprises the co-operative companies and securities scheme. On 22 December 1978 the Commonwealth and the six States executed a formal agreement that provided the framework for a co-operative Commonwealth-State scheme for a uniform system of law and administration in relation to company law and the regulation of the securities industry in the six States and the Australian Capital Territory. A copy of the Agreement is set out in the Schedule to the National Companies and Securities Commission Act 1979. Clause 8 (1) (a) of the Agreement provides that the Commonwealth will submit to this Parliament legislation which has been unanimously agreed by the Ministrial Council for Companies and Securities, and shall take such steps as are appropriate to secure the passage of the legislation. The relevant amendments in these Parts have been unanimously approved by the Ministrial Council only after detailed discussion and consideration. Also, the amendments are of a kind considered appropriate for inclusion in the Miscellaneous Amendments Bill. The effect of the particular amendments is set out in detail in the explanatory memorandum that has been circulated. I draw attention to the following features.
COMPANIES ACT 1981

Under the amendments of the Companies Act made by Part XV of the Bill, the provisions of the Act relating to inspection of registers kept by companies and the availability of copies of these registers will be standardised. See, for example, clause 95. Other amendments result from ongoing work on preparation of the regulations to be made under this Act. Some of the amendments are not intended to change the operation of the principal legislation, but simply to ensure that it does, in fact, operate as originally envisaged. A significant change to the Act is in the area of registration of charges. It had originally been intended that details of charges contained on registers maintained under the pre-existing law would be transferred to the new registers to be maintained under the new priority system. However, because of administrative difficulties in some States relating to the transfer of information on existing charges to the new register, the Ministerial Council has decided to retain the existing registers for a 12-month period at least. This will enable the Ministerial Council to review the provisions relating to the register. For this purpose, a new section 215A is to be inserted in the Act by clause 105 of the Bill. There are also a large number of minor amendments which needed to be made to the Companies Act 1981 before it came into operation.
COMPANIES (ACQUISITION OF SHARES) ACT 1980

The amendments of the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Act are made by Part XVI of the Bill. The time within which the National Companies and Securities Commission may declare an acquisition of shares or other conduct to be unacceptable has been extended from 14 days to 90 days after the acquisition has taken place or specified conduct has been engaged in. The amendment is to be found in clause 132. Once the Commission has made such a declaration, it will be able to make certain orders which are to be published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette-see clause 133. These will include orders restraining the disposal or acquistion of an interest in specified shares, restraining the exercise of voting rights, or directing a company not to issue shares to a person who holds shares in it. These orders will generally expire after 30 days, although a person aggrieved by an order will be able to apply to the Supreme Court for its variation or revocation. Furthermore, in exercising its powers under sections 45, 47, 48, 57 and 60 of the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Act, the Supreme Court will have the power to make interim orders and will be able to make orders without requiring undertakings as to damages-see clause 131.
SECURITIES INDUSTRY ACT 1980

Part XXXVI amends the Securities Industry Act. References in sections 4 and 12 of the Act to an acquisition of shares or an acquisition of securities will be clarified by providing that they shall include circumstances where a person is taken to acquire shares in a company for the purposes of the Companies ( Acquisition of Shares) Act-see clauses 208 and 209. Also, in exercising its powers under sections 14, 83, and 147 of the Securities Industry Act, the Supreme Court will have the power to make interim orders and will be able to make orders without requiring undertakings as to damages-see clauses 210, 212 and 213 of the Bill.
CONSULAR PRIVILIGES AND IMMUNITIES ACT 1972
DIPLOMATIC PRIVILEGES AND IMMUNITIES ACT 1967

The purpose of the amendments made by Parts XVII and XX of the Bill to the consular and diplomatic privileges and immunities legislation is to assist in preventing the misuse of the customs duty exemptions provided by that legislation. Pursuant to the obligations in the two Vienna Conventions on diplomatic and consular relations respectively, Australia accords, by way of that legislation, customs duty exemptions to members of foreign diplomatic missions and consular posts in Australia. It is currently possible for most diplomatic and consular personnel and their families to import into Australia for their personal use motor vehicles free of sales tax and customs duty. Those vehicles may then be sold or otherwise disposed of without the payment of duties or taxes after they have been retained for two years. Luxury vehicles can thus be sold at a considerable profit.

The amendments increase from two to three years the period within which persons entitled to customs exemption under either of the Acts may not dispose of motor vehicles without restriction. The three year period corresponds with the usual period for which foreign diplomatic and consular personnel are posted to Australia. At the same time, the number of vehicles which can be imported free of customs duty by each family under the Acts will be reduced administratively. These measures are consistent with international practice.
COPYRIGHT ACT 1968

The amendments to the Copyright Act 168 contained in Part XVIII of the Bill are concerned entirely with the provisions of that Act providing for the Copyright Tribunal. Having regard to the nature of applications currently before the Tribunal and applications expected to be made to it in the near future, the Government has concluded that the existing provisions of the Act requiring members of the Tribunal to possess legal qualifications unduly restrict the range of possible candidates from which members may be appointed. It is felt that the deliberations of the Tribunal could be helped by the presence of members possessing expertise in other occupations relevant to the subject matter of applications before, or likely to be coming before, the Tribunal. Accordingly clause 139 of the Bill broadens the range of qualifications for eligibility for membership. At the same time, by analogy with the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act, only judges of the Federal Court of Australia are, under the Bill, to be eligible for appointment as President and Deputy President of the Tribunal . In this regard I point out that under the existing provisions of the Copyright Act, the President and Deputy President have more onerous duties than other members.

Clause 144 modifies the provisions of the Act permitting a tribunal to continue hearing an application after one of its members ceases to be available. The Bill will make the authority of the Tribunal to continue in such circumstances dependent on the continued presence of the President or Deputy President on the Tribunal for that hearing. The opportunity has been taken in the Bill to make other amendments to the Copyright Act to substitute new provisions regarding the termination of the appointments of members of the Tribunal, clause 140, the authority of the Deputy President when acting in place of the President, clause 141, and the fixing of the remuneration and allowances of Tribunal members, clause 142. The provisions substituted by the Bill follow the pattern of provisions for similar bodies in other Acts that have been enacted more recently than the provisions of the Copyright Act being replaced.
PARLIAMENTARY ALLOWANCES ACT 1952

These amendments are primarily designed to provide a legislative basis for the payment of a Presiding Officer who, though himself no longer a member of the Parliament, continues to perform for a period the statutory functions of the office until the election of a successor. Thus Sir Condor Laucke, though no longer a senator after 30 June 1981, was deemed to be President of the Senate, in accordance with the Parliamentary Presiding Officers Act 1965, until 18 August 1981. There was, however, no provision for him to be paid any allowance. In such circumstances an appropriate ex gratia payment has customarily been made .

It now seems appropriate to put the matter on a proper footing, and at the same time to repeal obsolete provisions of the Parliamentary Allowances Act 1952 which relate to allowances now prescribed by the Remuneration Tribunal. The amendments also provide for a situation in which a Chairman of Committees is required, for example by the death of the Presiding Officer, to take over the functions of his office for a time.
PATENTS ACT 1952

Part XXXI of the Bill includes provisions which amend the Patents Act 1952 to relax the requirements for patent applicants who wish to make divisional applications. The jurisdiction of courts under a number of provisions in the Patents Act is clarified, and two further classes of decisions under the Act are made subject to review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Part XXXI also introduces a wider regulation making power with respect to the professional conduct of patent attorneys. This is being included at the request of the Institute of Patent Attorneys of Australia.
ROYAL COMMISSIONS ACT 1902

The amendments made by Part XXXIV of the Bill will enable an Australian royal commission to function in a foreign country where appropriate arrangements in that regard have been made with the foreign country. It is envisaged that in some cases a royal commission would take evidence in the foreign country pursuant to its Australian commission and in other cases it would take evidence pursuant to an authority issued to it under the law of the foreign country. See clause 203. The legislation is proposed against the background of discussions between Australia and New Zealand for the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking, conducted by Mr Justice Stewart, to take evidence in New Zealand for the purposes of its inquiries.
STUDENT ASSISTANCE ACT 1973

The Student Assistance Act 1973 outlines the broad provisions of the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme-TEAS-and the Post-graduate Awards Scheme. The clauses which form Part XXXIV of the Bill will amend the Act to repeal those provisions which are no longer relevant, to make minor changes to facilitate the administration of the two schemes and to make certain changes to the procedures of the Student Assistance Review Tribunals which review decisions of the Department of Education on individual students' entitlements. The proposed amendments do not reflect changes in Government policy and will not restrict entitlement to benefits. As far as the administration of TEAS and the Post- graduate Award Scheme is concerned, the amendments will provide that the Minister for Education may approve part only of a course in addition to the existing authority in relation to a course as a whole, clauses 223 and 226. For example, a course may comprise an academic component which is suitable for approval and periods of employment experience which fall outside the scope of educational assistance. The amendments will also enable regulations to be made which would provide for the payment to persons under TEAS of amounts associated with travel to and from an institution, other than by way of reimbursement of fares, clause 224.

There are clauses which concern procedures to be followed by Student Assistance Review Tribunals. They will enable an appellant to withdraw a request for review if, for example, in the light of further information the decision being appealed against has been reversed in the appellant's favour, clause 232. An appellant will also be given the option of having his appeal heard by a two member tribunal where, for example, the third member is found to be unavailable on the day the appeal is scheduled to be heard, clause 233. The amendments will provide two further measures which are consistent with the Government's experience with other review bodies and the recommendations of the Bowen Report of the Committee of Inquiry into Public Duty and Private Interest, and are in the interests of appellants. They will require a Tribunal member to declare any interest he may have in the proceedings under review, clause 233, and will enable the Tribunals to safeguard the confidentiality of certain documents presented and evidence given in respect of a particular hearing, where there is good reason for doing so; clause 236. I commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill amends the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975 to provide a mechanism for Australia to introduce reciprocal countervailing duty measures. Last November, following the countervailing action taken by the United States against Australian lamb exports, the Government announced that Australia would be introducing this amending legislation. Specifically, the amendments will allow Australia to take reciprocal countervailing action in any case where another country applies countervailing duty against Australian exports without applying an injury test or using a concept of a subsidy broader than the concept currently embodied in the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act. The United States legislation already contains provisions that have the same effect as the measures proposed in this Bill.

Problems were created for Australia last year when America threatened countervailing duty action against Australian lamb exports without applying the necessary 'injury test' and adopting a broader definition of a 'subsidy' to that currently contained in the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act. The difficulty with America has been overcome for the time being as a result of a bilateral understanding with that country. This understanding was made on the basis of Australia joining the Subsidies and Countervailing Duties Code and, consequently , the 'injury test' is now accorded to Australian exports by the United States. The Government, however, has indicated that it will review its membership of the Code in the light of experience and the option of considering withdrawal from the Code remains open. Accordingly, the decision to join the Code does not negate the adoption of the principle of reciprocity in relation to countervailing duty actions by Australia. I commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House has a general debate covering this Bill, the Customs Tariff Amendment (Off-shore Installations) Bill 1982, the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment (Off-shore Installations) Bill 1982, the Excise Tariff Amendment (Off-shore Installations) Bill 1982, the Sales Tax Amendment (Off-shore Installations) Bills (Nos. 1 to 9) 1982 and the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment (Off-shore Installations) Bill 1982 as they are associated measures? Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering these several measures? As there is no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This package of 14 Bills has as its basic purpose the application of various Australian laws to drilling platforms and rigs which are attached to the continental shelf of Australia. Australia declared its sovereign rights over the Continental Shelf in 1953. This jurisdiction was effectively confirmed by the first United Nations Conference on the Law of the Sea held in Geneva in 1958. One of the conventions drawn up at this conference related to continental shelves, and Australia is a party to that convention. Australia's sovereignty over the continental shelf is clearly in right of the Commonwealth, as against the States, as was established by the High Court in 1976 in a decision on certain matters relating to the Seas and Submerged Lands Act. The Commonwealth, therefore, has the responsibility to control activities related to the shelf, and this power is relevant to the provisions of these Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition supports all of these Bills. I notice that the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr N.A. Brown) nods in fond accord. The Bills not only represent a necessary extension and clarification of Commonwealth powers, but also provide a sensible basis for the administration of various laws in relation to the peculiar circumstances of off-shore oil and gas drilling. In the past, the objectives of many of the Bills were partly achieved through the existing principal laws, together with the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967. One of the requirements of existing law was that all drilling rigs and goods to be supplied to drilling rigs must be first imported to an approved Australian port, before being sent to the drilling sites on the continental shelf. This importation requirement enabled the various customs, quarantine, immigration and taxation laws to be applied.

However, with the opening up to exploration and production activity of the vast but distant North West Shelf section of the continental shelf, and the likelihood that further remote areas will also be explored in the future, it has become impractical to import all rigs and goods to Australian ports before attachment to the shelf. This particularly applies to the giant production platforms for the Woodside project, which will be imported direct from Japan. Accordingly, these Bills provide that an installation may be brought to its operating site, provided prior government approval is obtained. When the installations are attached to the seabed, they will become under the legislation , a part of Australia.

The arrival of the installations and its attachment is to be supervised by officers until customs, immigration and quarantine clearance is given. Subsequent to the attachment of the installations, goods to be used on the installation in general will be required to be imported first to an Australian port. However, provision is made in clause 11 of the Off-shore Installations ( Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill for a collector of customs to exempt a ship or aircraft from this requirement. This exemption may be subject to conditions which will ensure that all relevant requirements are met. Exemptions may be desirable in certain circumstances, such as the need to obtain vital items in emergencies from places outside Australia.

The Opposition considers that all of these arrangements seem practical and desirable. We draw attention, however, to certain matters which are of some concern. We hope that these matters will be monitored closely by the responsible departments and the Government. We do not, at this stage, believe that there is a need to amend the provisions in relation to these matters; we merely suggest that they may prove to be areas which could cause difficulties.

Firstly, there can be no doubt that the potential exists for off-shore platforms and rigs to become a channel for the illegal importation of narcotics and other goods, possibly even for illegal immigration. Surveillance of the installations and movements of ships and aircraft in relation to these installations is clearly an important requirement. Section 59 of the Customs Act provides that ships and aircraft within the 12-mile limit may be required to bring to, or land, for the purposes of boarding. The Bills we are debating tonight seek to extend this power to enable a ship to be directly boarded, but also to enable ships or aircraft which are within 500 metres of an installation to be subject to these requirements. What the Opposition questions is whether a zone defined as 500 metres from the installation is really adequate for the purposes of this legislation. If the installations are to be declared a part of Australia, why does the 12-mile limit not apply? Will the distance of only half a kilometre make such provisions almost impossible to enforce? We are aware that 500 metres is the conventional safety zone around an installation, but why is this relevant to the administration of Customs law?

The second concern of the Opposition relates to the penalties under the proposed legislation. The penalties by way of fine of only $50,000 for the unauthorised attachment of an installation to the shelf seems inadequate and, more importantly, the fine of $10,000 for failure to meet conditions could, in certain circumstances, be trivial. These penalties are, we recognise, consistent in some degree with those proposed under the Customs and Excise Amendment Bill, which we hope the Government will find the courage to bring on for debate in the near future. It has been listed for a fortnight, I might add. However, we believe that the greater risks attending the peculiar circumstances of these installations, including the greater cost and difficulty associated with exercising control over the movement of persons and goods associated with the installations, suggests that there may be a need and reasonable grounds for more substantial penalties.

Our third concern relates to this Government's abysmal record in relation to Customs control. The inadequacies of the Government in relation to Customs have been highlighted by recent events-by the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking and by the report of March 1981 of the task force that inquired into allegations about the Customs service in New South Wales. One of the problems highlighted in these inquiries, which has again come to light in media reports of substantial delays in Customs due to a lack of staff, is the general problem that this Government has not provided adequate staff or equipment to the Bureau of Customs, or for the purposes of coastal surveillance generally.

The effectiveness of the legislation now before the House relies on adequate resources being provided. We know that deficiencies have been revealed in this respect in the past. The aircraft available for surveillance are too few and too slow. The Australian defence forces are increasingly being oriented towards 'big note' items, such as questionable aircraft carriers and sophisticated interceptor fighters, while resources needed for coastal and maritime surveillance are kept at inadequate levels.

My colleague the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley) is particularly concerned about and knowledgeable in this area. Later in this debate I am sure that he will make a few very pertinent points about it. The former Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore), who introduced these Bills, made no mention of the administrative or staffing requirements or of arrangements which would apply to the application of the law to off-shore installations. We in the Opposition make a considerable point of discussing it because we believe that it is at least as important as the enactment of appropriate law.

It is to be hoped that the Government will one day learn that it is counter- productive, particularly in a revenue-raising department such as the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs, to apply cutbacks and staff ceilings without proper regard for the essential functions of such departments. The present staffing level of this Department in the whole of Western Australia is 390. This is 10.5 per cent of the total of the State Offices. We are talking here about one-third of the Australian coastline and one-third of the sovereign area of Australia. Are these resources adequate? We very much doubt it. Now that off- shore installations are to be included as part of Australia-these will initially affect Western Australia most of all-we would like an indication from the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr N.A. Brown) of what administrative resources will be made available to give effect to this legislation.

I have indicated that the Opposition supports this package of legislation. I have also expressed our main concerns which relate to its effectiveness in terms of penalties, the geographical area of jurisdiction and the administrative resources and arrangements that are associated with it. There remains one other issue which I wish to explore in my remarks. The former Minister, in his second reading speech, claimed:

A very important result of applying the Customs laws to these operations will be the legislative protection of the rights of Australian industry to share in the development opportunities to the same extent as now applies in relation to undertakings within Australia.

The Opposition regards this as of crucial importance. Yesterday my colleague the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford), raised as a matter of public importance the problems being experienced in the Australian steel industry. One aspect of this problem has been illustrated in relation to the North West Shelf project where, I understand, Australian steel not only is absent from the platforms produced in Japan but also is not being used for pipeline construction . The North West Shelf project is believed to involve much less in Australian materials and equipment content than is the average for resource development projects. Linking manufacturing to resource development is one of the principal means of spreading the benefits of that development.

What should be done? As a starting point we should be looking to Canada and the United Kingdom, where planning offices have been established. In Canada, an office of industrial and regional benefits seeks the maximum possible use of planning skills, project development ability, machinery and material supplies from local companies, while in the United Kingdom an off-shore supplies office seeks the same objective in relation to North Sea development. While these planning agencies have been very successful, Australia is suffering a balance of payments deficit due in part to the import of machinery and materials for resource developments. This Government's continued rejection of planning and government intervention is damaging our private sector. Many opportunities for job creation and growth are being lost because insufficient efforts are being made to maximise local involvement in resource development. For example, the metal industries still have sectors working at only 75 per cent of capacity.

One of the principal features of Labor's economic management will be the establishment of government policy mechanisms which will seek every practicable avenue for local companies to meet the needs of resource projects. The package of Bills we are debating is in many ways characteristic of measures brought by this Government to the Parliament. Because they are drafted by efficient and loyal public servants, the legislation is a sensible and reasonable attempt to meet the needs of the nation. But there are two failings which are the direct responsibility of the Government. Firstly, there is a failure to commit the required resources and staff to ensure that this legislation is put into full effect. That must be a source of frustration to the public servants who have helped to draft this legislation. Secondly, there is an hiatus of policy-a rejection of the necessary clarity of vision and strategic approach needed to achieve all of the objectives of the legislation. I have illustrated this in the case of the role of the Customs Tariff in encouraging Australian participation in the resources sector. In closing, I reiterate that the Opposition supports these Bills. I stress the Oppositions concern that the Government should, at least on this occasion, take them seriously enough to ensure that they are given proper effect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although the Opposition does not oppose these Bills, some crucial points need to be made in relation to the matters before us. Some of these points have been raised by my colleague the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown). I emphasise in particular the following two paragraphs contained in the speech of the former Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, which are of importance. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It has been the Government's longstanding policy that the treatment to be accorded these off-shore activities should be no different, in principle, from the treatment accorded similar resources ventures being undertaken within Australia. The petroleum exploration and recovery activities taking place in Bass Strait and elsewhere around Australia for upwards of 15 years have been governed by the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967. In that period, the only extension to off-shore activities of Commonwealth law outside the ambit of that Act was the application in 1968 of relevant income tax legislation.

There are two points that need to be made about that. First, it is not true that it has been Government policy to treat off-shore installations in the same way as other resources ventures. Preferential treatment was given to the Bass Strait oil producers in a variety of ways. Secondly, if the Government wishes to use the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act as applied to Bass Strait oil to illustrate what may happen to legislation such as this, we shall have to monitor it very tightly in order to ensure that corruption and inefficiency are not rampant on these rigs.

The fact is that the Government's record in relation to Bass Strait has been woeful. This applies particularly to the collection of excise taxes imposed by the Victorian Government and the Federal Government on the oil. In that case the situation was described by the Public Accounts Committee of the Parliament-not by the Opposition-as one of negligence, in that up to $100m was lost from revenue. What has happened is that, firstly, the Federal Government relied on officials of the Victorian Government to measure the quantity of oil, but the Victorian Government did not have adequate computer facilities to do so. We had the further stage in which the Victorian officials, not having adequate computer facilities, relied on the measurements of the quantity of oil given to them by Esso Australia Ltd and Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd-the very companies which were paying the excise tax. We had an extraordinary situation.

An analogy can be drawn here. We have been assured that the provisions of the various Acts will be enforced on these rigs. However the question is: Are we to have a Mickey Mouse form of enforcement similar to that which existed in that case, which resulted in $100m of taxpayers' money being lost? It is extraordinary that the very companies which stood to benefit from the underpayment of the tax were relied upon to measure the amount of oil and to report on the amount of tax to be paid.
The Committee urged immediate action in order to rectify the situation. It asked for this action to be carried out as soon as possible. It said:

The Committee understands that following the Direction issued by the Designated Authority on 9 June 1980, a reassessment has been made of the value of petroleum at the well-head for all royalty periods from the commencement of production. The Committee recommends that:

officers of the Department of National Development and Energy, and the Auditor- General's Office actively participate in the final verification of royalty calculations which should be completed as soon as possible.

Although that recommendation came six months ago, on the best information available to me no action whatsoever has been taken to ensure that an adequate measuring mechanism has been put into place, so we are faced with a situation that is very similar to that which existed when the Committee began its reports. If this is to be an example of the kind of administration that is to take place with regard to off-shore installations, we are not satisfied. I can assure the House that the Opposition intends to keep a close watch on the Government's procedures for the enforcement of laws in relation to these matters. As the honourable member for Parramatta has pointed out, there are dangers in relation to this matter, not only in respect of purely criminal activities, such as the importation of drugs, but also in respect of the contravention of immigration laws and in respect of quarantine matters and other matters.

The fact is that the companies operating these rigs have been given a privileged position by the Government and the Parliament. They have been given this privileged position insofar as they are able to bring in goods, personnel, services and so forth, directly from overseas without going through the normal ports of Australia. That privilege should not be abused. The fact that the Opposition does not oppose the Bill and does not oppose making things easier in terms of the importation of parts, equipment and so forth for these developments gives the lie to the statements that are continually made by the Government that the Labor Party is opposed to resource development and to strategies to support it. We have not opposed these developments in any way. We have acted responsibly in support of whatever measures are necessary to ensure the success of such projects. This does not mean that we believe in allowing a situation in which such companies would be able to escape their responsibilities to the Australian people in terms of taxation and in terms of the pursuance of normal procedures. We believe in the principle that the Government has stated-although I believe that it was not carried out in the case of Bass Strait oil-namely, that all resources projects should be placed on an equal footing and treated alike.

These developments, especially the North West Shelf project, are of great importance to the future of Australia. My colleague the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley) will have more to say about that. I want to emphasise again that our policy on resource development is not to frustrate or to stultify development. We believe that within proper guidelines, with proper Australian participation in projects so that benefits can be distributed to the Australian people as well as to those foreign companies which have brought in capital, resources projects should be allowed to proceed and will be allowed to proceed.

The honourable member for Parramatta mentioned another important point. It was referred to in the second reading speech. We should be doing all that we can to ensure that the maximum employment and job creation for Australians is taking place as a result of these developments. Sometimes experts, technicians and skilled workers are available in Australia but are not taken from Australian cities to the places concerned. Instead, foreigners are brought in who do not even have Australian resident status in many cases and they are used on these projects. In particular, the immigration provisions ought to be overseen to be sure that they are not abused and that the maximum job opportunities for Australians result from these sorts of projects.

Finally, I mention the importance of the products-the oil, gas and so on-being processed as much as possible within Australia so as to create industry here, especially in the remote parts of Australia where we need to decentralise our industry to ensure that more people are encouraged to live there and to create a worthwhile social environment. I have talked to people who spend a great deal of time working on oil rigs and similar installations. Life on these rigs is not wonderful. The workers often are isolated from their families and friends and although the companies do what they can to create some kind of social environment, it is severely restricted. Under those conditions we hope that the companies will use the provisions given to them in order to do what they can to make life as good and as bearable as possible for the work force in those remote areas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak on this legislation because in large measure it results from Government consideration of problems which will emerge from off-shore developments in Western Australia. If developments on the North West Shelf go ahead they will result in large platforms being brought directly to the site. This contrasts with the initial development in Bass Strait, when basic equipment was brought in to Australia via Australian ports. It is also a possibility that occasionally-not on most occasions, but occasionally-materials and goods will be brought in directly from overseas and will not be processed through Australian ports. To ensure that these installations will not become staging points for the entry of prohibited imports, drugs, exotic diseases or illegal immigrants, a variety of Acts are being amended by these Bills. To a very substantial extent these Bills make the rigs part of Australia's territory. Establishing the procedure for the extension of Australian law off-shore is one thing; having the capacity to ensure that the amendments are enforced is quite another.

SPEECH.PARA: It is to the question of enforcing this legislation that I wish to direct my remarks entirely. One of the problems of enforcing this legislation lies in the legislation itself. A second problem of enforcement lies in the current state of surveillance and enforcement off-shore via the Department of Transport and the Department of Defence. The problem in the legislation is that referred to by the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown) concerning the limit on the type of activities that can be engaged in by Australian enforcement forces in the 12-mile limit to within 500 metres of the rigs. I suspect that the reason the Government has limited itself to that is that it must be slightly embarrassed, as any government would be, about the fact that it is effectively applying territorial law in an area which is not strictly to be regarded as territorial waters but merely as an exclusive economic zone. Therefore, the Government is acknowledging an acceptable international safety standard of distance around rigs. If that is the case, I can understand why the Government would do that but I do think that the Government ought to test the limits of the applicability of that commonly internationally accepted position. Whilst it may be all right in the North Sea, I suspect there may be problems in Australia in the remote areas with which we are dealing.

Given the nature of surveillance off-shore, which I will get on to in a minute and the very considerable distance that patrol boats carrying officers capable of enforcing Australian law have to travel, the Government may well need to develop a formula whereby boats that have visited those rigs and remained within the exclusive economic zone where Australia has, nevertheless, special rights, can still be boarded by government enforcement vessels because they will not have the time, under normal circumstances, to intercept any offender if the offender has had any degree of warning at all-if the distance to be imposed on the area of enforcement is only 500 metres. I suspect that we can deal with that problem in a legislative committee. The Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr N.A. Brown) might like to flag it in his new experiences and have a thought about it when it is there.

It is ironic that at the time when the Government correctly seeks to expand the responsibility of the Bureau of Customs via this legislation, it is effectively cutting back aids to enforcement. The Government expands the requirement for surveillance and interception off-shore and then reduces the capacity, or does not expand the capacity, of those given the task to meet this new demand. The new demand for enforcement and surveillance, quite deliberately as a result of this legislation, is going to be considerable off the North West Shelf in Western Australia. This legislation is devised to cover installations in an area where our surveillance and enforcement capabilities have been demonstrated to be defective and most vulnerable. The North West Shelf area, along with the whole of our northern coastline, has been the focus of worried attention by governments since the mid-1970s. The Commonwealth's responsibilities in the area have been greatly expanded by the 200 nautical mile exclusive economic zone. Also, we have become far more aware than we were because we at least have started giving the degree of surveillance of the problem of incursions in the area in which we should be interested.

We have had near the North West Shelf area several spectacular interceptions of efforts at illegal immigration-including the interception of several citizens of India, dressed like impeccable civil servants under the Raj, who were detained on an island. They made the statement that they had lost their way. I do not know whether they had lost their way to Charing Cross railway station or where they had lost their way to, but apparently that is the excuse they gave. The situation was quite evident. The incident was not isolated but that would have been one of a very few groups intercepted. Likewise, the Australian Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs and the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, when reporting on quarantine and on the illegal importation of drugs, in their reports in 1980 were both scathing on the adequacy of arrangements in the north. The Royal Commission painted a picture of almost unlimited access for the would be smuggler. Government measures to meet these problems have been quite inadequate and have been the object of criticism by the Royal Commission and by numerous interested bodies. This has been despite the stepping up of surveillance activities by the Royal Australian Air Force, contracted civilians and increased numbers of Royal Australian Navy assets devoted to the task.

In its defence report of 1982 the Government emphasised four areas in which it believed the surveillance capacity in that region had been improved. Firstly, mention was made of planned extensions and development of an airfield at Derby. Secondly, new patrol boat bases were to be constructed in Darwin and Cairns. Thirdly, moves to base port and home port vessels at Cockburn Sound were to be speeded up. Fourthly, increased surveillance operations by the Orion aircraft from Edinburgh in South Australia were to take place over the west coast. Left out of the defence report but included in recent election promises, including those made during the last two elections, has been a patrol boat base in the north-west of Western Australia. Patrol boats are absolutely essential to the enforcement of this legislation.

When we look at the surveillance and enforcement capacity of the Government to invoke this legislation, I believe that we see three problem areas. Firstly, despite increased efforts the Royal Commission on Drugs described the effort as inadequate and misdirected. As was pointed out by my colleague the honourable member for St George (Mr Morrison) in a debate at about this time last year, fishermen in a number of ports in the north-west and off-shore in the north-west set their watches by the RAAF and civilian patrols, so regular are they. The patrols are so timely that any would be smuggler could pinpoint when they would be likely to occur and therefore time his incursion to evade detection. In fact, the RAAF's contribution has been declining. In 1977-78 it was about 3,075 hours of surveillance. In 1978-79 it was 2,385 hours, and in 1979-80 it had dropped to 2,260 hours. Furthermore, the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) has made it quite evident in evading questions from me that defence capital infrastructure in programs in Western Australia are going now to be cut back. That will set back developments in Derby and will put the patrol boat base-I think he believes- permanently on the shelf.

A second point is that the capacities on the enforcement side are manifestly inadequate. Great play was made four years ago about increasing the number of patrol boats devoted to the enforcement task from seven to nine. Despite that increase the number of patrol boat days spent on patrol was increased from only 1,600 to 1,677 days per annum. Without a patrol boat stationed permanently in the north-west enforcement will be extraordinarily difficult. We are talking about enforcement on the North West Shelf itself. It will be more than 1,000 kilometres from Perth and more than 1,000 kilometres from Darwin. Given the steaming times of patrol boats, that will pose very considerable difficulties if patrol boats are to be relied upon substantially for interception and enforcement.

The third evident point is that there are too many departments involved in the process of surveillance and enforcement. There are already, or will be as a result of this legislation Customs officials involved. Also involved are the Department of Transport and the Department of Defence. We believe that the responsibility should lie purely with the Department of Defence on the one hand and the Bureau of Customs on the other. Now that the Government has added to its difficulties in this area and has sent the Bureau of Customs well and truly off- shore we have reached a point in time at which it may well feel inclined to believe that that rationalisation process ought to take place.

Now that we have an immense amount invested in the north west, may we have that patrol boat base and a patrol boat, as a matter of emergency? May we also look forward if we are not to have the patrol boat but merely the base, at least to some degree of innovation on the patrol boat question? There are in Western Australia manufacturers who have put forward perfectly adequate types of boats for the surveillance and enforcement that the Customs Bureau might well feel inclined to utilise. Perhaps the use of a group of smaller boats devoted to close in-shore and oil rig work, not necessarily to tasks in more difficult waters, might be appropriate. Such boats are available, incidentally extremely cheaply. Their use is indicated by this particular development and perhaps the Government will develop an interest in that approach. If this legislation suggests nothing else, it suggests how overdue such initiatives now are.
