DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Small Business in Australia-Canberra Rugby League-Anzac Day Ceremonies in Canberra-Slaughter of Seal Pups-Uranium Mining: Aborigines

PROCTEXT.PARA: Small Business in Australia-Canberra Rugby League-Anzac Day Ceremonies in Canberra-Slaughter of Seal Pups-Uranium Mining: Aborigines
Motion (by Mr N.A. Brown) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr F.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is estimated that there are more than three- quarters of a million enterprises in Australia. Of these approximately 93 per cent are small, employing fewer than 10 people and 99 per cent are either small or medium size, employing fewer than 100 people. The top 500 largest enterprises represent only a minute fraction of all enterprises but they employ more than one-third of all those at work. More than two-thirds of Australia's 700,000 small enterprises are to be found in three divisions-agriculture, wholesale and retail trade and construction. But there are significant numbers of small businesses in finance, transport, recreation, manufacturing and community services.

SPEECH.PARA: When we examine the private enterprise sector, small and medium size businesses account for more than 60 per cent of total private employment and a similar 60 per cent of total private sector profits. Therefore small and medium size businesses are very important to this country from an employment and revenue- producing point of view. They provide a vital and flexible base to the economy yet receive very little attention from governments and negligible recognition of their role in the community. Some States have set up small business bureaus and departments of decentralisation to assist.

Appreciation of small business can be enhanced if time is taken to look for the strength of the sector rather than concentrating on its alleged weaknesses. These strengths include: Specialisation for market penetration, fewer industrial disputes, lower overheads, certain tax concessions, benefits of modern technology, rapid decision-making, and small run production lines to service large business. The disadvantages are: Lack of general business training of owner or manager, lack of mortgage security for fund raising and the myth of inefficiency. This has been the scenario for small business for many years. However, the scene has changed dramatically over the past 12 months. There has been a tremendous rise in costs to small business. For instance, shorter working hours, increased wages, increased light and power, workers' compensation, interest rates, fuel and transport costs have all risen. Small business is experiencing great problems, unable in many instances to pass on the increased costs. Staff have been and will be laid off, increasing the number of unemployed . Small business must not be allowed to wither on the vine as it is the biggest employer of labour in this country.

The needs of small business in Australia which may be satisfied by government action and support have not yet, we believe, been fully accepted as real and fundamental in a sound economy. To date there have been mainly token gestures, many of which could be seen as politically motivated. These gestures have come principally as a result of inflation and the economic pressures which have created havoc with small business in the broad sense. It is imperative, therefore, that government recognition of the significance of small business in Australia be unequivocal and supported by a clear public commitment to give full and separate consideration to the small business sector, both rural and urban, in all investigations and deliberations relating to economic and financial policy, industrial relations and employment issues, trade practices, taxation protection policies, training programs and many areas of legislation and regulation where all business is now subjected to common treatment without due regard to the special needs of differing elements. Our Government and State governments must give this section of the business world careful surveillance and make every effort to arrest a deteriorating situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak about rugby league. I specifically want to take issue with a column called 'Curran's Week' that appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald on Wednesday 14 April. The article is headed 'Capital Punishment for Rugby League'. In the article the journalist, for want of a better definition, shows complete ignorance of rugby league and total ignorance of Canberra and the Canberra environs. I will discuss just three of the issues raised in this scandalous article. He first of all criticises the rugby league authorities for incorporating the Canberra Raiders team into the first grade rugby league competition this season. I must confess a personal interest in this because I happen to be co-patron of the Canberra Raiders team together with the former member for Grayndler, Mr Fred Daly. In the article the journalist states:

SPEECH.PARA: The competition is weaker for their presence.
The 'their' refers to the Canberra Raiders. The article continues:

Canberra may win a game at home, so to speak, when Queanbeyan is gripped by mid -winter cold: But then, a team of Eskimos could probably do the same, so long as the match was played at the North Pole.

Since then-that was printed only eight days ago-the Canberra Raiders team has won two matches, one on the very night of that article when it beat a New Zealand South Island team, which included six international players, and then last Sunday when the Raiders won its first major match by beating Newtown 12-11. Newtown, I am delighted to tell those people who are ignorant of the wonderful sport of rugby league, was one of last year's grand finalists.

Obviously Mr Curran has never even bothered to watch the Canberra team play. Even I have seen the Raiders play one game in which it was defeated, but the team was playing Manly which is No. 1 on the rugby league ladder. On that occasion the Raiders gave the Manly team a very good game and held Manly to 23- 13. This man displays total ignorance of the game. I think this article detracts from the great effort that the team has put into improving its players and getting itself ready to compete in first grade rugby league. I must pay a special compliment to the coach of the team, Mr Don Furner. I take issue on the second point in the article in which Mr Curran states:
The competition is weaker for their presence.

The competition has in fact been greatly enhanced by the presence of the Canberra Raiders. The team has attracted huge crowds when it has been playing at its home ground. The crowds have numbered 12,000 and 10,000, thus making it among the top teams in attracting crowds to their home ground. This man then takes issue on a third point when he criticises the calling of the team the Canberra Raiders. He states that in fact the members of the team come mainly from Queanbeyan. He says that why the name Canberra was used remains a mystery. He does not understand that in Canberra we attempt to think in regional terms. Most of the rugby league teams in the New South Wales competition do not have people from their home areas. In fact, the backer for the team is the Queanbeyan Leagues Club but 80 per cent of its members are Canberra people. Over 50 per cent of the players are from outside Queanbeyan. The sponsors are the Canberra rugby league clubs and the supporters club is in the Australian Capital Territory Leagues Club. If Curran had watched Canberra play and visited Canberra he would not have written this nonsense. He would perhaps have been more enlightened, like another commentator of rugby league, Ron Casey, who had been very critical of the rugby league authorities in allowing the Canberra Raiders to join but who was prepared to acknowledge that he had made a mistake when, after the Canberra Raiders won so magnificently last Sunday, he sent the team a telegram saying:
'Congratulations. It only proves that JC is infallible and RC is not'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was with a great deal of sorrow and anger that I read in the Press that eight extraneous groups had sought permission to take part in the Anzac Day ceremonies in Canberra, the nation's capital. Only three approvals were finally given and an even later development has led to further withdrawals, but I believe that any groups which have the remotest possibility of offending the traditional Anzac Day ceremonies should be excluded.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no point in my going into what Anzac Day means to ex-servicemen and women because I would probably have no conception. But I know, as one who has ex -service relatives, what I believe Anzac Day is about. I admit that it means different things to different people. The fallacious argument that the celebrations of 25 April glorify war is, I hope, now treated with the contempt it deserves. Anzac Day gives those people who played such a significant part in forging this nation and in shaping world events, many at a great deal of personal sacrifice, a chance to remember their past comrades in the way they wish to and as they have traditionally done since the First World War. I am not arguing that the decision made to allow extra groups to march is against any law . But it is against the traditional Australian adage of giving everyone, particularly those who have most earned it, a fair go. Surely this is what civil liberty is about.

Over 40 years ago-between April and late October 1941-brigades of the Ninth Division of the Second Australian Imperial Force, along with allied troops, held Tobruk in one of the most memorable feats of arms accomplished by Australia's fighting men. Legend has it that the Axis powers tagged them 'the Rats of Tobruk ', a name that they still wear with pride. From 8 April to 25 October casualties amount to 749 killed, 199 wounded with 604 prisoners taken by the Axis powers. I quote a passage from the Official War History volume on Tobruk and El Alamein written by Bart Maughan. It states:

. . . if the most dreadful burden borne by the defenders was the constant manning of shallow and sun-scorched diggings and weapon-pits in the regularly bombed bullet-raked Salient, in which to stand in daylight was to stand for the last time; these judgments only illustrate that each man had his own job in the conduct of the defence. The spontaneous respect of all arms and services for the performance of the others and loyalty with which they combined were the things that made Tobruk strong in defence and dangerous to its besiegers . . .

Now we find that the local Rats of Tobruk will not be marching in the Anzac Day parade because of the situation that has developed, in, of all places, the nation's capital. I feel that the very fact that those people who choose to interfere with traditional Anzac Day services are going against the wishes of veterans such as the surviving Rats of Tobruk who have done so much for their country should be enough for them to stop and rethink what they are doing. Of course, there were many areas as bad as or worse than Tobruk when we take into account all the battle fields Australians have fought over. This strengthens my case. How any Australian could even tolerate the situation now developing I cannot understand. Perhaps too many of us have forgotten. To quote a wartime phrase to those who have forgotten: 'Wake up, Australia needs you!'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to bring the voices of some wonderful young Australians into this austere chamber. I will quote firstly from letters written by students of Clayfield College and addressed to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), which I am presenting to him and to this chamber on their behalf. They tell their own story. Telita Holsted says:

SPEECH.PARA: I am in Grade 7 at Clayfield College. The reason why I am writing is because my class and I are particularly worried and concerned about the seals which are being slaughtered off the cost of Newfoundland.
Krista Hauritz says:
Do you realise just how many helpless seal pups are being slaughtered? Ninety per cent of them have been murdered since 1900.
Anne Hawley went on to say:
Harp seal pups are being slaughtered for their soft fur. It isn't rich people who need them but the pups themselves.
Ronald Singh says:

Do you know how they are being killed? The hunters use a large club and dong them over the head. That's bad enough but on top of that, the hunter takes the fur off while they are still alive. That's horrible!
Julia Sorby makes the following statement:
Everyday, the mothers of the seals, watch their pups, (which they love) being skinned, both alive and conscious.
Bronwen Kelly says:
This senseless killing must be stopped.
Kylie McFillin states:
It is a ritual killing which is not necessary.
Vicki Born went on:
Perhaps, as you are a man of authority and also I believe a humane man, you could make them understand that this killing is extremely cruel.
According to Lynne Rowcliffe:
The seals are only a couple of days old when they are slaughtered. In a few weeks or less over one hundred thousand are due to be clubbed to death.
Jane Gould states:
As you probably already know their numbers are rapidly decreasing.
Catherine McDonell went on to say:
Seals are a lot like us. You might think they are lesser creatures. I feel they are defenceless so they need our protection.
Michelle Warren states:
I believe you should stop this insane killing immediately by lodging a protest with the Canadian Government on our behalf.
Janine Wood made the following comment:
I thought you were supposed to make laws to protect our environment . . . and that's not just human beings.
Simone Turner says:
My suggestion is that the Canadian Government makes a tourist attraction of the seals and all the other wild life in their beautiful country.
Tanya Louise Wolfe went on:
'Life is not meant to be easy.' This saying is so true but please do try and help. These animals will become extinct because of the greed of humans.
Tracey Nicol states:
I think it is really cruel that these animals are clubbed to death and their skins used for commercial purposes only.
Toni-Anne Ward says:
Is there a law to protect them? Animals, insects and any other living being have a right to live. If they don't then there is something very wrong in our world.
Carolyn Reid made the following statement:
I am astonished that you haven't taken action before this to stop the insane killing of the defenceless seals . . .
Jannine Matted says:
The Canadian Government must be out of their minds.
In the words of Alison Morris:
How would they like to be in the seal's skins?
Jane Dunn says:
I feel that because the seals can't talk, we can speak for them.
Samantha Hudson states:
Remember these words 'Life is precious'.
Zoe Murray continues:
Would you like to be hit on the head a couple of times, then skinned and left to die just for a coat for someone's wardrobe.
In the words of Caroline Draper:
Those seals need you Mr Fraser.
Madeline Smith says:
Help them before they become extinct.
Helen Barr went on to say:
Many children and parents have signed a petition and won't give up until we have won.
A. Helyer went on:
We are trying to raise some money for the Green-Peace movement.
Lynette Jonis says:
At least next years seals should live.
Kimberley J. Bell states:
I hope you will try to make contact with the Canadian Government.
Sonya Townson went on to state:
I want you to write to the Canadian Government to ask them to stop this carnage of innocent animals.
The words of Hilary Odling are:
Please! The majority of Australians think these seals should be protected.
Alison Kennedy states:
Please let us know.

These children are presenting a legitimate concern. They look at the world with a clear gaze which is unmisted by the greed and self-interest which clouds the vision of a war-weary world. We in this chamber should heed what they say. I join with them in calling on the Government to approach the Canadian Government and to deny imports of Canadian harp seal skin products into Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Mr G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue of uranium mining and Aborigines was brought to our attention yesterday with the tabling of the report on the social impact of uranium mining on Aborigines of the Northern Territory, prepared by the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies. If and when the two new mines at Jabiluka and Koongarra go into production payments to Northern Territory Aborigines by way of mining royalties will be in the vicinity of $28m per annum. Clearly, such an enormous sum of money will have a significant impact on Aborigines in the region. The last section of the report, which is entitled ' Social assessment: A Caution', states:

SPEECH.PARA: Any assessment of the current impact of uranium mining would acknowledge that mining has brought to the Aboriginal people of the Region access to financial resources which provide a basis for a degree of dependence from government funding and presence, and for forward planning across a whole spectrum of interests.

If uranium mining has managed to achieve this and the benefits have contributed to the advancement, independence and well being of Aborigines, I put it to honourable members that it is totally irresponsible and indeed outright dishonest to use Aborigines as a vehicle for the anti-uranium cause.

There have been suggestions by the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West) that Aboriginals have become too dependent on mining against their interests and against the interests of government programs. Surely it is a desirable and positive step if Aborigines can attain independence from government authorities. Let us not fool ourselves. Mining royalties will place Aborigines in a position of being able to decide their own future in a very big way. We should be very suspicious of anyone in the Australian Labor Party or the Government who deliberately seeks to make Aborigines become dependent on them. The point I am making is that Aborigines will have the capacity to make decisions about how money is spent in accordance with their own priorities and not someone elses.
The report significantly speaks well of the Northern Land Council and its dealings over Jabiluka and Koongarra. It states:

. . . the Northern Land Council is going to great pains to identify the traditional owners of the two areas involved and to determine their views and those of other Aboriginal people likely to be affected by the projects.

The Committee's confidence in the NLC contrasts sharply with opinions expressed by the Australian Labor Party recently which have sought to portray the NLC as acting in a deceptive, irresponsible and underhand manner when dealing with Pancontinental Mining Ltd and Denison Mines. Cultural change and the impact of television on Aborigines is also referred to. There is no doubt that television will alter the Aboriginal way of life even further, particularly as more children include programs such as Sesame Street and Cop Shop into their daily lives. Policy-makers must be clear where they stand on the issue of cultural change.

We have three courses of action: Firstly, to formulate policies which will resist cultural change and sustain traditional ways; secondly, to formulate policies which will hasten cultural change and rapidly break down traditional ways; and, thirdly, to allow individuals their own choice about where they want to go in their own time. Personally, I favour the latter. I see no point in adopting the sentimentality of the first proposal or the aggressiveness of the second. The only sensible stance is to allow individuals who make up Aboriginal culture to decide where they wish to go. This is not to say that we, as Australians, should value Aboriginal culture any less but it is, I believe, the only sensible position we can adopt.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
House adjourned at 11.8 p.m.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: El Salvador

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 10 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to recent media reports indicating that Government troops in El Salvador have been responsible for the deaths of some 30 ,000 or more Salvadoreans in brutally gruesome circumstances.

(2) Is it a fact that the Government of the United States of America has been actively supporting the military activities of the Salvadorean Government by the provision of training programs and military equipment; if so, will he ensure that Australia dissociates itself from any United States policy and actions on El Salvador that will cause further suffering in that country.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of many conflicting and disturbing reports about loss of life in El Salvador.

(2) The United States has provided military assistance to the Government of El Salvador at the request of that Government and in the light of clear evidence of external support for left-wing guerilla movements operating in El Salvador. The United States has a genuine and long-standing interest in the Central American region which the Australian Government fully understands. At the same time the United States has underlined the importance of economic and social reform in El Salvador and has given over $126m in non-military economic aid during the last year. The Australian Government deplores the continuing violence, the human suffering, and the continuing support for the left-wing guerilla groups which have caused the Government of El Salvador to request military assistance from the United States.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Equal Employment Opportunities: Department of the Capital Territory

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) In recent years the Department has implemented a policy of equal employment opportunity and in February 1981 the application of the policy was reviewed by management, following correspondence from the Public Service Board, and found to be operating effectively.
(b) The main aims include
(i) Selection of staff on the basis of merit and qualifications regardless of ethnic origin, disability, sex, sexual preference or membership of a minority group.
(ii) Elimination of any forms of discrimination.
(iii) The formulation of training and development procedures which recognise the need for equal employment opportunity and promote the necessary awareness.
(c) The policy is being applied successfully.
(d) Management monitors the processes of selection, training, development and practical application of the principles of equal employment opportunity.
(e) The whole Department.

(f) The Department consults with unions on a variety of subjects and the Department's consistent application of the principles of equal opportunity has not given rise to any union complaint or representation.
(g) The Department receives and distributes publications of the Equal Opportunities Bureau of the Public Service Board, attends seminars and consults with the Bureau when guidance may be required.
(h) The Department does not regard the application of the principles of equal opportunity as a matter for priority rating-the Department's policy of applying those principles is absolute.
(2) Not applicable.

(b) what is the estimated extra cost of providing the shelter;
(c) will the shelter be able to withstand a nuclear attack;
(d) what accommodation capacity will the shelter have; and
(e) for what period will occupants be able to be sustained in the shelter in the event of a nuclear attack.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The new Parliament House will not have a bomb shelter.
The building will, however, serve the needs of the Parliament for many years to come and planning for its design and construction must take account of all likely future requirements.

Provision has therefore been made in the basement of the building for an area of 1800 m2 which has been set aside notionally as an executive policy direction centre. The Parliament House Construction Authority has estimated that the cost of providing the required space in the building is $1.82m.
There are no plans to fit out or service the space at this time and no special anti-nuclear provisions are being made.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Rent Concessions in Government-owned Dwellings

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 17 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What rent concessions are made available in each State and Territory for tenants of Government-owned dwellings in relation to the:
(a) location of the premises,
(b) household size based on the number of (i) income earners and (ii) dependents; and
(c) household income based on the income of the (i) breadwinner, (ii) spouse and (iii) other earners.
(2) What are the different formulae and arrangements used in each State and Territory for making rent concessions to public tenants.
(3) What progress is being made towards achieving more uniform criteria and arrangements for rent concessions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The South Australian Housing Trust is the only organisation where rent concessions to those paying less than market-related rents determined for the dwelling vary between the central metropolitan area and other areas of the State .
The differential is about 5 per cent difference in rent levels.

(b) (i) No specific rent concessions are based on the number of income earners, although each State and Territory has a rebate system based on the income received by various members of the household. (ii) Western Australia is the only State which makes a special concession for children with a weekly rent deduction of $1 per child for each child after the second.
(c) Rent concessions are based on household income with the formula for each State set out in answer to Question 2.

(2) The formulae and arrangements used in each State and Territory for making rent concessions to public tenants are outlined below. The States and Territories are responsible for the detailed administration of rental rebate schemes, including eligibility criteria, within the overall requirement that welfare housing assistance is restricted to those in need for as long as they remain in need. In all cases tenants pay the lesser of either market-related rents or the rent determined according to the following formulae. Family income generally excludes family allowances, maternity allowances, domicillary nursing care benefits, handicapped child allowances, education allowances paid in respect of school students and allowances from legacy. The information is current at 1 March 1982.
New South Wales
The rent paid by a household is calculated as follows:

(a) 20 per cent of the income of the tenant, or tenant and spouse where both are in receipt of an income. For each additional member of the household in receipt of a regular income of over $25 per week, $5 is added to the calculated rent.

(b) 18 per cent of total income of a single pensioner or a pensioner couple without children whose only income is the aged, invalid, widow's service or similar pension and any supplementary assistance. Maximum additional income allowed is $6 after which clause (a) applies.
(c) 20 per cent of the total income of pensioners with children. Increases in weekly rents for pensioners are restricted to $1 per week per year.

(d) Those occupying designated aged housing pay a rent of $13.00 for single pensioners and $20.90 for pensioner couples. In the case of multi-storey units rents are $20.00 and $26.00 per week respectively.
Victoria
The rent paid by a household is calculated as follows:

(a) 20 per cent of the total income of tenant and spouse where that income is less than or equal to the Victorian minimum weekly wage ($144.80 is currently applied) plus rent calculated under (c) if applicable.
(b) 20 per cent of the Victorian minimum weekly wage plus 25 per cent of the weekly difference between the income of husband and spouse and the minimum weekly wage, plus (c) if applicable.
(c) 10 per cent of the income of any other wage earner of 10 per cent of the minimum weekly wage, whichever is less, is added to the rent assessed under (a) or (b).
Pensioners with incomes less than the State minimum wage pay 20 per cent of income.
Queensland

A household's rent is calculated as 20 per cent of $83.30, less 25 per cent of the difference between assessable family income and $83.30 if assessable family income is lower or plus 27.5 per cent of the difference if assessable family income is higher.
Assessable family income comprises the total of:
(a) the whole of the highest weekly income of that resident in the dwelling being tenant, spouse, any of their children over the age of 23 years, parents or parents-in-law in receipt of a pension.
(b) two thirds of the next highest income under (a).
(c) one third of the income to a maximum of $3 of any other person under (a).

10 per cent of the minimum wage ($145.60) is added to the rent payable if, in the opinion of the Queensland Housing Authority, any person occupying the dwelling and not mentioned under (a) above should be included in the determination of the rent.

Rent payable for children under the age of 23 years who are currently employed is 5 per cent of the guaranteed minimum wage ($145.60) up to 18 years of age and 10 per cent of the guaranteed minimum wage over 18 years of age. For children on unemployment benefit rent is 10 per cent of income.
Full rent is payable by permanent residents after a total of 4 weeks absence in any 12 months period.
Single pensioners pay 19.5 per cent of income including supplementary assistance and married pensioners 17.8 per cent of income.
South Australia

The South Australian Housing Trust determines rents on a graduated scale which for the Adelaide metropolitan area commences at 18 per cent of income when the weekly assessed income is $50 or less, 20 per cent of income when the income is $160 and gradually increasing to 25 per cent of income for incomes equal to or above the Australian average weekly wage (based on $220). In calculating assessed family income any income in excess of $50 per week earned by a spouse is taken into account as follows:
25 per cent of income from $50 to $79
50 per cent of income from $80 to $124
75 per cent of income from $125 to $179
100 per cent of income $180 and over.

The income of an employed member of the household over 30 years of age and not a spouse, is taken as that of the breadwinner if it exceeds that of the tenant. For additional residents under 18 years of age no rent is charged but for residents aged 18 to 21 years $5 is added to rent. For residents over 21 years $ 7.50 is added when income is less than $150, $10.00 is added when income is $150 to $250 and $15.00 is added when income exceeds $250.

Pensioners pay a rent which is determined by the dwelling they occupy if it is a pensioner unit (rent varies from $9 to $10 for single pensioners and from $15 to $17.50 for couples) otherwise single pensioners pay $13.00 (17.4 per cent of income) and married pensioners $22.00 (18.2 per cent of income).
Western Australia

Rent comprises 20 per cent of gross family income up to $130 per week increasing by 0.1 per cent per $1.00 in excess of $130 per week up to $160 per week increasing by 0.2 per cent per $1.00 in excess of $160 per week up to a maximum of 25 per cent of income at $170 per week.
Family income is assessed as the combined incomes of tenant and spouse plus a proportion of any of the residents' income based on their gross income obtained by applying the rent scale shown above.

The assessed rebated rent is reduced by $1 per child for all children beyond the second. The earlier formula does not apply to single and married pensioners. Their rental is assessed as 18.8 per cent of the basic pension (at November 1980 ) plus supplementary assistance. Single pensioners pay $13 or $12 if they are not receiving supplementary assistance. The married pensioner rental is $21 and $20 respectively.
Tasmania
The rebate is calculated as follows:

the gross weekly incomes of the tenant and spouse plus 25 per cent of the weekly income of any other permanent resident up to a maximum at the State minimum wage ($147 per week) comprises the family income.
The rent payable when income is less than the State minimum wage is 18 per cent of that income.

The rent payable for family income equal to or in excess of the Tasmanian State minimum wage is determined from a graduated percentage scale which commences with 20 per cent at the minimum wage plus approximately 31 per cent of the difference if family income is higher, up to a maximum of 24.1 per cent of the total income when family income reaches $207.50 per week.
Single and married pensioners pay 18.1 per cent of the pension but single pensioners in bed-sitting units pay $1.50 less than this amount.
Northern Territory

Tenants pay 20 per cent of combined tenant and spouse gross income as rent, on incomes up to and equal to the Northern Territory minimum wage ($149.20). Beyond this level tenants pay 20 per cent of the minimum wage plus 28 per cent of income over that amount. Persons in receipt of age, invalid, widow, service or similar pensions pay 15 per cent of income and those in receipt of a supporting persons benefit pay 18 per cent of income.

A charge of $5 per week is made in respect of each non-dependent resident of a dwelling 16 years to 20 years of age (inclusive) and $10 per week for non- dependent residents of the dwelling 21 years of age or older. A non-dependent person is defined as one in respect of whom a regular gross income of more than $25 per week can be evidenced.
Australian Capital Territory
Family income includes all income of the tenant and spouse.
Rent payable is 20 per cent of income up to and at the ACT minimum wage ($145. 10).
Above the ACT minimum wage, 25 per cent of additional income is taken as rent.
Pensioners pay 20 per cent of their income including Supplementary Assistance.
$5 is added to the calculated rent for each additional wage earner resident in the dwelling.

3. A working party of Commonwealth, State and Territory housing officials was held in Canberra on 25 November 1981 and prepared a report which Ministers considered in March 1982. It set out means of achieving uniform rental rebate policy as required under the terms of the 1981 Commonwealth State Housing Agreement. A further report will be prepared by the working party for consideration by the Housing Ministers in September.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Terence Ronald Scott: Allegations about Medical Treatment

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 18 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What investigation has the Minister made into the circumstances surrounding the illness and death of Terence Ronald Scott, Regimental Number 38649, following the letter dated 30 October 1981, from Mr Adrian Bishop, National Vice -President, Vietnam Veterans' Association of Australia, to the Minister, which sets out certain details, made certain disturbing allegations about the late Mr Scott's medical treatment while in military service, and sought answers to 8 detailed questions.

(2) Has the Minister's investigation established whether the allegations made in Mr Bishop's letter are factual or, if not, where those allegations differ from official records; if so, what are the details; if not, what are the reasons .

(3) In view of the serious nature of Mr Bishop's allegations, will the Minister now give an unqualified assurance that Mr Scott's widow and family will be given every possible courtesy by the Minister and the Department of Veterans' Affairs in the resolution of this matter.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) An investigation into the late Terry Scott's illness and death has been undertaken. Information has been received from my colleagues, the Ministers for Social Security and Defence, on matters relating to their portfolios.
(2) There are some differences between official records and the allegations made in Mr Adrian Bishop's letter.

Mr Bishop alleges that Mr Scott was refused medical attention. There is no indication in the records of such a refusal. Further information concerning Mr Scott's medical treatment while on service cannot be disclosed as the records of servicemen are confidential. Details of Mr Scott's medical history will be disclosed only with the permission of his next-of-kin.

Mr Bishop asserted that there was correspondence between the Repatriation General Hospital, Heidelberg, and medical authorities in South Vietnam and the United States of America. Departmental records indicate that there was correspondence addressed to the Commanding Officer of the Army Cadre then stationed at Repatriation General Hospital, Heidelberg, requesting contact with army consultant physicians about cases of a similar nature among Australian and American troops while on service overseas. There is no indication that correspondence was sent to overseas authorities.
Mr Bishop alleges that there was no post-mortem. In fact a post-mortem was performed at Repatriation General Hospital, Heidelberg, as soon as authorisation was given.

(3) Mr Scott's death was accepted as service-related and his widow and dependant child are fully covered by the provisions of the repatriation legislation. Mrs Scott has been advised of the medical services available to her as an eligible beneficiary and both Mrs Scott and her daughter have received medical treatment at the expense of my Department in New South Wales. Mrs Scott has been advised to discuss her daughter's health with her Local Medical Officer and to contact the New South Wales Branch if any further treatment is recommended. I can assure the honourable member that Mrs Scott and her daughter will continue to be given every courtesy by my Department.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Co-operation with Italy on Energy Resources

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Minister release full details of his meeting with Italy's Industry Minister, Mr Giovanni Marcora; if so, (a) in what ways will the two countries be increasing co-operation on developing energy resources, (b) was alternative energy mentioned, (c) were any plans made to investigate alternative energy, (d) were any agreements made or investigated concerning co-operation on nuclear power, and (e) did the Italian Minister give any assurances on energy co- operation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for National Development and Energy has provided the following response to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: A number of energy matters was raised during my discussions with the Italian Minister for Industry, Mr Giovanni Marcora. These included the potential for increased energy exports-especially coal and uranium-to Italy, the possibility for co-operative efforts in the energy area and the scope for Italian investment in Australian resources development. No formal energy co-operation agreements were entered into but the Minister and I agreed that there should be continuing contacts and consultations between Australia and Italy on a range of energy matters.
A copy of the Press Statement which I issued at the end of my visit to Italy is reproduced below for the information of the honourable member:
'Statement by Senator the Honourable Sir John Carrick, KCMG, on his visit to Italy on 11-14 January 1982.

The Minister for National Development and Energy, Sir John Carrick, said today that industrialised countries need to continue to press ahead urgently with restructuring their energy economies despite the current relaxed oil market.

The Minister was speaking following discussions with the Italian Minister for Industry, Commerce and Handicrafts, Senator G. Marcora, the Vice Minister for State participation, Sig. D. Giacometti, Ing. F. Corbellini, President of E.N.E. L. and other Government officials during his visit to Italy on 11-14 January.

Senator Carrick said Australia could make a valuable contribution towards Italian plans for shifting away from oil into coal and nuclear power. The Minister said Australia has abundant high quality coal and uranium reserves and was one of the few industrialised countries in the world with the capacity to contribute towards solving the world's energy problems through energy exports. The Minister said Australia reaffirmed its responsibility to help meet the needs of those countries without sufficient energy resources and in so doing contribute towards economic and political stability.

Senator Carrick said that Australia was becoming an important supplier of coal to Italy, supplying about 10 per cent of Italy's coal consumption in 1980. The Minister noted that Italy's energy plan envisages a very significant increase in coal consumption by 1990 and that nuclear power generation would play a larger role in Italy's energy future.

The outlook for the future expansion of Australian coal exports was promising, particularly in the light of investments by Italian companies in Australian coal ventures. Similarly, Australia was in a good position to supply uranium for Italy's nuclear programme.'

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Murray Goulburn Co-operative

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 10 March 1982 :

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was the Murray Goulburn Co-operative charged a gross levy of $2.3m for butter it had attempted to conceal from the Australian Dairy Corporation before September 1979; if so, (a) was the decision taken by him or his predecessor the right honourable member for New England, (b) did he or his predecessor take a decision to further penalise the company with a fine of $151,000 for late payment of the levy and (c) what other decisions did he or his predecessor take in this matter.

(2) Was the Murray Goulburn Co-operative paid (a) $249,800 storage allowance for holding the same butter (as concealed from the Australian Dairy Corporation) in storage before later sale, (b) a domestic butter oil allowance of $382,000 for part of the product which was later sold for other products and (c) $163,000 to reimburse the company for interest it had to pay on finance borrowed privately rather than from the industry pool.
(3) Did he or his Department or some relevant authority waive $16,687 of the fine of $151,000 imposed.
(4) Does the Dairy Industry Stabilization Act require that penalties should be imposed on anyone who provides the Australian Dairy Corporation with false or misleading information.
(5) Was any penalty imposed on the Murray Goulburn Co-operative; if not, why not.
(6) Does he hold 1,244 shares in the Murray Goulburn Co-operative.

(7) Does the report of the Committee of Inquiry concerning Public Duty and Private Interest state that because of his executive role, which may involve allocating benefits between competing interests and because his position may give him privileged access to confidential information, a Minister must avoid acquiring any interests connected with duties of his portfolio and divest any which may have been acquired.

(8) Is it a fact that, as a result of the Committee of Inquiry, (a) a Minister should divest himself of shares and similar interests in any company or business involved with his department and should cease to be involved in the daily routine work of any business, (b) when directing the business of the department he administers, a Minister should inform the Prime Minister of any real or apparent conflict of interest that arises and (c) the Prime Minister unless he asks the Minister to divest himself of the interest, should either arrange for another Minister to deal with the matter or else give explicit authorisation to the original Minister to proceed with it.
(9) Is he in breach of the Government's own requirements in matters of public duty and private interest; if not, why not.

(10) Is he able to say whether the recommendations and principles contained in the Report of the Committee of Inquiry have been jettisoned in the case of National Country Party Ministers or are they being ignored by all Ministers with the Prime Minister's approval.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Murray Goulburn Co-operative was charged a total of $2.318m in respect of Dairy Industry Stabilization Levy on a product the Company had claimed was milk fat concentrate, but which was established to be unsalted butter and therefore subject to levy.

(1) (a) The fact that the product was unsalted butter was determined by my Department as a result of investigations that had been set in train by my predecessor, the right honourable member for New England. However, determination of the amount of outstanding levy was not calculated until the company, which was disputing the Department's findings, conceded that the product was unsalted butter. This occurred after I became Minister for Primary Industry.

(1) (b) Section 6(1) of the Dairy Industry Stabilization Act provides for a penalty of 10 per cent per annum for late payment of levy. In the case of Murray Goulburn, a penalty for late payment of $151,760.01 applied. However, a remission of $16,687.67 was granted to the Company in respect of the penalty that had accrued up to February 13, 1980, the date that I formally advised the Company that the product was leviable and that the levy must be paid. This was in accordance with normal practice.
(1) (c) Other decisions which I took on this matter related to the interest allowance paid to Murray Goulburn on the recommendation of the Australian Dairy Corporation.
(2) In respect of the disputed product, Murray Goulburn received:
a storage allowance of-$249,863.15
a domestic butteroil allowance of-$382,590.65
an interest allowance of-$163,215.52
all of which totalled-$795,669.32.
The product in question was automatically eligible to the storage and domestic butteroil allowance once the Company conceded it was unsalted butter.
(3) See answer to (1) (b) above.

(4) Section 22(2) of the Dairy Industry Stabilization Act 1977 provides for a penalty of up to $1,000 to be imposed on conviction of having presented information that is false or misleading in a material particular.

(5) The Department did not consider the records and/or returns of Murray Goulburn to be false or misleading. Prosecution under Section 22(2) of the Dairy Industry Stabilization Act 1977 was not, therefore, contemplated. The question in dispute between the Department and the Company was whether or not certain production was leviable under the legislation. Once the Company conceded the product was unsalted butter, it lodged the necessary returns.
(6) I and my family hold a total of 1,244 shares in the Murray Goulburn Co- operative.
(7) to (10) With regard to these questions, I refer the honourable member to the Prime Minister's statement of 2 December 1981.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 11 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Further to the Minister's answer to question no. 3750 (Hansard, 9 March 1982, page 740) has radioactive material ever been stored at Ravenhall and Derrimut, 18 kilometres west of Melbourne; if so, (a) between what dates was the radiactive material stored there, (b) in what quantity and (c) where did it come from.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for National Development and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) No radioactive material has ever been stored at Ravenhall. Radioactive material was stored at Derrimut from the late 1950s to 1979.
(b) and (c) See table.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: FFG Shipbuilding Contracts

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 16 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a report to the United States of America Defense Secretary by the General Accounting Office which accuses certain United States shipyards of overstating the escalation costs on shipbuilding contracts by delaying the computation of escalation.
(2) If so, does this report name, inter alia, Todd Pacific Shipyard Corporation as one firm involved.
(3) Did Todd Pacific construct Australia's FFG-7 frigate, HMAS Adelaide and are other FFG class vessels under construction by Todd for Australia.
(4) Will he give an assurance that Australia has not paid and will not pay any money on the FFG program related to the charges of escalation overstatement by Todd; if not, why not.

(5) Does he recall the conclusion of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence that in principle the expenditure overseas of large sums on Defence equipment should be supervised by Australians (Parliamentary Paper No. 260, 1979, page 71); if so, is this conclusion relevant in the case of the allegations made by the US General Accounting Office against Todd.
(6) Has he responded to the Joint Standing Committee's Report which was tabled on 22 November 1979; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.
(3) Yes.
(4) This matter is under investigation.

(5) Yes the Committees's conclusion does have a certain relevance to this case. The ships are being acquired under the United States Foreign Military Sales system which provides for United States Government contract supervising agencies to safeguard customer nation interests. However the progress of such contracts is closely monitored by Australian Defence staffs both in Washington and Canberra.
(6) I intend to table my response to the Joint Standing Committee's Report in the near future.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Unauthorised Fishing Vessels in Territorial Waters

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 23 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a report in the Sunday Mail of 28 February 1982, that a Papua New Guinea magistrate's court imposed a fine on the captain of a fishing vessel caught in Papua New Guinea territorial waters and confiscated his multi-million dollar boat?
(2) Would such action be a proper penalty to discourage violations of Australian fishing boundaries?
(3) Was the Taiwanese fishing vessel Yuan Tsuan caught in Australian territorial waters on 13 November 1981, confiscated; if not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware that on 27 February a Rabaul District magistrate's court ordered the forfeiture to the Papua New Guinea Government of the United States fishing vessel Danica, including her equipment and catch of skipjack tuna, after the Captain of the Danica had been found guilty of fishing inside Papua New Guinea's 200 mile zone without a licence. The captain was also fined K500 ($A650).

The vessel was subsequently repurchased from the Papua New Guinea Government, by the vessel's former owner for a fraction of its value. Since then an agreement has been reached between the Papua New Guinea Government and the American Tunaboat Association allowing access to the Papua New Guinea 200 mile zone for American tuna fishing vessels.

(2) Penalties such as vessel forfeiture also exist under Commonwealth fisheries law for offences of the kind involved in the Papua New Guinea incident. Forfeiture has been imposed on a number of occasions when masters of foreign fishing vessels have been convicted for breaches of our fisheries law.

(3) The master of the Yuan Tsuan was convicted of being in charge of an unlicensed vessel in the Australian fishing zone equipped for the taking of fish . He was fined $3,500 under the Fisheries Act. In addition, the vessel's catch was forfeited. Forfeiture of the vessel was not ordered by the magistrate as he was not satisfied beyond reasonable doubt that the catch on board the vessel had been taken in the Australian fishing zone. The master was also fined $200 under the Crimes Act and $100 under the Customs Act.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: International Court of Justice: Compulsory Jurisdiction

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 23 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: On what date and in what terms have there been changes in the last 10 years in France's declarations of acceptance of the compulsory jurisdiction of the International Court of Justice.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: In a notification received by the Secretary-General of the United Nations on 10 January 1974, the Government of France gave notice of the termination of its declaration of 20 May 1966. That declaration recognised as compulsory the jurisdication of the International Court of Justice in conformity with Article 36 paragraph 2 of the Statute of the Court. No other declarations have been made by France during the period in question.
